PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Commonwealth Home Loans
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, M.P.:

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal-Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony, M.P. a Commonwealth Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75 per cent and that at 1.9.82 the amount of principal had only been reduced by $395.06 since the 1.10.81 leaving a balance of $14,609.94.

(2) Your petitioners therefore request that the Government immediately make available similar generous terms to the many thousands of home buyers in Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to abnormally high interest rates.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHILDS; ELSTOB; GRIMES; HAINES; MCINTOSH; TATE
PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) Many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) The Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(a) Express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) Urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Yugoslavia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Federal Government of Australia discriminates against Croatian migrants in Australia the target of combined Yugoslav and Australian security operations with the express purpose of discrediting the movement for Croatian independence and statehood, and that in so doing it is aiding and abetting the Yugoslav regime in the sentencing and imprisonment of Croatian intellectuals, students and priests and ordinary people in the thousands, the imprisonment of more than two thousand Albanians as a result of the uprising in Kosovo at the beginning of this year, and the murder by Yugoslav Secret Police of more than 70 Croats in Western Europe in the past few years.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate urge the Government that diplomatic relations with Yugoslavia be called into question and discontinued as a sign of protest, and that Australia ask the United Nations General Assembly to supervise a referendum whereby the constituent nations of the so-called Federation of Yugoslavia might vote on the question of secession.

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace Klaipeda, Lithuania was the only church permitted (by the Soviet authorities) to be built in post-war Lithuania.
That the church was built by the Catholic parishioners from their own resources and with support from overseas Christians.
That upon completion of the church building in 1960, the church was not allowed to be consecrated and, in 1961 was resumed by the State for purposes other than religious.

That this resumption of the church and the subsequent persecution and arrests of the local clergy and other christians is contrary to the spirit and the letter of the Universal declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Human Rights.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled request the Australian Government to communicate most strongly to the Government of the USSR the sympathy of the petitioners for the plight of the Lithuanian Christians and ask that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the Catholics of Klaipeda for the practice of their religion without interference.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED WAGES FREEZE: GENERATION OF EMPLOYMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Following the Premiers Conference yesterday and the announcements made by the Government last night, when will the estimated $300m to be saved by the proposed public sector wages freeze be made available for employment generating activities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should say in answering this question that later today, perhaps at the time listed for statements from Ministers, I will make a statement, which Mr Anthony will be making in another place, on the broad terms of the Premiers Conference. As to this particular amount of money, the Government's intention is to act as early as possible. It has decided that it will make this money available throughout the Commonwealth for employment generating projects of its indication. It will seek from the Premiers their views, and also through them local government involvement. The money will be made available as quickly as it can be put into the stream, as soon as the projects are clearly identified.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that the sum saved, $300m, will not ultimately accrue to the Commonwealth as revenue until the end of the 12 months period, will expenditure be incurred on job development programs as the money anticipated to be saved comes in? If not, when?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —That amount will be set aside for job creation. We will not wait for the actual savings to be made, month by month. The notional amount will be used to create various jobs. Much of it will be passed directly to the States to enable them to create jobs. It will be passed out in the ordinary way that other revenue is paid out to the States, month by month.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and draw her attention to a report in this morning's Australian which alleges that eight Soviet motor mechanics are being employed by Belarus Tractors Pty Ltd at Milperra and are being paid directly from the Soviet Union. Is the report correct? If so, can the Minister inform the chamber of the date on which entry visas were granted to the Russian mechanics and whether work being undertaken by these men could be carried out by skilled Australian unemployed tradesmen?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not seen the report and I do not know whether the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is aware of it. I will seek the information from him and see what response he is able to make on the matter.

—Will the Minister for National Development and Energy concede that those charges and prices which are set by the Government should be controlled so that prices are frozen or minimally increased during the next 12 months? In particular, I ask: Should the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting in Vienna on 19 December result in a lowering of the Saudi light crude bench-mark price of $34 a barrel, will he ensure that Australian motorists get the immediate benefit of a lowering of the import parity price for Australian produced oil? If there is no lowering of the bench-mark price at the Vienna meeting, will the Government in any case freeze the price of petrol to motorists insofar as it is within the Government's control?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has decided that it will take steps within the areas for which it has responsibility, including medical fees and so on, to get restraint. That was part of our announcement yesterday. The Government has indicated, and I have indicated here, that it is its intention to maintain the link with import parity pricing. That means that if the prices were to rise, we would follow that; if the prices were to fall, we would follow that. The Government makes these adjustments on 1 January and 1 July of each year. It would be the Government's intention to continue to make that adjustment on 1 January of next year.

ANSWER.PARA: Whereas some quite wild statements have been made by some, including State Premiers, that there is likely to be an 8 cent to 10 cent rise because of the ordinary events of the past, if the normal conditions occur and the $US34 price still maintains as at 1 January, the anticipated increase would be 2 cents to 2 1/2 cents. The extreme estimates are quite wrong. The Government intends to maintain its import parity pricing because it is fundamental to this country's recovery that we should have an energy balance, a petroleum balance. If there were to be a departure from import parity pricing, one could immediately expect that there would be a falling away in oil and gas exploration in this country, and a loss of employment in that regard, but, more importantly for the future, a tremendous increase in our dependence upon imported oil and, therefore, upon foreign exchange. It would be the utmost stupidity to have policies that were ' stop and go', which would destroy the one thing that is going for us.

The fact is that import parity pricing has changed the face of Australia's future with regard to oil and gas. Whereas it was very likely that there would be a fall-off in our self-sufficiency from 67 per cent some two years ago to 40 per cent by the end of this decade, and perhaps 20 per cent by the end of the century, now, because we are finding more because of the impact of import parity pricing, we shall almost certainly have a maintenance of that self-sufficiency over this decade. It is too early to predict that fully, but at least there is that reason for optimism. That is an enormous saving and value to Australia. We should do nothing to disturb that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer to an article in today's Press which states that the major Telecom Australia union claims that about 16,000 jobs will be threatened if the Government adopts the recommendations of the Davidson report, the Committee of Inquiry into Telecommunication Services in Australia. It was also stated that the local electronics manufacturing area would be jeopardised and may not even survive. Is the Minister able to comment on these assertions?

—I believe that the assertions made in relation to the Davidson report are not well founded on fact. We do not believe that the loss of employment would be of the order that has been mentioned. I am not even aware of how that has been estimated. The question will need to be referred to the Minister, Mr Brown. I undertake to do that for Senator Townley.

—I should like to ask a question concerning the dam on the Franklin River of a Minister who was in the Cabinet discussions on this question when the decision was made-preferably Senator Peter Baume, but, if he was not in the Cabinet discussions, then the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Minister aware of an interview that Mr Anthony, the Acting Prime Minister, gave this morning in which he indicated that the compromise to which he alluded over the Franklin consists of letting the dam and the world heritage listing proceed together? Does not the Minister consider that to indicate that the Federal Government will allow the dam to proceed, only three days after winning the Flinders by-election on a 'no dams' policy and some five days before the World Heritage Committee meets to discuss the South West Tasmania nomination, is to hold the World Heritage Committee in contempt, to treat our nomination as a farce and to bring Australia into international disrepute? Can the Minister indicate how the building of a dam that will flood 133 square kilometres of wilderness, 13,000 hectares, and destroy archaeological sites of irreplaceable value will be achieved while that area is to be preserved? Can the Minister indicate why the Federal Government regarded the Franklin River as an area of international significance in December 1981, when in November 1982 it is prepared to see the area inundated? Can the Minister indicate what proposal the Australian delegation will be putting to the World Heritage Committee in Paris on 13 December-five days hence-now that the Government appears to have done an about-turn on the Franklin River and allowed it to be flooded?

—It is not appropriate to comment in any way on Cabinet discussions, on who was present or on what was said. Senator Chipp, as a person who served in Cabinet, would know that as well as anyone. The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment will be making a statement to the Parliament later this afternoon. That is an appropriate thing for him to do. I do not intend to pre- empt that statement. He will make a statement about the dam. Of course, the dam site represents a part of the area for which listing is being sought. I do not regard it as inappropriate that the Commonwealth should want to continue with the listing. I regard the application and the listing as being of importance. The submission which the Government has sent to Paris to be put before the World Heritage Committee will be covered in the statement by the Minister.
—Will you make the statement here too?
—Yes.

—I raise a point of order. I think it could be fairly said that the two hottest issues in this country at the moment are the proposed wages freeze and the damming of the Franklin River. Senator Button has asked a question on the former and received no answer from the Leader of the Government. I have just asked a question based on a Press conference-not on a Cabinet meeting-given by Mr Anthony on the steps of Parliament House this morning wherein he stated that it was possible to proceed simultaneously with the World Heritage listing of South West Tasmania and the flooding of the Franklin River. My question was based on that. I suggest that Question Time is becoming an absolute farce when Ministers such as Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Peter Baume are able to evade direct questions of this nature.
—Senator Chipp and other honourable senators are aware that Ministers have the right to answer questions as they see fit.
—I ask a supplementary question. How can the Minister for Education reconcile Mr Anthony's statement that it is not incompatible to proceed with--
—You raised a point of order on your own question. Proceedings are not being broadcast.

—I have proceeded in this place for 22 years without Senator Harradine's help. I can well do without it now. Will the Minister try to reconcile for the Senate the statements that it is compatible to proceed with the flooding of the Franklin River and the listing of the wilderness area of South West Tasmania on the World Heritage List?

—I am grateful for the supplementary question because by way of interjection Senator Coates asked me whether the statement being made by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment in another place will be made here. That is our intention. When the Minister makes it in the other place I will seek leave to make it here for honourable senators. In other areas that have been listed on the World Heritage List-Kakadu National Park, for example-it was compatible with the listing to set aside some areas for a particular purpose. As I said earlier, the area to be covered by the proposed dam represents a part of the area which is recommended for listing.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. I ask: Is the Australian Government aware of the report on the front page of the Launceston Examiner of 6 December 1982 that the Tasmanian Government has received, and has been withholding since 10 November, a confidential legal opinion commissioned by that Government from Mr J. D. Merralls, Q.C., an eminent Melbourne counsel, which confirmed the advice of the Tasmanian Crown Solicitor's Office that the Commonwealth has a duty and the authority to enforce the World Heritage Convention in Australian law and can override Tasmanian decisions in respect of the Franklin dam? Has the Australian Government received a copy of Mr Merralls's 25-page opinion? If not, will it seek it from Premier Gray so that his constant propaganda against Commonwealth power can be exposed, particularly in the light of the message conveyed to the Australian Government by the tremendous 41 per cent write-in of the 'No Dams' vote in the Flinders by-election last Saturday?
—How many didn't write in?
—How many wrote the other thing?
—Order!

—Mr President, I am happy to respond to the argument between Senator Missen and Senator Harradine but unfortunately I am not familiar with the report in the Launceston Examiner and I have not heard of the legal opinion referred to in the question. I will refer the question to the Acting Attorney- General and see whether he has information for the honourable senator.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether it is a fact that the Budget deficit is now approaching $4,000m and is expected to pass that mark as the receipts drop from the ailing economy? Is it not also a fact that the Government's take from the oil levy is a further $4,000m? Is it fair now to ask where all that money is going? Is it fair to ask, with such substantial support, why the Government has not been able to manage the economy much more effectively than it has? Has the Government now forgotten its intention to pursue and to recover the massive further amounts of money that have been lost to the Treasury through tax avoidance and evasion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges asked his question in five parts. As to the first part of his question, that the deficit is approaching $4 billion, yesterday I made the point that essentially there are three elements to that. The first is the drought which could not be predicted and which is therefore absorbing approximately $360m. I would have thought that no honourable senator here would object to that being an additional expenditure to our previous deficit. Secondly, there has been a more rapid growth in unemployment than had been predicted by any of the departments or by the Government and also the nature of unemployment involving mature adults and married people, pushing up the costs. Thirdly, because of the slowing down of the economy due to overseas influences there has been a fall-off in revenue. So the answer to the first part of the question is yes, the deficit is now considered to be in that region.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the second part of the question as to whether it is a fact that the oil levy is in the order of $4,000m is no. From my recollection, but subject to checking, it is in the order of $3.2 billion to $3.3 billion. But I will check that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Billion?

—Billion dollars, yes. I will check that and let the precise figure be known. It is something of that magnitude. Senator Georges asked where that money is going to. I am very happy to say that it is going to such matters as allowing a cut in taxes, as announced recently, from 1 November; a substantial increase in family allowances, as announced in the Budget; an increase in the dependent spouse allowance; a subsidy on housing and a whole variety of new social services and welfare benefits going to the people. So the money that is accruing from the processes of the oil levy is going back to the people in the way of social welfare benefits, education benefits, Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowances and in the extension of benefits generally. Quite clearly, that program was applauded and approved recently in the Flinders by-election. With regard to any suggestion that the deficit reflects bad management, I draw the attention of Senator Georges to the fact that the proposal of the Australian Labor Party was to have a deficit of at least that magnitude. The fact of the matter is that the Government has managed well. It has passed the revenue that it has gained back to the people by way of a large number of benefits.

ANSWER.PARA: The final part of the question related to pursuing the recovery of revenue lost by way of tax evasion or avoidance. Legislation has been passed through this Parliament. It will be the subject of vigorous action by the Australian Taxation Office. I remind the Senate that this Government, in the course of its seven years in office, has had an unprecedented record in pursuing tax evasion. It will continue to do so. It is mindful of the fact that pay-as-you-earn wage earners should not be asked to bear a burden for others who, by using the cash economy or other devices, try to avoid their fair and just burden.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, refers to the frequent complaints about the lact of critical information given on packages and containers of much of the processed food manufactured in Australia. Has the Government closely considered whether manufacturers should be required by law to indicate the percentages of each foodstuff used in the preparation of a marketed product, rather than just list the contents? If so, is the Government planning to legislate accordingly?

—The labelling of processed foods is really a subject of State and Territory legislation. For that reason the Commonwealth has a limited capacity to take the action recommended by Senator Walters. Of course, the food standards to which the States refer are standards which have been developed by the National Health and Medical Research Council through its Food Standards Committee. This Committee is aware of public concern regarding food labelling. A working party has been formed recently to consider the provision of improved information on labels, including percentage ingredient labelling. The working party report will go to the Council. If it is endorsed, it will go from there to the States and to the Territories to see whether their governments will adopt into legislation the recommendations which are made. It is only in the Australian Capital Territory that the Commonwealth could consider a direct application of any recommendations. We will, of course, take it under consideration in relation to the Australian Capital Territory. It will take some time for the processes I have described to be completed. The advice I have is that after the appropriate consultations have taken place the matter would probably not be finalised for the NH and MRC's consideration until early 1984 at the earliest.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to statements made by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, that by reducing wages we will make Australian goods competitive on domestic and world markets. Is the Minister aware that wages in countries exporting goods to Australia in ever increasing quantities range from $1 to $5 a day with few, if any, other benefits such as paid holidays or sick pay? In what way does the Government believe that we can compete with such near slave wage produced goods, be they white goods, textiles, clothing, footwear or other consumer goods?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not imagine that anyone would think that what has been contemplated with a wages pause for 12 months would enable us to compete with the wage levels of many of the countries lying to our north. But as far as Australia is concerned, what needs to be looked at is the level of profitability of the companies which are seeking to employ people and the level of prices of the commodities which we seek to sell. It is fairly evident that a wages pause would be of assistance. That does not mean that we will drop our wage levels and conditions down to those of countries with which we would not be able to be compared in any terms, but we may be able to have a better relationship between profitability and competitiveness than we will have if we have continuing wage increases, especially at the level of the last year or two. What is contemplated will be of assistance to those who are seeking to give employment and to continue employment and will make us more competitive in a number of ways with those with whom we seek to trade.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. I notice that the United States Federal Aviation Administration has advertised tenders which will close by January 1983 for the provision of 100 to 125 microwave landing systems. Will the Australian Interscan system compete for this contract? What will be the extent of the Australian industry's involvement in this undertaking?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I understand it an Interscan bid for this contract will be submitted to the United States of America in January of next year. Firm bids for the manufacture of specific subassemblies have been requested from 25 Australian companies for inclusion in the Interscan system. Under the United States FAA system there will be a further 12 months of procurement negotiation with selected firms before a supply contract is awarded. If the Interscan bid is successful the Australian companies could expect to commence manufacture in early 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs recall giving a direction to the Aboriginal Development Commission on 22 September 1981 in his then capacity as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to make a grant of an amount not exceeding $338,000 to the South Australian Government in relation to land known as Granite Downs Station, being land which is to be transferred, on the expiry of existing leases, to the Pitjantjatjara people? Why did the Minister not lay a copy of that direction before the Senate as required by section 11 (3) of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980? How could the Minister give such a direction when the ADC had already received advice in March 1981 from the Attorney-General's Department that the making of such a payment by the Aboriginal Development Commission was outside the terms of the ADC Act?

QUESTION.PARA: Was that money ultimately to be paid by the South Australian Government to a Mr Hugh McLachlan, the present lessee of Granite Downs Station, as compensation for loss of reasonable expectation that the leases would be renewed upon their expiration? Has that sum of money, which I understand represented almost half of the Commission's land purchase allocation for 1981-82, already been paid over by the ADC despite the fact that the four leases in question do not expire until between 1996 and 2008 respectively and that the Pitjantjatjara people will have no enjoyment of the land until then? Finally, how can the Government justify tying up so much money for so long in non-Aboriginal hands especially when the payment of that money has had such a devastating effect on the ADC's land acquisition budget?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senator Evans's question is based upon a misapprehension. I will seek to obtain the documents and the details. Senator Evans's question is based upon his presumption that I issued a direction to the ADC. I believe the facts will reveal that I issued no direction, but I will check on this. Had there been a direction issued, of course it would have been laid before the Parliament as required under the Act. I believe it was not a direction in that sense and, therefore, was not laid before the Parliament. I think it appropriate that I obtain the documents and a considered answer and come back to the Senate with the information for Senator Evans. As I say, I think he is incorrect in the assumption underlying the question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction. I refer to the fact that earlier this year the Government announced that it had decided to implement the recommendations of the Crawford report on the revitalisation of the Australian shipping industry, including the granting of tax concessions and investment allowances for Australian-owned ships. Implicit in this decision was the requirement that overall manpower costs for Australian ships should be reduced to competitive international levels. I ask the Minister: Is it not an obvious fact that total manpower costs are affected not only by crew sizes and pay levels but also by other factors, such as the amount of annual crew leave, overheads such as workers' compensation and the proportion of routine ship maintenance done by the crews? Can the Minister say what progress has been made in each of these areas to bring Australian shipping costs down to competitive international levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the points outlined in the question asked by Senator Hamer in respect of overhead costs are a very important factor in shipping costs in the context of the kind of overseas trade situation that he outlined. I might just draw attention to the fact that obviously Sir John Crawford, being an eminent man, would have recognised that point in taking into account those industrial practices in the preparation of his report. However, the major thrust of his recommendations was to seek a trade-off of manning levels more in keeping with international levels in return for increased opportunities in an expanded participation of Australian flag ships in the overseas trade.

ANSWER.PARA: The package developed following that report was a positive attempt by the Government, in association with the unions and the shipping companies, to make Australian shipping on the whole more competitive. It is a sensible self-help policy which stresses the importance of proper commercial development of shipping based on productivity improvement and, very importantly, improved dispute settling procedural arrangements. It was never expected to produce substantial growth of the Australian industry in the short term but to lay the foundation for long term growth of Australian shipping. While there are other factors affecting crewing costs, including those to which Senator Hamer has referred, it is difficult to make international comparisons of the indirect crewing costs.

The whole thrust of the Government's revitalisation package is the first real attempt by any government in maritime history in Australia to make Australian shipping more commercially attractive. However, in the current international climate freight rates are falling and, indeed, the number of ships laid up is increasing very significantly. That must be seen as militating against immediate introduction of additional ships in our overseas trade. Hence, much of the immediate incentive to improvements in the areas mentioned by Senator Hamer are perhaps not of as great advantage as might be seen in the first place.

The Crawford package is based on commercial consideration rejecting cargo reservation. There is no compulsion on shippers to use purely Australian vessels . Despite these very serious short term problems, steps have been taken by the industry to work towards longer term improvements in productivity. That has culminated in the agreement to form a peak council of shipowners and unions. This council will be meeting next week. The council results from Sir John Crawford's recommendations on industry consultations. It is expected to make a significant contribution to achieving improved efficiency in the industry. I am sure that that will include the aspects outlined by Senator Hamer in his question which are most relevant to the particular problems of overseas shipping competitiveness.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.
—I only partially quoted from it.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the proposed 12-month wages freeze which, if implemented, will reduce the real wages of all Commonwealth employees, regardless of income, by at least 10 per cent by the end of 1983. Does this reduction represent a 38 per cent tax increase for a Nullarbor railway fettler employed by Australian National Railways who receives a gross wage of $234 a week and a take-home pay of $190 a week? Does this not make a mockery of the tax cut Budget now being heavily promoted at public expense?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be noted that the leaders of all eight governments in Australia agreed yesterday that there should be a wage freeze. The only difference is about the duration of such a freeze-whether it should be six months or a year. In fact it is the consensus of all the leaders that there should be a wage freeze. This freeze comes against the background of a very substantial rise in average real wages over the last year. Indeed, excessive wage increases brought about the inflation which has caused the present situation. There has to be some decline in real wages. It is agreed by all leaders that it is necessary to stop wages rising in order to stop the further disemployment of people and to allow some profitability in industry so that it may employ people. In measuring the decline in real wages one has to offset the real advantage of the recent tax cuts, increased family allowances and various other benefits that have been passed to people. So I am quite unable to say what would be--
—You cannot answer the question.

—I can understand Senator Button's difficulty in this situation. His party is now in utter disarray. I repeat that the fact is that one could not measure what decline, if any, there would be in real wages. One would need first of all to offset the benefits that have just accrued and also make an estimate of what the inflation rate will be over the coming year, given the influence of the wages freeze in depressing that rate. That is what it is all about-getting a wage freeze that will bear down on inflation and therefore help to maintain the purchasing power of people and not erode it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it a fact that in a television program produced by a Norwegian team and shown recently in a number of countries, visual and oral evidence was produced in relation to the huge number of people held in detention , without trial, in Vietnam? Is it a fact that the number is not less than 15, 000 and could be as high as 200,000 people? Since the war in Vietnam finished seven years ago, is it not a gross infringement of basic human rights that any of these people should continue to be held without trial? Will the Australian Government raise the matter in the United Nations and all other appropriate places to muster international pressure to force the Vietnamese Government to observe fundamental human rights?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — There have been a number of media items, including reports by Amnesty International, on the plight of the Vietnemese who are held in detention in Vietnam. We are aware that there are many Vietnamese, particularly those who served the non-communist government before 1975, who are held in re-education camps and prisons in Vietnam. The Government has no exact figures of the people held in detention but estimates range as high as 200,000. We are, therefore, unable to state with any certainty whether detainees have been brought to trial or whether their arrest and detention has been brought about by administrative action without judicial review. It has not been the practice of the Vietnamese Government to give publicity to its trial procedures as regards political detainees. Nonetheless, we remain concerned about the allegations. We have consistently expressed concern about violations of fundamental human rights and freedom, regardless of the political system of the country in which they occur, and we will continue to do so. Senator Peter Rae asked whether this matter could be raised in the United Nations. I will make that specific request known to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and I will seek from him a response to it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle because she is the only Minister in this place from the State of Victoria. I assume that she was around the polling booths for the Flinders by-election last Saturday. I ask the Minister whether it is a fact that Liberal Party posters outside all or nearly all polling places for the Flinders by-election stated:

QUESTION.PARA: For an effective vote for no dams vote 1 Peter Reith.
Peter Reith, of course, is the Liberal candidate elected to the other place. I ask whether it was also said freely in local newspapers in the electorate:
Vote Reith for the only effective no dams vote.

How does the Government reconcile that statement designed specifically to influence the voter-undoubtedly it did influence the voter-with the disgraceful and cynical sell-out of the Franklin revealed today in which the Government has said it will permit the dam to proceed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think Senator Mason should wait for the statement that is to be made by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment before he says what will be in that statement. The statement is to be made later in the day in the other place and I understand also in this place. I will check whether the wording on Liberal Party posters quoted by Senator Mason is accurate . If any comments need to be made on that I will see that they are made. But the statement that will be made by the Government should be awaited before any further comment is made on this matter.
—I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister deny that statements to that general effect were made on the Liberal Party's posters in the Flinders by-election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I said, I am not aware of what the wording was on any of the posters in Victoria to which Senator Mason referred. I am not aware whether the wording was as stated by Senator Mason. As I said also, a statement will be made later today. I have no further comment to make on the matter.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and follows his answer to Senator McLaren. In deciding to impose a wage freeze in respect of Commonwealth employees, namely, the employees of this Government, did the Government take into consideration the fact that 48 per cent of Commonwealth employees earn less than average weekly earnings? Is it a fact that that amounts to some 750,000 people? In considering the imposition of the squeeze and its likely political effects in relation to highly paid bureaucrats and so on--
—Forty-seven per cent will always be seen as less than the average. An average is an average. You have to have some above and some below.
—I am sorry, Senator Teague, there are a lot more people--
—Could you repeat your question?
—I am getting so much assistance.
—We will try to help you.

—Thank you. If honourable senators opposite do not understand how wages are calculated why do they not shut up and let me ask the question? Did the Commonwealth Government take into account the fact that 47 per cent of Commonwealth Public Service employees are earning less than average weekly earnings?
—A figure of 750,000?
—Yes. Does that 48 per cent constitute some 750,000 people? Was this taken into account by the Government in terms of the imposition of the freeze on Commonwealth employees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, but my intention in interjecting was to try to get an understanding of the question and, without being difficult, the real worry with me was the figure of 750,000. My recollection is that the number of Commonwealth employees all told is something far less than that.
—It should have been 75,000.

—I am sorry, I did not want to be pedantic. Having got that correction we can proceed to the other matters. I think that was the reason for the interjections. I think it would be fair to say that of all Australian wage earners more than 48 per cent receive less than the average weekly wage. That is the simple fact. Therefore, if the figure that Senator Button has given me is correct, the Commonwealth employees would be slightly better off than the average person in private employment. Of course, another very much more important factor has to be considered. Public servants have permanency of employment whereas the threat outside is the loss of employment. That is not so with Commonwealth public servants. The factor which Senator Button raises was taken into account. However, what we and all Premiers are aiming to do is to place a freeze on all persons, whether in the public or private sectors.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no dispute amongst the eight people-the six Premiers, the leader from the Northern Territory and the Acting Prime Minister-that it is desirable to have a wage freeze in the public sector. The only dispute is about the length of time. Therefore, all eight leaders took into account the impact upon all public servants. But they went further than that, and it is important to understand this. All agreed that they would intervene in the appropriate ways in the arbitral tribunals to seek a similar freeze for the private sector. Therefore, it is not just an intention to single out one group in the community. All are involved in this. In one case it would be an intervention collectively of Premiers plus the Commonwealth; in others it would involve their own interventions. But all have agreed that they would take steps in the arbitral bodies to seek to bring about a freeze in the private sector. This is aimed to be across the board; it is aimed to be fair to all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to his letter in the Adelaide Advertiser of 4 December in which he responded to an article in that paper about a Vietnam veteran who claimed a number of adverse effects to his health as a result of herbicide spraying while he was in Vietnam. Does the Minister recall that his reply canvassed a number of solutions to the problems concerning Vietnam veterans and their health but did not refer specifically to the scientific studies about which he has commented from time to time in the Senate? Are these scientific studies still in progress? Can he say specifically what these studies are concerned with and when these studies are likely to be completed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jessop rightly draws our attention to the letter in the Advertiser of last Saturday which outlined several things which the Government is undertaking, including counselling of veterans who are claiming problems from herbicide exposure or from the broader experience of having served in the war in Vietnam. I encourage veterans who feel in need of that service to get in touch with either the Department or the counselling service and to take advantage of it. Senator Jessop asked what progress has been made in connection with the scientific studies. I would like to point out that we expect the results of the study on the birth defects of the children of Vietnam veterans which has been undertaken by the Commonwealth Institute of Health to be in the hands of my officers by about the middle of January. That study will then need to be referred to a body of scientific advisers for their review and opinion, which should reach me by the end of that month or, at the very latest, in the earlier part of February. I should therefore be in a position to make some public statement as to the outcome of that very important study by that time.

ANSWER.PARA: The second study which is under way concerns mortality amongst Vietnam veterans . That study is reaching an advanced stage of preparation. There has been considerable difficulty in co-ordinating all the activities of various State authorities in this area but we have received a great deal of co-operation from the State governments. We expect to have at least initial results on that very important aspect in the earlier part of 1983, followed by the final results in the middle to latter part of 1983.

The third study that is being undertaken, and concerning which a great deal of preparatory work has been done, is in relation to the morbidity of Vietnam veterans and the problems arising from various illnesses experienced by them. That study, given the degree of progress that can be made in that area, is in its last stages and I expect to be able to report on it in the earliest part of 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Now that extensive alterations and additions to the Hollywood Repatriation Hospital have been approved and funds allocated, there appears to be a substantial amount of unused ward and operating theatre capacity in the adjacent Queen Elizabeth II Hospital at Shenton Park. I ask: Has consideration been given to the feasibility of the shared use of the existing facilities and whether this would obviate the need for the costly upgrading of the Hollywood Repatriation Hospital? Have there been any discussions with the Western Australian Government and, if so, what has been the result?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the operating theatres at the Hollywood Repatriation Hospital in Perth has caused considerable difficulty. As I announced during the Budget debate, in the next two years work, to cost $6.5m, will be undertaken on the operating theatres at Hollywood. That work is being accorded a high degree of priority because there is a very real need in the hospital for the theatres. I emphasise that the work to be undertaken includes also the provision of surgical wards and various other facilities that should be made available in that hospital.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Giles has drawn attention to the fact that the hospital is contiguous to the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital and that the question of rationalisation of facilities therefore arises. For some years a committee comprising officers of the Repatriation Department, medical personnel from the Hollywood Repatriation Hospital and representatives of the State Health and Medical Services Department has met in an endeavour to rationalise various services that are available at the Hollywood and Sir Charles Gairdner hospitals. A considerable amount of work, one for the other, is done by the two hospitals.

As to the development being undertaken, the overriding question is what facilities would be available in the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital for patients who would otherwise seek treatment at the Hollywood Repatriation Hospital. That represents a considerable problem. Some 18 months ago, in conjunction with representatives of the State Health and Medical Services Department and the Minister for Health in Western Australia, Mr Ray Young, the question was examined in great detail. It was found that there were in Sir Charles Gairdner insufficient beds for the use of the veterans and that the capital expenditure to which the Federal Government would be committed if it redeveloped the facilities at Sir Charles Gairdner, for their use by veterans, would be greater than would be involved in the development contemplated at Hollywood.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Education whether his attention has been drawn to the statement made two days ago by the former Prime Minister, Sir William McMahon, on PM, that the first reason for the Liberal Party victory and the Australian Labor Party's collapse in the Flinders by-election was 'the activities of Dawkins', the education spokesman for the Opposition, and the divisive policy on independent schools announced recently by the Australian Labor Party. What response has there been from Catholic schools and representatives of other independent schools by way of endorsement of the Government's firm commitment of support for all non-government schools?

—The Liberal victory in Flinders was really based upon its being a better party, with better policies and a better candidate. However, I did see a transcript of remarks by the former Prime Minister, Sir William McMahon, in which he laid some of the blame at the feet of the Labor spokesman on education, stating specifically that he had raised issues that had worried and divided the community. I have also seen a statement put out by the Catholic Education Commission and endorsed by Catholic bishops. They reject specifically the two parts of the Australian Labor Party's policy on which it bases its differentiation from the Government's policy. The first point is that the Government believes there should be a basic grant to each child in non- government schools. The Labor Party does not agree. The Catholic bishops and the Catholic Education Commission support the Government and reject the Labor Party proposition.
—That is not true.

—That is absolutely correct. The second point concerns what is called the percentage link, that is, how much support should be given to non- government schools. The Government believes that it must be a percentage of what it costs to educate a child in government schools. The Labor Party says it will do away with that and put in something else. The Catholic bishops and the Catholic Education Commission reject that proposition. So, on the two things that separate our policies, the education authorities in the most needy part of the non-government system have come down firmly on the side of equity and have rejected what is a misjudged, ill-advised, divisive and inequitable proposition from the Labor Party. If the electors of Flinders used this as part of their judgment they showed very good judgment.

—Is the Minister repre- senting the Minister for Primary Industry aware that during the drought years of 1965-68 the then Federal coalition government introduced a special unemployment scheme in New South Wales rural areas, with more than 90 per cent of funds being allocated to local councils so that town improvements could be carried out? Since unemployment today in country areas of New South Wales is at least 10 times higher than it was in 1965-68, why has the Federal Government refused to introduce an unemployment assistance scheme as suggested by the New South Wales Minister for Agriculture, Mr Jack Hallam?

—I am aware that during different periods of drought various measures have been used to relieve some of the hardship which is suffered. In the instant drought we have introduced a couple of relatively novel approaches in the form of the very wide fodder subsidy and the interest subsidy. They have been legislated for in this place within the last few months. I was not aware of Mr Hallam having raised this matter with either the Minister for Primary Industry or the Prime Minister. I will have to make inquiries about that part of the honourable senator's question. I will find out why, if the matter has been raised, the Government has rejected it, if that is the case.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the difficult social security cases where a decision regarding pension appeals cannot be reached in a State and is referred to the Department of Social Security Central Office in Canberra. Can the Minister give an indication of the processing time of such appeals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where there are appeals against decisions of officers of the Department of Social Security-they are always appeals against a failure to give benefits; we find that, of course people do not appeal against favourable decisions-the decisions are first made the subject of inquiry by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. In cases where the Social Security Appeals Tribunal's view is thought by the Department not to be correct, the matter is first referred to Central Office for consideration. Unfortunately, there is no regular statistical collection which would reveal the length of time taken to process these appeals in the Department's Central Office. There have been periods of delay longer than I would have thought appropriate, or indeed the Department thinks appropriate, but in recent months strenuous steps have been taken to reduce outstanding numbers and the time being taken.

ANSWER.PARA: While I cannot give any statistical overview, I did ask officers of my Department for some information on this matter. They tell me that during November about 35 appeals were received at the Department's Central Office from State or Territory directors who did not believe that a tribunal recommendation should be accepted. Of these 18 have been finalised already. The balance are still outstanding. The 18 cases finalised were, on average, finalised within about 18 days of receipt. I would regard that sort of processing as quite adequate, but I would not be in a position to deny that there have been some rather more extended periods of delay. We are attempting to reduce those to a minimum.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Georges, in a series of questions, asked me for the figure for the yield of the oil levy. I said to him that it was $3.2 billion or $3.3 billion and that I would check it. The figures for the last two recorded years were $3,108m for 1980-81 and $3,163m for 1981- 82. I understand that a significantly higher figure was recorded in the Budget for this year, but that may have to be modified depending upon the decision on prices of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries, and also because of the downturn in output of oil. Tragically, right at this moment, there is a tugboat strike that is causing a loss of almost half of the output from Bass Strait. When that happens, less revenue accrues; we are forced to buy more overseas oil; and less money is, therefore, available to Australian production. Of course, it is difficult to estimate but the yield should be within the ambit I have indicated.

—Yesterday Senator Chipp asked me a question about emergency relief or emergency aid services in Victoria. In the course of the answer I said that it was my recollection that I was awaiting recommendations from the Victorian Emergency Relief Committee about the disbursement of $125,000 which will be paid to Victorian agencies for emergency relief. I have since had a chance to refresh my memory. The position is that on 14 November I wrote to the Victorian Minister for Community Welfare, the Honourable Pauline Toner, seeking her recommendations for the distribution of that money. She replied to me recently declining to make recommendations because Victoria was reviewing its policies in this area. She suggested that the Victorian Emergency Relief Committee again be contacted. That was the source of my recollection. We hope to approach that committee within the next few days to obtain its recommendations for the distribution of those funds. When the recommendations are received, assuming that the Victorian Emergency Relief Committee chooses to make recommendations, approval from me will be sought for distribution and the funds will be distributed as soon as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 November Senator Colston asked me a question about the delay times for appeals to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal in Queensland. I answered that question without notice and then gave a supplementary answer on 1 December which had been supplied to me by my Department. When I put that down on 1 December, I indicated that the period specified in that answer was rather better than I had expected-an average delay of 15.8 weeks. I have now received a further supplementary answer from my Department indicating that the calculations were incorrect and that it should have been 31 weeks. I apologise to Senator Colston and the Senate for that bit of misinformation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an updating and correcting response to that question.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

On 1 December 1982 I provided an answer to a question without notice from Senator Colston about the average delay in Queensland between lodgment of an appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal against the rejection of a claim for an invalid pension and the hearing of that appeal. The average period referred to in the answer prepared by my Department was 15.8 weeks. At the time I commented that that figure was somewhat better than I had anticipated and I took this to be a reflection of the efforts being made within my Department since August to improve the processing of appeals.

However, I am now advised by my Department that this figure was incorrectly calculated, and that the revised figure is approximately 31 weeks for the average processing time between registration of an appeal and the date a recommendation was made by the Queensland Social Security Appeals Tribunal, for medical appeals finalised in the quarter ended 30 September 1982. I very much regret that incorrect information was previously given to the Senate. This error occurred through an inadvertent breakdown in clerical procedures which should not recur as revised instructions have now been issued governing the calculation of figures such as those in question.

When I provided the answer to Senator Colston's question, I mentioned that we have regarded ourselves as having problems in the appeals area and that they have received a great deal of attention. This is certainly the case. The revised figure which I have now provided to the Senate is plainly a reflection of the fact that those problems have not yet been resolved. I have asked my Department to increase its efforts in this regard so that a marked improvement will soon become apparent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Grimes asked me a question about a person's entitlement to unemployment benefit during a period of seasonal closure or shutdown. I am advised that in normal circumstances people who are unemployed in industries subject to seasonal closure or shutdown take their annual recreation leave over the period of the shutdown. I am also advised, however, that if a person did not have a recreation leave entitlement which covered him for the period of closure or shutdown, that person could be eligible for unemployment benefit for the balance of the time of the closure, provided that the person met the usual eligibility criteria-that is, he would have to be taking reasonable steps to obtain work and would be subject to the normal waiting period. I have asked my Department to ensure that this procedure is administered uniformly, and an instruction will be sent to all officers of the Department to clarify the situation.

—Yesterday Senator Elstob asked me a question about the advertising campaign. I undertook to provide specific figures. I think I mentioned a figure of $160,000 which was my Department's contribution to television advertising. The newspaper campaign which accompanied that and which contains more detailed information has a budget of $300,000. The Australian Women's Weekly article which I referred to in answering that question cost $29, 000. That was paid for by the Government Information Unit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Townley asked a question about whether there would be job losses if the recommendations of the report of the Davidson Committee of Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia were implemented. I am advised by the Minister whom I represent that he addressed this question when he spoke recently to the Australian Press Club. The Davidson report actually suggested that in his proposed competitive environment there would be a potential for job creation and that he thought his proposed structure would lead to a more dynamic telecommunications industry and to the creation of new jobs. I have half a dozen paragraphs from the Minister's recent address to the Press Club which covers this part of the Davidson recommendations. It may be suitable to have those paragraphs incorporated in Hansard and I seek leave so to do.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The paragraphs read as follows-
Davidson suggested that in his proposed competitive environment there would be potential for job creation in that his proposed structure would lead to a more dynamic telecommunications industry.

By opening up the field of providing some Telecommunications services (to private sector involvement) we at once exploit alternative resources and create competition which leads inevitably to the most efficient use of those and other resources, to the ultimate benefit of all Australians.

There is also by this means scope for enormous employment growth. Australians will have to come to accept that we can never hope to create jobs in the numbers we need by relying on the industries of the past. It is to the high technology industries that a country as prosperous and well-educated as Australia must turn. This is true of our communications industries. If allowed to expand they can generate thousands of jobs.
Telecom itself is the largest employer in Australia. Its employment numbers could expand substantially if the expansion of Telecommunications is itself encouraged.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Walsh proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's belated acknowledgement of the massive budget deficit increase .
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —After weeks of obfuscation and false denials the Government has finally admitted that the Budget deficit will blow out to an all time record of $4 billion. Significantly the admission was made three days after a by-election in Flinders. This is not to say that a deficit of that magnitude per se is wrong. The fault is not in the amount of the deficit but in its structure and the fact that the estimates were falsified in order to deceive the public as to the size of the deficit in the lead-up to a planned general election in December, and subsequently in the lead-up to a real by- election in December. Present conditions justify a deficit of that magnitude, or arguably even higher, providing it is directed towards capital works and the stimulation of economic growth. But instead of a deficit derived from capital works expansion and a stimulation of economic growth this deficit is a function of a sequence of bribes directed to politically sensitive groups and also a function of the falsification of the estimates upon which it was based because the truth had to be hidden from an electorate conditioned over many years by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to believe that increasing deficits were both irresponsible and economically disastrous.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1982 Budget was a political and not an economic document. It conforms to a sequence of such documents. This Government has had no consistent economic strategy since and including the Budget of 1977. Instead of a strategy we have had a series of stunts and pre-election gimmicks. In 1977 the stunt and pre- election gimmick was the fist full of dollars, the tax cuts, followed immediately after the election by tax increases. The stunt in 1980 was the resources boom. Recklessly, Government Ministers talked up the resources boom and thereby touched off the wages explosion, the effect of which they now stand back from in horror as though they were not responsible for it. Of course, that was compounded by the Prime Minister's irresponsible decision to abandon centralised wage fixing in May of 1981 because he thought it was more important to attend the royal wedding in Buckingham Palace. He could not jump quickly enough on to the 707 and he wrecked centralised wage fixing and aggravated the wages explosion that the reckless talking up of the resources boom for the purpose of the 1980 election had already touched off.

Of course, the gimmick in 1982 for the election planned in 1982 was the family Budget now being advertised to the public at great expense to the public. There was no general election in 1982, but the fact that the deficit had been deliberately underestimated was withheld from the public until after the Flinders by-election. Of course, there is still no economic strategy from this Government. We have a continuing political strategy, the latest manifestation of which is a wages freeze aimed at a March election. In no other area has the Prime Minister so debased economic debate in this country as on the question of deficits. For opportunistic reasons in 1975 and beyond he created deficit fetishism when, with respect to the deficit in 1975, he asserted:
We are like a family that has greatly overspent its income. Our house is mortgaged.
In April 1977, continuing the family budget analogy, he said:

We all know in our own families that if we spend too much for too long we will discover eventually that we are too much in debt to the bank. We also know that debts can take a long while to pay off. We know that while we are paying off debts we are going to have to give up other things that we would normally want.
On 7 November 1977, in the run-up to the 1977 election-this is again the political strategy, there was no economic strategy-he said in the House of Representatives:

Throughout 1978, starting with the peak period in January-February, there will be a sustained reduction in unemployment . . . The one factor that would prevent that happening would be a return to the mad deficit financing of the Australian Labor Party.

This is an appropriate time to note that the deficit now admitted by this Government will be the largest ever. In conjunction with the theologians in Treasury and having created deficit fetishism, the Prime Minister then produced deficit dogma, which was often contradicted by the empirical evidence. The dogma incorporated such nostrums as if the deficit is reduced ipso facto inflation will fall; if the deficit is reduced ipso facto interest rates will fall, and, of course, vice versa. Those two nostrums have been flatly contradicted by the statistics ever since 1978. However, they retain a life of their own. The dogma has a life of its own, independent of reality. On Budget night the Opposition knew that the Estimates, from which the deficit was derived, had been falsified and the deficit understated, and we said so at the time. On 20 October I moved to refer the Estimates of receipt and expenditure to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for examination. We did that for two reasons; because the economy was collapsing at a faster rate than even we had anticipated and because we frankly did not believe what we were being told by the Government. We wanted to hear from Treasury officials, not from Ministers , what the honest Treasury assessment of the position was. In moving that motion to refer the Estimates to the Finance and Government Operations Committee-I stress on 20 October almost eight weeks ago-I said that the deficit would be between $3.2 billion and $3.7 billion. Senator Sir John Carrick said in reply:

Senator Walsh's argument is that there will be a blow-out in expenditure; that there will be something terrible about this blow-out; that there will be a deficit of, on the basis of his calculations-I do not accept the figure-of the order of $3,300m, and that that would be very bad.
Senator Sir John Carrick got the figure wrong, as he gets almost all figures wrong, but still he was within the range that I had quoted. He continued:

Senator Walsh says that we should inquire into pay-as-you-earn receipts. How can we, by 28 October, know with any certainty what the trends will be? My advice from the Department of the Treasury is that it is too early to judge, that at this stage no major change is expected.

I do not believe that Senator Sir John Carrick was telling the truth when he made that statement. That is why we wanted to get the Treasury officials here, to hear from the Treasury officials-from John Stone or one of his officers-what the Treasury actually believes and not what Ministers falsely asserted. On that day-that is, on 20 October-I gave to the Senate details of expenditure in excess of that to which the Government had admitted at the time of the Budget. Those details included expenditure of between $356m and $600m on drought relief; $300m on unemployment benefit payments; receipt shortfalls from pay-as-you-earn taxpayers of $200m; provisional taxation of $200m; company taxation of $300m; tax recoupment of $100m; health insurance rebate of $100m; and sales tax excise of $50m. The figures given by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in the House of Representatives half an hour ago either corroborated or showed that those estimates which I had given almost eight weeks ago were, as I said at the time, probably conservative. I prepared those estimates literally in a matter of minutes. I know that I have a conceptual grasp of figures and arithmetic qualities immeasurably superior to any of the innumerates who populate the Government benches. But there are numerate people in the Treasury. They must have known and they must have been able to produce, either on 20 October or before that date, as accurate an estimate of the deficit as that presented yesterday by the Treasurer to the Premiers. The Treasury must have known on 20 October that the deficit would blow out to something like $3.5 billion. Senator Sir John Carrick said:
My advice from the Department of the Treasury is that it is too early to judge, that at this stage no major change is expected.
That was with respect to PAYE tax receipts. I repeat: I do not believe that Senator Sir John Carrick was telling the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before passing from that subject, on the matter of taxation, I note that on 26 August 1975 the present Prime Minister, who was then Leader of the Opposition, condemning the Budget which had just been produced by the then Treasurer, Mr Hayden, on the grounds that it was profligate and the deficit was excessive, among other things said:

SPEECH.PARA: Why should Australian taxpayers support an extra 504 employees in the Taxation Office . . .

Everyone now knows that there was very good reason for putting more resources into the Australian Taxation Office. There would have been an enormous net gain to revenue because the tax cheats would not have escaped with some of the billions of dollars with which they did escape. The components of the Budget are wrong, of the individual items which have contributed to the deficit blowout are not the types of items which ought to be the components of a deficit Budget in times of deep economic recession.

As I said before, there is nothing wrong or irresponsible about a deficit of this size under present economic circumstances when unemployment is running above 8 per cent and is headed for double figures. Deficits of that size and even greater have been consistently produced by the Government of Japan in association with low rates of unemployment and inflation and high rates of economic growth. The fault is not in the aggregate; the fault is in the components of the aggregate and the way in which the public has for so long been deceived about those components and their aggregate effect. For example, the Government appropriated $356m for drought relief. I noted today that the Treasurer is sticking to that figure. I do not believe that is a correct figure. The advice I received from inside the bureaucracy is that the present truthful estimate of the bureacracy is $500m, but we can take it either way.

This Government has said that it will tolerate no blow-out of the deficit for expenditure to generate employment. But it blew out the deficit without any serious thought, by an amount of between $356m and $500m, for drought relief. How much employment will that $500m blowout of the deficit generate? The answer is almost none. There is no limit to this relief and there is nothing to stop millionaires qualifying for assistance under that scheme. Millionaries will qualify to receive a slice of that $500m and there is no limit to the amount that they may receive. This was another enormously costly political stunt which was divorced from any concept of long term economic strategy and produced against the planned horizon of a December election.

The latest such political stunt is a freeze on wages for Commonwealth employees . There is a quite widespread misconception that Commonwealth employees are fat cats. Some of them are. Among the fattest of all are those of us who sit in this Parliament. But we are not all fat cats. Today I inquired what was the take home pay of a railway fettler at Cook or at any of the other small towns on the Trans -Australia railway line. I was informed that it is $190 a week. I believe that Senator McLaren asked a question about this. I again remind honourable senators that this Government provided $500m-that is, it added $500m to the deficit-for a program which among other things will enable millionaires to make claims on that $500m and imposed no limit to the amount that those millionaires may claim. This Government has now said that the real wages of railway fettlers, which currently stand at $190 a week net, will be reduced by 10 per cent before Christmas 1983. All Commonwealth employees are not fat cats. This latest political stunt was used as a substitute for economic strategy in the run up to an election, which is now planned by the Prime Minister for March. I inform Senator Martyr that I do not believe it will be held, but it is now planned. That illustrates the sorts of inequities which are being imposed by the Government.

The former member for Flinders has been allowed to grab almost half a million dollars, 95 per cent of it tax free, on his retirement from this Parliament. That is a scandal. Even more scandalous is the fact that should he be survived, on his death, by a spouse-if he has a spouse at the time of his death-the spouse will collect for the rest of her life a penson of $40,000 in 1982 dollars. He has received half a million dollars in cash almost entirely tax free and his spouse will receive $40,000 plus if she outlives him.

The Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, meanwhile is living it up in Paris at the Crillon Hotel in a room that is costing the taxpayers $410 a day. These are the people who have just frozen for 12 months the money wage of the railway fettler at Cook who gets $190 a week after tax. They have decided that that railway fettler's real wages will be reduced by 10 per cent between now and Christmas next year. They are like a herd of pigs with no sense of responsibility and no economic strategy, just a ferocious determination to hang on to power and keep their long snouts in the public trough.
