I would like to remind the Senate of statements that have been made since the announcement of the Budget which have given information to the Parliament and to the nation with regard to changes that have arisen since the Budget was introduced. On 16 September a public statement was made concerning the introduction of drought assistance of $356m. That might be called a political stunt by Senator Walsh but I think that those people who will benefit from the drought assistance in one of the worst droughts in Australia's history would not regard it as a political stunt; they would regard it as a matter of necessity and as a matter of extreme importance to them in their very grave situation.
—Like Ralph Hunt, for example?

—Senator Walsh was listened to for as long as we could tolerate it. I think he should listen to me. On 14 October the first announcement was made of a revision to the estimate of the number of unemployed beneficiaries for this year. On 24 November a further revision was announced of the number of unemployment beneficiaries expected in 1982-83. A review of the figures and financial statements of the Government is made in November. That gives the first preliminary estimate. The result of that was received by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and by the Government on 30 November. There is a February review of figures which is more definite. At this stage many of the figures are preliminary figures.

SPEECH.PARA: Estimates at this early stage of the financial year can be uncertain, particularly as the economy is entering a period of flux. But the available indicators suggest that the deficit for 1982-83 could be in the vicinity of $4, 000m. That figure was given yesterday by the Treasurer during the conference with the State Premiers. The growth in the deficit stems principally from a deterioration in the economy which has affected both the receipts and the expenditure of the Commonwealth Budget. Perhaps I can describe some of those in a little more detail later. The current outlook is subject to a deal of uncertainty. The Government is shortly to undertake its normal mid-year review of the Budget outcome, which should provide a better basis for forecasting more accurately the growth of the 1982-83 figures. We have been able to accommodate some of the effects of the downturn in the economy caused by the drought and the effects of the international recession, for example, by introducing drought relief programs. But we are still aware that the significantly enlarged deficit is imposing upward pressure, for example, on interest rates, which rates impinge on prospects for medium term recovery. In discussions with the Premiers on the wages pause the Government outlined the difficulties facing the economy. Some of the statements that were made publicly yesterday arose from that meeting.

The deterioration in the Budget figures can be given in some detail. As I said, it is due mainly to unexpectedly rapid deterioration in the economy in both receipts and outlays. The figures now given are that the outlays will be $1,343 higher than budgeted. That is 17.1 per cent higher than in 1981-82. One of the main items causing that $1,300m increase is a figure of $603m for unemployment benefit. This figure has arisen from the increase in the forecast of the number of unemployment beneficiaries from 395,000 to 525,000. The increase in the financial figure is also a result of the increase in the average benefit because a higher proportion of the unemployment beneficiaries are adults with family responsibilities. There is the addition of $356m for drought assistance; $52m for natural disaster relief; and $93m for public debt interest to finance the higher deficit.

On the other side of the Budget, the receipts are $708m lower than budgeted. The Budget receipt figure of $44,685m which is 9.5 per cent higher than the 1981 -82 figure excludes some effects of the wages pause, but the main items in the changes are the lower gross pay-as-you-earn collections of personal income tax, a lower figure of $323m mainly because of the lower earnings and the revision of the average weekly earnings. The average weekly earnings have been revised from 12 per cent to 11 1/2 per cent and also there is the effect of lower employment, a decline by one per cent rather than constant as was assumed at the time of the Budget figures. There are lower other personal income tax collections of $123m which reflect the severity of the drought and the higher proportion of primary producers who are self-assessing. Also there are the delays and the changed scope for the special tax to recover the evaded company and Division 7 tax, a reduction of $155 on the Budget estimate; the lower private consumption and other expenditure showing a reduction in sales tax of $84m; excise duties, excluding oil and liquefied petroleum gas, $170m; Customs duty on imports, $100m ; and increase in excise revenue from crude oil and LPG, $240m. The figures showing those changes have therefore led the Treasurer at the first available opportunity to him to announce that the likely outcome of the 1982-83 Budget is $4,000m.

I think we ought to keep in perspective the $4,000m as it does arise from the factors that I have just mentioned. That $4,000m is about 2.5 per cent of the gross domestic product. Whilst Senator Walsh likes to call it the largest ever deficit, we ought to remember that the deficit in the year 1975-76 was $3,566m or 4.9 per cent of the gross domestic product as against 2.5 per cent of the gross domestic product for this year, 1982-83.

In other countries, the deficit is approaching 5 per cent of the gross domestic product in the United States of America, about 5 1/2 per cent in Japan and about 6 1/2 per cent in Canada. In all countries, an increasing deficit is automatic when economic conditions deteriorate. For instance, welfare expenditure will increase and tax revenue will decrease. I do not think that anyone would suggest that we could control that increase in the deficit by, for instance, cutting down social security assistance or other assistance to individuals or by raising taxes and other charges. Of course, we get the effect of the downturn in the economy and at the same time we get the increase in social welfare expenditure and things of that kind.

I do want to say that the deficit is being financed in a responsible manner. I think that that is the most important thing that ought to be stressed. The M3, in the target range of 9 per cent to 11 per cent is the figure that was given at Budget time. The financing of this deficit can be undertaken in a responsible way. There is no reason why we should expect any loss of control over the money supply. The funding task will be larger than expected. But we have considerably greater flexibility through the tender system. Our securities have been selling well. Between 1 July 1982 and 10 November 1982 the non-official take-up has been over $3 billion. This compares with $662m in the same period of last year. That is quite a considerable increase in that non-official take-up. The non-bank take -up in the same period was $1,907m compared with $133m last year. The other thing that ought to be kept in mind is that the Budget is only one element in the growth of the money supply. There are also offsets; for example, there are indications that corporate demand is declining and placing less stress on the money supply.

The money supply growth is well within the Budget target of between 9 per cent and 11 per cent. The end of October money supply figure was 10.2 per cent higher than the October figure in 1981. The crucial factors in what happens to interest rates in Australia are what happens to interest rates overseas and what happens to wage rises and the inflation rate in Australia. I think we could address ourselves to those things very profitably at this time. Senator Walsh said that this Commonwealth deficit is the highest ever. In considering that statement we should look at the percentages of gross domestic product in relation to the Commonwealth Budget deficit for the last 10 years. In 1972-73 it was 1.6 per cent of GDP; in 1974-75 it was 4.1 per cent; in 1975-76 it was 4.9 per cent; it fell to 3.3 per cent the following year and ranged down to 0.4 per cent in 1981- 82. We have estimated that the Budget deficit of $4,000m will be 2.5 per cent of gross domestic product in 1982-83.

I have mentioned some countries with comparable Budget deficits in the present very severe economic circumstances. There are many comparable countries in the world. I think we ought to consider at this time how a Budget deficit would be financed by the Opposition. I think we need go no further than the Hayden alternative Budget Speech on 24 August this year. Mr Hayden said:
A Budget deficit could be financed by a net addition to money supply financed by Treasury Bills bought by the Reserve Bank.

In other words, the Opposition would print more money. Mr Hayden's statement of August this year was that he would print more money, print more Treasury Bills and we would have the consequent effect of that. In relation to the Budget deficit that the ALP would like to see, on 17 August Mr Hayden said:
We would have aimed at a domestic deficit of the order of $1,000m to $1,500m instead of a surplus.

If that deficit figure is taken with an overseas deficit of $1,900m, we see that Mr Hayden's deficit in August, without taking into account the circumstances that have occurred in this financial year, would have been in the order of $2, 900m to $3,400m and he would start printing Treasury Bills to fund it. But what size deficit would Mr Hawke like? He said:

. . . Budget deficit is talked about as 1 per cent of the gross domestic product as though that's some sort of terrible thing when in fact if you look at the rest of the Western countries with which we're co-operating and the OECD . . . figures that have been published for 1982, the 13 of them, the average is a deficit which is 4 per cent of the gross domestic product. In other words, there would be by the standards of what other countries are trying to do to stimulate their economies there's a hell of a lot more room for this government to take.

That was what was said by Mr Hawke in an interview on 18 August. If he wants Australia to have a Budget deficit comparable to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average-namely 4 per cent of gross domestic product -he would want a deficit of about $6,600m. We can take our pick of Mr Hayden's figure of $3,400m and Mr Hawke's figure of $6,600m. Senator Walsh is saying that he does not mind having a deficit. If we look at the Budget deficits during the Labor Party's period of office we find that in 1973-74 the Budget deficit was 0. 5 per cent of GDP; as I have said, in 1974-75 it was 4.1 per cent; and in 1975- 76 it was 4.9 per cent. I should point out that 4.9 per cent of GDP in current dollars would imply a deficit of about $8,000m. So, on that basis, Mr Hawke's figure is closer than Mr Hayden's to the Budget deficits of Labor's period of office.

I want to say a couple of things about wages. In the Budget forecast average weekly earnings were set at 12 per cent. That figure has since been revised to 11 1/2 per cent because of slower earnings growth during this financial year. It is difficult to quantify the reduction in average weekly earnings growth. If fully effective it could achieve an outcome as low as 10.5 per cent. The effect of the lower AWE figure and the level of employment down by one per cent instead of being constant as forecast has caused estimates of tax revenue to be revised down by $323m. If average weekly earnigs of the order of 10 1/2 per cent could be achieved this would reduce gross pay-as-you-earn estimates by an additional $ 250m to $300m. Therefore, as a result of the wages pause the deficit could increase by a further $250m to $300m from the PAYE revision. The lagged effects, which are more likely to affect the 1983-84 Budget, need to take into account the respending of wage savings by governments and the subsequent taxation of and expenditure by beneficiaries of respending and some reductions in the numbers receiving the unemployment benefit. But wage effects and average weekly earnings are quite crucial to what will be the PAYE receipts in this Budget and in the Budget of next year when the effects of the wage pause are taken into account.

I think it is appropriate to give details of some changes to the Budget-time forecasts. In the Budget gross farm product was expected to decline. It is now expected to decline by around 20 per cent, which is about twice the decline expected at Budget time. I think that reflects the severity and the consequences of the drought. One needs to take very seriously indeed a decline of about 20 per cent in gross farm product and recognise the effect that that has on the general economic climate in this country. Non-farm product is also expected to show a small decline, whereas the figures in the Budget Papers indicated that there would be a no-growth situation. Because of these factors gross domestic product is expected to decline by about 2 per cent, whereas at Budget time it was predicted that there would be no growth.

I have already quoted some of the main changes to forecasts of expenditure aggregates within the domestic economy. Private business fixed investment is now expected to fall by 15 to 20 per cent. Private consumption expenditure is now expected to show little, if any, growth. Government expenditures are expected to increase strongly, mainly reflecting very sharp increases in capital expenditures by both State and Commonwealth governments. Imports are now expected to decline, whereas the Budget showed no growth, reflecting the weaker domestic economy. I have mentioned average weekly earnings. The level of inflation was forecast at Budget time to be at around 11 per cent and it is expected that there will be little change in this regard.

As I have said, the level of employment is now expected to decline by one per cent or so. I have already given revised figures as to numbers of unemployment beneficiaries. I have stated also that the growth in monetary aggregates is broadly on target. These are the changed circumstances that yesterday led the Treasurer to give the most up-to-date information that he was able to give with regard to the likely outcome of the 1982-83 Budget. Most of the aspects dealt with are of a very serious nature and the Treasurer has provided the reasons the figures have had to be changed.

At Question Time today a question was asked regarding the sum of $300m that is expected to be realised as a result of the wage pause in the Commonwealth sector . Next week a Bill to appropriate that sum will be introduced. The funds will then be available to be drawn upon month by month as employment-related programs call for expenditure of that nature. The support given yesterday to the wage pause, and its likely result, is significant in terms of the Budget outcome and the economic circumstances in which we live. I believe that support for such action is of crucial importance at this time.

There is no satisfactory single measure of the economic impact of Budget transactions. The Budget deficit (or surplus) is sometimes taken as a shorthand or summary measure of budgetary impact but its use for this purpose is subject to some important qualifications. The deficit simply indicates the difference in total between outlays and receipts; it cannot adquately reflect the differing economic impacts of the various components of total outlays and receipts, or of changes in those components. The mix of Budget outlays and receipts, as well as their total size, can be very relevant to the assessment of the Budget's overall impact on the economy.
It is also important to recognise, as is pointed out in the next section, that the Budget deficit is only part of the total deficit of the Commonwealth sector.

In terms of their economic effects it is useful to distinguish between domestic and overseas transactions. Government payments made overseas do not add directly to domestic incomes or to the demand for locally produced goods and services, while government receipts from overseas sources increase total receipts without withdrawing purchasing power from the domestic private sector. In the table above overseas transactions have been netted out to arrive at estimates of domestic and overseas deficits (or surpluses). TALK.START.PARA: —It is doing the opposite, now.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sentor SIDDONS-Indeed, it is. Governments are not households. We heard reference today to the Government needing to be frugal and to balance its Budget as a good household does. Governments do not have to balance their books. The fact is that the Government is the only place from which money comes. To say that the Government has a deficit is really nonsense. It is obvious from the table of deficits that for the last two years the Government, with its domestic surplus and its very small overall deficit, has been taking money out of circulation. It has been taking money out of circulation through taxation at a greater rate than it has been putting it back into circulation through social benefits and other government payments.

This Government has consistently refused to recognise the historic counter- cyclical role of governments. When the economy is in a boom time, governments should have smaller deficits and even modest surpluses. They should restrict their spending when there is excessive demand. But in bad times they must be prepared to stimulate the economy wisely so that there is a demand from consumers for what the economy is capable of producing. It is inevitable that we turn to the situation that applied in the 1930s. It is frightening, at least to me, to see how many similarities there are between that time and now. It was in the 1930s that governments of the day restricted wage increases. They tightened the money supply and increased taxes. They said that the only way in which inflation could be controlled was by a tight money policy. That is precisely what is happening today. It seems to me that we have only to apply simple common sense.

It is interesting that Franklin Roosevelt never really accepted the economic theories of Keynes. He has often been credited with pump-priming the American economy back to health. In fact, that was not the case. Roosevelt agreed with the economic orthodoxy of his day but he also wanted to do something about the unprecedented unemployment and the failing banks. For that reason and that reason only he embarked on a vast policy of Federal spending which provided jobs and wages. That is what got the American economy out of the Depression of the 1930s. Surely it is a simple matter of common sense that we must do the same.

The Australian Democrats are not opposed to the wages pause as such but we are opposed to it in isolation. A wages pause accompanied by control of imports- control of money going out of the country-and accompanied by an injection of funds into the economy to stimulate both consumption and production is a package that would make sense. Control over imports is often criticised because it is said that it will unfairly benefit local industry and will be inflationary. In this sense a wages freeze certainly would eliminate any dangers of excessive wage demands caused by import controls. The Government now finds itself with a deficit of considerable proportions-about 3 per cent of the gross domestic product-and it has not yet come up with a strategy that will stimulate the economy and create jobs. So it has some very careful thinking to do. Obviously the deficit will increase even further. We are saying that the money available to the Government should be spent with the primary objective of making sure that our unused human resources are used wisely and beneficially.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is debating a matter of public importance raised by the Opposition in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's belated acknowledgment of the massive Budget deficit increase.

Earlier in this debate we heard the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) give a chronological list of announcements detailing the changes that have been made since Budget night. I believe that that list substantially refutes any credibility that this matter of public importance had. I am concerned at the implications and aspersions that the Opposition cast not only on the Ministers of this Government but also on the senior echelons of the Public Service. Not only the Department of the Treasury but also the heads of all government departments and their advisers prepared the very detailed estimates that eventually passed the scrutiny of this Parliament and of this chamber. The Opposition, which includes the Australian Democrats, has echoed an outrageous indignation in this matter, using all the benefits of hindsight. We have heard flippant comments about people being able to do exercises more accurately on the back of an envelope. The Democrats have suggested using increased inflation techniques and increased Budget deficits to overcome the present situation.

The detailed budgetary processes refute the allegations of shonky figures and alterations by the Government. Let me outline to the Senate the detailed procedures that are necessary before the figures find their final form on Budget night. Firstly, in early January the forward estimates are prepared. These examine trends for the coming three years. The second step is in March and April when the general parameters are outlined. The third step is in about May when discussions take place with the Ministry. Bids are also received in May; that is the fourth step. The fifth step is that new policy proposals are considered in great depth. The Budget Committee meets in June and July and Cabinet then considers the items which have been referred to it by the Budget Committee. So the basic strategy is determined in May and June. All this indicates a very detailed involvement by many people. Many figures and many people from the senior echelons of the Public Service are involved.

To imply that all these sorts of situations that are now facing the community could have been envisaged at that early stage of the beginning of January this year is something of a falsehood. Indeed, the Opposition is using the benefit of hindsight in proposing this motion. Also, Opposition senators fail to realise that in the figures in 1974-75 when they were in power there was over a 12 per cent difference between the estimate and the outcome; but even acknowledging our present projected $4 billion deficit, the percentage difference between estimate and outcome for this year will be less than 5 per cent. Much of the Opposition's criticism is, therefore, based on a falsehood and a failure to recognise the comparison between these two results.

It is true that there have been difficulties. These have been brought about by five main factors. Firstly, there is the severity of the great Australian drought which has resulted in increased government payments to the agricultural community on the expenditure side as well as a loss of revenue. Secondly, there are the implications of the international recession which has hit Australia very much in a rush. It has resulted in a severe downturn in demand and prices not only for agricultural exports but also for the mining industry and export oriented manufacturing. Thirdly, it would have been hard to envisage the massive wage increases and the associated shorter hours campaign, which had a dramatic effect on many businesses and employment opportunities in those areas. Fourthly, I refer to the unprecedented number of people who have applied for unemployment benefit and social security payments. This has been reflected in the fact that the Government will have to put on an extra 1,800 people to process claims. Fifthly, associated with the international recession there has been a vigorous dumping of goods on the Australian market.

So the net result, inevitably, has been that revenue projections have been down and expenditure projections have been up. Naturally, this has increased the projected deficit. But as the Minister for Finance mentioned, the matter is still very much under control. The Government must recognise the need to be able to fund its services but at the same time to get maximum dollar value into the pockets of taxpayers. Australia is still very much a high personal income tax country. In the long term, there is a need to review the tax mix. It may not be entirely inappropriate to consider an appropriately structured form of capital gains tax, provided that there is an exemption of the family home.

We must still seek to create opportunities for people to invest. We must provide the right environment for people to work and an incentive to work and to work offered overtime. At the same time, however, we recognise that a post- Budget problem exists which requires the co-operation of all sectors, because the Federal Government cannot do it alone. Yesterday, at the Premiers Conference , we saw a basis for a good co-operative approach. It reflected the typical Australian characteristic of trying to help one's mate when in distress. We have recognised that these are hard times. I believe that these ideals were manifested earlier at Gallipoli.

It has been estimated that savings from the wage pause affecting the Commonwealth and the States could be $1,000m. If extended to the private sector the figure would increase to $3,000m. Although in the national interest, yesterday's conference did not achieve all that the Government hoped for but we recognise that it went a very long way. Certainly the general thrust has been put into place. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee ) has the responsibility of introducing appropriate legislation into Parliament next week involving a wage pause. That will affect members of parliament, judges and public servants. It is a recognition of the need at present to batten down the hatches at a time of not only domestic but also international difficulty.

Wage increases have had a significant effect on employment in Australia. Last year the average increase was 17 per cent, whereas the consumer price index increase was 12 per cent-a net gain to wages of 5 per cent. Because of that and other factors, Australia's competitive position has slipped. Many people are still advocating a measure of price control, or perhaps price surveillance. Price control gives tremendous benefits to importers, where goods would not be subject to price controls. Secondly, there are difficulties with primary industries with varying supply and demand differences. Thirdly, there is a problem of the adequacy of recovery of prices in those manufacturing areas where manufacturers are currently unable to recover full costs. In other words, we would be making those manufacturers and employers worse off and we would be putting them in a position in which they would shed labour rather than increase labour with price controls. At present, the States hold the power over prices.

The savings which will be gained from this wages pause will be used for work- related activities. The States will nominate those activities, but the Commonwealth will control the money. It is expected that this could be released as early as within a couple of months. What will be the result? Employees can go on their Christmas vacation in the knowledge that their jobs will be much more secure than they would be without a wage pause. I believe that there is an increasing awareness on the shop floor, out on the farm and in the typing pool that wage increases are visibly causing a reduction in employment in people's own working environments. The thought at the back of their minds is 'My mate's job or my neighbour's job today may be mine tomorrow'. All too often when industry closes its doors they are seldom reopened, and in decentralised areas there is great social cost to the whole community.

The purpose of the Budget was to pass on benefits to people-this is an aspect that the Opposition has failed to acknowledge-especially in the form of tax cuts , increased family allowances, mortgage interest relief, increased educational allowances, increased payments to the handicapped, rent assistance, pharmaceutical benefits to low income earners, and increased numbers entitled to fringe benefits. But recognising the current problems, the Government has further acted to assist families-for example, with the six weeks extra family benefit for school leavers to cover the gap between leaving school and the normal time for receipt of unemployment benefit.

From the international point of view, there is some evidence that Australia is being used as a dumping ground for marginally costed and subsidised goods. But our Government is taking action to ensure the effectiveness of fast-track anti- dumping procedures to enable the taking of securities. We have also responded by increased short-term protection measures. I believe that consideration is being given to the return of some form of government preference in government purchasing, and that government departments may have to pay duty when purchasing imported goods. All these measures should dramatically assist local industry.

Consideration is also being given to preference for Australian industry in allocating overseas aid and in seeking an extra $25m for the Australian Industry Development Corporation. We have a whole range of measures designed to overcome the worst problems of the recession that is affecting Australia at the moment. We not only have the policies but also are enacting them. We acknowledge the difficulties. We are not hiding them irresponsibly as was alleged in this debate . I believe we have the answers. The Australian Democrats seek to put Australia into hock in perpetuity following a line of Third World country economic thinking. Long term one must seek to balance one's budget. I believe that our Government is acting responsibly. I now move:
That the business of the day be called on.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a statement, it being the statement by the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) on the special Premiers Conference.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government called yesterday's special Premiers Conference to achieve concerted action by all governments in Australia to address the deteriorating employment situation. The Commonwealth put to the Premiers and the Chief Minister a set of proposals around which it hoped to achieve agreement, the central thrust of which was to put in place the widest and most effective pause possible in wages for the next 12 months throughout the Australian economy , as a means of saving jobs. Full agreement was not reached on the proposals put by the Commonwealth. That fact, however, should not obscure the great measure of agreement which was achieved, and its significance. The conference produced an unprecedented agreement among eight governments to effect a pause in wages in the public sector and through concerted action before tribunals and by other means to achieve a similar pause in the private sector. I shall enumerate the points of agreement in a moment.

The Commonwealth was seeking agreement on a 12 months' pause in wages. The Premiers of Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory will be fully supporting the Commonwealth Government in this respect. The Premiers of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia will be seeking a six months' pause in wages. I do not rule out that, depending on the state of the Australian economy during next year, the Premiers of the latter three States may well extend the action they are taking to 12 months. That is for the future, however. What must not be overlooked is that all eight governments have agreed on effective action to secure a pause in wages throughout the economy of at least six months' duration. That is the unprecedented central aspect of the agreement reached yesterday.

The fact that the governments represented at the meeting here in Canberra yesterday reached such an historic agreement is a reflection of the seriousness of the economic situation we are now facing. I think we have all been surprised at the suddenness with which the international recession finally impacted on Australia. It may have been late in coming to Australia, but there is no doubting now that our domestic economic performance is being affected by-
reduced demand for our exports;
rock-bottom commodity prices which are not only affecting the profitability of our resources sector, but have also contributed to the drying up of new resource investment plans;
increased import competition as overseas suppliers search for market opportunities wherever they can find them.

All of this, of course, is being exacerbated by the worst drought in memory. In those circumstances it will become increasingly a matter of absolute survival for our businesses to maintain and improve their competitive position. Unfortunately, as we all know only too well, domestic wage developments have been working in the opposite direction. Over the year to the September quarter average weekly ordinary time earnings rose by about 17 per cent, and this does not take account of reductions in standard hours. Real wages rose by about 5 per cent; while productivity was virtually unchanged. With domestic demand weak, the world economy in recession and an increasingly difficult world trading environment, many Australian businesses have not been able to pass on these increases in wage costs. As a result, profits have fallen by about 13 per cent over the last year and retrenchments have multiplied.

In short, excessive wage increases have worsened our economic problems; they have weakened our competitiveness, contributed directly to unemployment, and weakened demand. They have meant an increase in the real incomes of those in employment, while their less fortunate fellows have lost their jobs. It was against that background that all those present at the conference yesterday approached the discussions in a constructive and co-operative spirit. Each had his own perspective on the problems, but each was seeking constructively to find a consensus on urgent and effective measures to deal with the worsening employment situation. Specifically, this is what was agreed:

The Commonwealth Government will legislate for a 12 months' pause in wages and in reductions in standard working hours in its own employment. There should be no 'catch-up' at the end of the wages pause to recoup wages which might have been forgone in the course of the pause.

The Queensland, Western Australian, Tasmanian and Northern Territory governments will effect a similar 12 months' pause in wages and in reductions in standard working hours in their own employment, by legislation as necessary.
The New South Wales, Victorian and South Australian governments will effect a six months' pause in wages and in reductions in standard working hours in their own employment.

To achieve the widest and most effective pause in wages throughout the private sector, the Commonwealth, Queensland, Western Australian, Northern Territory and Tasmanian governments will approach the arbitral tribunals seeking a 12 months' pause in award wages and in standard working hours in the private sector.

The New South Wales, Victorian and South Australian governments are expected to intervene alongside the other five governments by supporting a six months' pause . The Commonwealth Government will be seeking the support of the Peak Councils for a 12 months' pause in wages. The Government will be meeting the Confederation of Australian Industry later today and has sought an urgent meeting with the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

The wages pause is to take effect as soon as possible, with exceptions restricted to processing of applications for those few groups not yet in receipt of a wage increase in the most recent 'community wage round'.
Legislation to give effect to the wages pause will be introduced as soon as possible.
Resumption of wage increases after the end of the pause would depend on restoration of capacity to pay, which would be determined by appropriate Commonwealth and State tribunals.
All governments will urge a pause in over-award payments.

Professional incomes funded from the Commonwealth Budget will be included in the pause by legislation where necessary. The States are expected to take similar action, where professional incomes are funded from their Budgets.
All governments will seek commitments from professional bodies for a pause in professional fees.
All governments will urge maximum restraint in other non-wage incomes.

Subject to all legislation to effect the wages pause and achieve the necessary savings being passed, the savings to the Commonwealth Budget achieved through the wages pause, expected to be some $300m, would be expended on employment- related projects of the Commonwealth's nomination throughout Australia, projects of high labour content and high Australian content, capable of being implemented quickly. Special consideration will be given to projects in areas of high unemployment within States. The Commonwealth will be consulting all the States and the Northern Territory to identify such projects.

To the extent that State governments participate in the wages pause there would be some savings to their Budgets which they might use in similar activities. Alternatively, they would be relieved of the need to increase taxes or charges or to reduce services.
Semi-government and local authorities are to use their savings from a wages pause in additional employment-related activities or, as appropriate, to defer increases in charges or reduce borrowings.

The Commonwealth Government will be taking a range of other measures to help Australian businesses to weather the present economic difficulties, and to maintain their employment. These measures include a 'Buy Australian' campaign, reintroduction of preference for Australian goods in government purchasing, together with increased availability of finance through the Commonwealth Development Bank and the Australian Industry Development Corporation and acceleration of payments to businesses under various existing assistance schemes . We are also acting to ensure that Australian businesses have effective recourse to anti-dumping action against unfairly priced imports. The Government has also considered the proposals being advanced to divert some of the funds spent on the unemployment benefit to enable the unemployed to work on projects of value to local communities. Apart from questions of cost and effectiveness, such proposals may simply replace jobs. They therefore require careful consideration.

Because of the seriousness of the unemployment problem, the Commonwealth has indicated to the Premiers that it will introduce a community projects program for a trial period of 12 months. Letters will be sent to State governments shortly outlining specific guidelines for the trial and inviting their nomination of projects. The Commonwealth would provide grants through the States for local bodies to undertake specific additional projects using part time labour recruited from the longer-term unemployed. These grants would cover employment at casual award wages for a period necessary to earn an equivalent of benefit plus $35 a week. Each project could run for up to 12 months and employ up to 50 people. As a guide the Commonwealth would be willing to provide funds equal to the benefit rates involved plus an amount of $2m to cover the $35 a week supplement. This would enable trial projects involving about 1,000 people.

The measures I have just outlined constitute a vigorous response to the serious employment problems facing the Australian community. They are not a total cure and we still have a difficult job ahead of us. But the unprecedented nature of the agreement struck among the eight governments represented at yesterday's meeting shows how seriously the problems are viewed by governments. The mood among ordinary Australians throughout the community is equally realistic. There is a strong sense throughout the country that those who have jobs should now make some sacrifice to help their fellows who either do not have jobs or whose jobs are at risk. It is now up to all of us to join in this consensus and give our strongest support to making the program work. I commend the statement to the Senate.

At that stage we had a combination of demand- push and cost-push inflation. At present, if nothing else, we certainly do not have demand-push inflation. Therefore, one wonders whether the medicine that has been prescribed for the current disease is appropriate to that disease or whether it would have been more appropriate for the disease that we experienced as a nation in 1973 and 1974. SPEECH.PARA: I give notice now that I will seek to move an amendment to the legislation or ensure in some other way that the Government audits expenditure on its works or job creation programs so that once every sitting week a report is made in the Parliament as to where the money is going. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to inform the Senate of the Government's intentions regarding South West Tasmania. The Government reaffirms its wish that the Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks be inscribed on the World Heritage List along with the other nomination of Lord Howe Island. If these nominations are accepted by the World Heritage Committee, these areas will join the Kakadu National Park, the Great Barrier Reef and the Willandra Lakes Region on the World Heritage List.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators would be aware that the World Heritage Committee is meeting in Paris commencing 13 December. Professor Ralph Slatyer, the former Australian Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation and the outgoing Chairman of the World Heritage Committee, will lead the Australian delegation. Professor Slatyer will be assisted by Dr D. F. McMichael, Secretary, Department of Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Max Bourke, Director of the Australian Heritage Commission and Mr Ernst Willheim of the Attorney-General's Department. Additionally, the Government, in response to the request by the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Gray, has issued an invitation for the Tasmanian Government to be represented in the delegation subject to the conditions which normally apply to State representatives on Australian Government delegations. For the information of honourable senators, it is the practice at meetings of the World Heritage Committee for the nominating country to respond only to questions put by the Committee. Notwithstanding this limitation on participation in the discussions on the nomination, I hope the invitation to Tasmania will be accepted.

The Government has provided to the Bureau of the World Heritage Committee the additional information sought on the nomination of the Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks for inscription on the World Heritage List. The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh), whom I represent, gave Professor Slatyer this morning, just before his departure for Paris, the Government's response which he will deliver to the Bureau prior to the meeting of the World Heritage Committee. In responding to the request the Government noted that the Bureau has recommended the inscription on the World Heritage List of the Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks. I should like to confirm to the Senate the Government's firm belief in the international importance of this area and its outstanding biological and cultural qualities which have been recognised by its inclusion on the Register of the National Estate. Here I would make special reference to the archaeological sites, the Huon pine habitat, the temperate rainforest and the other unique features of this area. The Commonwealth Government has co-operated with the Tasmanian Government over a number of years in documenting the natural resources of the area as a basis for future planning and management. The Commonwealth looks to continuing this co- operative approach.

Towards this end the Government stands by its commitment to provide financial and other assistance in the establishment and management of a national park of world significance which includes a substantial wilderness component. Nonetheless, the Government has to face facts. The Premier of Tasmania has stated firmly and with the backing of legislation that the proposed dam is to proceed. Accordingly, the Government has indicated to the World Heritage Committee that the Tasmanian Government is constructing a hydroelectric power scheme in the nominated area and that the Commonwealth has been and is discussing the scheme with the Tasmanian Government with a view to minimising the damage that the dam might cause. The Government does not intend to intervene in the construction of the dam. The Government in its discussion with the Tasmanian Government will make it clear that it will back its concern for these features with money, manpower and technical resources.

I am pleased to inform the Senate that the Tasmanian Government has agreed that the Commonwealth will be consulted in the development of the management plan for the area. The mechanism for consultation is to be the subject of discussions with the Tasmanian Government. Whilst Fraser Cave and other caves of archaeological significance will be flooded by the dam, I am advised by Mr McVeigh that every endeavour will be made to preserve this important part of our heritage. The Senate will understand that the position taken by the Government will be welcomed by parts of the community and opposed by others. The expressions of concern have been clear and widespread. Nevertheless, the Government has to strike a balance between competing intentions. Confrontation between the Commonwealth and the States and between individuals in the community is not the road to prosperity, development or the conservation of our heritage. The Government believes, on balance, that its decision is the right one and seeks from the community support in its continuing discussions with the Tasmanian Government. Finally, Mr McVeigh joins with the Premier of Tasmania in exhorting those who oppose the construction of the dam not physically to interfere with construction works. Mr McVeigh makes the comment that he abhors violence, as I am sure do all in the Senate. Nothing can be gained from violent confrontation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I must express on behalf of the Opposition our deepest disappointment with the statement which the Government has just put down. It is one of the most contradictory, hypocritical statements that I have heard in this place. On the one hand the Government insists that it will maintain the nomination of the South West Tasmania region for the World Heritage List. It acknowledges all the reasons why this area should be protected and the reasons that make this area unique. It does not attempt to disagree with the evidence to the effect that in many respects this area is irreplaceable. On the other hand it concludes that the Government does not intend to intervene in the construction of the dam. It is incomprehensible to the Opposition and I think it will be incomprehensible to the general public that the Government has adopted this contradictory position. Either the South West Tasmania region is important and unique enough and is a significant enough possession of the human race to deserve its nomination for the World Heritage List or it is not. If it is-the Government agrees that it is and restates that it is-why is the Government unprepared to take the necessary steps to protect it?

The hypocrisy of the statement is really quite unbelievable. Let us take the particular reference to the caves which are of enormous archaeological significance. I remind honourable senators that when I had an opportunity to speak in support of the Australian Democrats' Bill to protect the South West Tasmania region I referred to the evidence that was given to the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania which inquired into this matter by pre- historians such as Dr Rhys Jones and Professor Mulvaney from the Australian National University. I quoted at some length the evidence they gave because I believed it was, in a way, the most gripping and the most important evidence that had come before that Committee. Their comments are recorded in Hansard, but briefly what they said was that the ancient nature of these caves and the information which they contain about Aboriginal Tasmanians was of outstanding significance to our understanding of the development of the human race. I would say that, particularly in the light of the treatment of the Tasmanian Aboriginal people by the European colonisers, we have an even more overwhelming responsibility to protect that information than we would have had if the Tasmanian people had not been destroyed in the way they were by the invasion.

The tragic irony of what the Government is now proposing to allow to happen has not escaped pre-historians or Aboriginal people. Attention has been drawn to the irony of, first of all, the almost complete genocide which was carried out in Tasmania. Secondly, now that there has been this discovery of the caves which contain the early history of those people who were subjected to genocide we seem to be prepared to sit back to enable that information, that part of the history of the Aboriginal race and the history of humankind, to be wiped out. That is a tragic irony which the Opposition finds intolerable. I remind honourable senators that this is very important evidence because it was not available when the Gordon-below-Franklin dam was first proposed. We believe it would be proper for both governments involved to review their situation and attitude to the damming proposal on the basis of the new evidence which was revealed to the Senate Committee. I do not know what the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) meant when he said:

I am aware that whilst Fraser Cave and other caves of archaeological significance will be flooded by the dam, I am advised by Mr McVeigh that every endeavour will be made to preserve this important part of our heritage.

Again, that is a statement of complete self-contradiction and hypocrisy. The significance of the area is acknowledged, as is the importance of the preservation of this part of our heritage; yet the damming will go ahead. How can the heritage possibly be protected if the damming is to proceed?

On behalf of the Opposition I express our complete disappointment with the Government's failure to look at the alternative package which we have proposed for the economic development of Tasmania. As I said when I spoke on this topic recently, the Federal Australian Labor Party is very sympathetic-extremely sympathetic-to the economic problems faced by Tasmanians. We are all too aware of the unemployment situation in Tasmania. We are all too aware of the collapse of a number of industries-the textile industry, the mining industry and so on. We are not unsympathetic to the pressures on the Tasmanian Government to enter into activities which will create employment and which will start to bring some economic growth. But we do not believe-along with the Senate Select Committee, I might add-that the proposed dam is the economic solution to Tasmania's problems. We believe that a whole range of other economic measures which have been outlined a number of times recently by Senators including me, would be a much more effective form of job generation for the State of Tasmania, which would have a much more stable future than the building of a dam-which, after all, is a one-off thing in terms of employment-and which would provide a great deal more employment across the board for a range of people who are unemployed, not just the people who can work in the construction industry.

I realise that many honourable senators wish to comment on this statement because it has come as such a shock. It is an abrogation of Federal responsibility in a vital area. I believe the Federal Government has taken an extremely shortsighted approach to this problem. It is a complex problem. As I have said, the economic problems in Tasmania are great and cannot be solved easily. But the Federal Government's hypocrisy in, on the one hand, recommending the inclusion of the South West Tasmania region on the World Heritage List and on the other hand, refusing to stop the destruction of that region must be condemned.

—Senator Peter Baume is describing himself with utter perfection when he uses the word 'sham'. At least he has the grace to recognise his own hypocrisy in presenting this particular document. This statement is hypocritical not only because of its decision but also because of its cynical timing. Only three days ago at almost every polling booth in Flinders on hoardings the slogans appeared:

SPEECH.PARA: 'For an effective vote for no dams vote 1 Peter Reith'.

The Liberal Party secretariat was responsible for these slogans yet, while they were erecting those signs, the Liberal members of the Cabinet knew damn well that a decision had been made to dam the River Franklin and allow it to be gone.

But even worse than that political hypocrisy, that home town hypocrisy, to win Flinders by lies, be deceit, and by distortions-let that go-is the fact that the Government made this decision just five days before the World Heritage Committee meets in Paris to discuss South West Tasmania's nomination. This holds the World Heritage Committee in contempt. It treats our nomination as a farce and will bring Australia into international disrepute. I should like to quote what the Australian Heritage Commission has had to say. Does any Liberal opposite say that the Commission comprises a group of people who are rampant communists or rampant left wing militants? I would have thought not but what it said is that this decision will make Australia the laughing stock of the world at the meeting in Paris next week. That is a comment by the Australian Heritage Commission.

The proposition that Senator Peter Baume has put to us this afternoon is that Australia is nominating an area for listing on the World Heritage List, namely, the South West wilderness of Tasmania. Why are we doing that? We nominated it because the Liberal Government believed in November 1981 that it had international geographic values, cultural values, historical, sociological and aesthetic values. That is why we nominated it in November 1981. The Government says: 'We have a duty to protect the area under Article 4 of the international World Heritage Convention. We pledge that we will do everything in our power to the utmost of our resources to protect the area that we nominate'. Five days before the Committee is due to sit the Government says that it will allow some barbarian to plunder the area. Thirteen thousand hectares of the area we have nominated will be submerged under water, water diverted by a State Government in Tasmania. That action is now approved by this Government which has the effrontery, the gall, to go to Paris to present a case for listing. I would not be surprised if the Committee just threw out Australia's representatives on Monday of next week. The Committee would be perfectly entitled to do so. We are not talking about a little backwater. We are talking about an area as important-
Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always amused when I hear the troglodytes opposite, the Senator MacGibbons and the Senator Crichton-Brownes of this world laughing at these sorts of things. What we are talking about is not a backwater area. We are talking about the South West Tasmanian wilderness which has been nominated, along with Lord Howe Island, for listing on the World Heritage List. The only other Australian areas presently listed are the Great Barrier Reef, the Kakadu National Park and the Willandra Lakes region. The South West Tasmanian wilderness is in that league for its uniqueness, its beauty, and its historical and sociological importance. That is how important this proposition is. Yet, this Government is asking us to accept that we will proceed with the listing and simultaneously ask Dr McMichael to say: 'Look, we have asked you to list this but just cut out 13,000 hectares which are going to be flooded forever'.
—I wonder what Mr Reith thinks of that in Flinders.
—I wish Mr Reith were here.
—He would be as humiliated as I am.

—I thank Senator Missen for his comment. I believe it. I accept Senator Missen's interjection as a true statement from Mr Reith. I should like to quote a remarkable sentence from Senator Peter Baume's statement. As Senator Ryan said, after pointing out the importance of this area, the statement says:

SPEECH.PARA: Nonetheless, the Government has to face facts. The Premier of Tasmania has stated firmly-
My goodness, I wonder if it had not been stated firmly by the Premier of Tasmania whether the Anthony-led Government would have reacted differently-
and with the backing of legislation that the proposed dam is to proceed.

No mention was made in the statement made by Senator Peter Baume of the fact that the Commonwealth has the power to override the Tasmanian Government in this area. Who is the authority that I quote? It is no less than the Attorney-General of this Commonwealth who has said that not only has the Commonwealth got the power but perchance it has an obligation to intervene.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Tasmanian Government's own advisers.

—Again, I am indebted to Senator Missen. Tasmania's own advisers also suggest that the Commonwealth has an obligation to intervene in State legislation and prevent the dam. Senator Baume continued in his statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, the Government has indicated to the World Heritage Committee that the Tasmanian Government is constructing a hydro-electric power scheme in the nominated area . . .

What a weak-gutted, limp-wristed way to tell the World Heritage Committee something. Here is a nation which in Paris will appear before 21 member countries of the World Heritage Committee and say: 'Look, we are the national government of Australia. We believe this area should be listed on the World Heritage List but look, chaps, the Tasmanian Goverment is going to proceed with a hydroelectric scheme in the nominated area'.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a Federal Constitution.

—If Senator Teague wants to interject, let him look at the Constitution and let him read the opinion of his own Attorney-General which says that the Commonwealth has an obligation to intervene in this area. The statement pathetically continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not intend to intervene in the construction of the dam.

This hypocrisy has only to be stated to be understood. We can draw an analogy if we roll the clock back a few years to when Dr McMichael was in Paris at a meeting of the World Heritage Committee before the Great Barrier Reef was listed . We would have had the same position then if Dr McMichael, on behalf of Australia, had said: 'We, Australia, nominate the Great Barrier Reef for listing but we must tell you something before you make your decision. We have leased a portion of the Barrier Reef to a multinational oil company to explore for oil. Now will you please go ahead and list it?' The analogy is perfect and total. Yet that is the proposition that Australia is putting now. The Government statement continues:
In responding to the request the Government noted that the Bureau has recommended the inscription on the World Heritage List of the Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks.
The Minister continued:

I should like to confirm to the House the Government's firm belief in the international importance of this area and its outstanding biological and cultural qualities which have been recognised by its inclusion on the Register of the National Estate.
The Government is even without the shame to nominate some of the area's qualities. The Minister says:
Here I would make special reference to the archaeological sites, the Huon Pine habitat, the temperate rainforest and the other unique features of this area.
Then there follows the classic statement of them all by Senator Baume, the Minister for Education:

I am aware that whilst the Fraser Cave and other caves of archaeological significance will be flooded by the dam, let me assure the House that every endeavour will be made to preserve this important part of our heritage.
Have we got a group of fools on the other side of the House?

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you heard of excavation?

—Ah! I note the intellectual capacity of Senator Harradine, the paid sycophant of the Liberal Party. He interjects: 'Haven't you heard of excavation?' I would have thought that Senator Harradine would be more original than that, that he would have suggested that we put a glass cage around the cave . I would have thought at least that that was a proposition that was worthy of consideration, but Senator Harradine says that we should excavate it. I will treat Senator Harradine with the utter contempt that he truly deserves. What a statement to make! I appeal to all members of the Senate, except the paid sycophant, to whom I have just referred. Is the Government foolish enough to believe that this is a statement that can be comprehended: That whilst the Fraser Cave and other caves of archaeological significance will be flooded, the Minister assures the House that every endeavour will be made to preserve this important part of our heritage? What the Minister's statement-he has the shame to use the word 'sham'-does not state is that the evidence before the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania was that this could be, perchance, the most important archaeological discovery ever in the southern hemisphere, and yet what will we do? We will put 13,000 hectares under water. This particular cave, named ironically enough after the Prime Minister of Australia, will be flooded. It shows human habitation of 20,000 years ago. To my knowledge it is the only such cave in the southern hemisphere that can link important research into that era with research being conducted in the northern hemisphere. The Prime Minister himself has received representations from a score or more of world renowned archaeologists, pleading with him not to flood the Fraser Cave. I am sure interested people will take a great deal of heart from the interjection from behind me that it is all right, we should not worry, that we can take out the cave piece of dirt by piece of dirt. I do not know whether the interjector would nominate a spot where it could be resurrected after it has been taken out of the Franklin River. I repeat that the building of this dam will flood 133 square kilometres of wilderness-13,300 hectares-and destroy those archaeological sites of irreplaceable value. With such a proposition, how can that area be preserved? Why did the Federal Government regard the Franklin River as an area of international significance in December 1981, to the extent of nominating it for the World Heritage List while in December 1982 it makes a decision to allow it to be dammed? I quote a comment by a person I admire enormously, Mr George Pizzey, the naturalist who writes for the Melbourne Herald. On 2 December he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: All this lost forever to produce 180 megawatts of power.

I repeat that to produce 180 megawatts of power we will dam 13,300 hectares of the most beautiful country in the world. How much is 180 megawatts of power? Let us compare it with Melbourne's Newport power station, which produces 500 megawatts; Yallourn, which produces 1,450 megawatts and Loy Yang, 2,000 plus megawatts. Yet here is a proposition to produce 180 megawatts of power. With regard to the employment aspect, I wonder whether honourable senators know how many full time jobs will be provided by this dam once it is concluded. The full time jobs provided will amount to 29.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't believe that, surely?

—Twenty-nine full time jobs will be provided for an expenditure of $1,100m. Sometimes, notwithstanding the dislike that Senator MacGibbon attracts to himself from me, although underneath I have an affection for the chap, he is a person who from time to time has extolled the virtues of Senate committees in this place. If he chooses, I can give him the reference to the evidence on that point that was given to the Senate Select Committee. The number of permanent jobs created by this scheme will be 29, for an expenditure of $1,100m to provide 180 megawatts of power. Mr Pizzey concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: Many experts dispute the view that Tasmania's severe economic problems and unemployment can be solved by the availability of more electricity.
There is at least a case for a halt at this stage before this last wilderness is destroyed, and other economic proposals considered, possibly involving Commonwealth compensation.

That is all the majority of the Senate Select Committee asked for. We asked for three years breathing space, that the project be held up for three years to see whether alternative methods of power can be forthcoming. A majority of five out of six members of the Committee concluded that there was no need to proceed with the dam at this stage. What more evidence do the Senator MacGibbons of this world want when an all party Senate Committee says that? Yet the Cabinet, in the absence of the Prime Minister, has gone ahead and has brought down this proposal . There is only one way left, as I understand it--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not saying he didn't know or approve of this decision?
—I do not know. The Senate knows that I am no apologist for the Prime Minister. I never have been and never will be.
—Now is not the time to start.

—It may well be that now is not the time to start. But I happen to believe that the Prime Minister's record on conservation is good and I still have enough faith to believe that this decision was taken against his wishes. Maybe that is naivety at its worst.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that there is only one way left open to us. The Australian Democrats have a Bill which is supported. We thank the Australian Labor Party and some members of the Liberal Party for supporting the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill. The Bill is before the Senate. It has passed the second reading stage. A delaying device has been attached to it by Senator Harradine. If the Bill is passed through the Senate and is sent to the House of Representatives before it rises, at least members of the House of Representatives will be forced to stand up and be counted and to vote on this matter one way or another.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will never get called on.

—That could well be the ultimate test. But I promise Senator Withers that his friends in the House of Representatives-I can accommodate him here-at least will have an opportunity to vote on the question of whether it should be called on. As I understand it there will be a motion to suspend Standing Orders. There are members of his own party, including Mr Reith, who will support that. That will certainly show us those who say in public that they support a proposition and then vote against it in private. At least I can announce this: Notwithstanding the decision, the campaign will not end here. The Australian Democrats, in company with the Australian Labor Party, I am sure, the Tasmanian Wilderness Society and other conservation groups, will not give up the fight at this stage.
—Many Liberals too.

—And many Liberals-I thank Senator Missen for the third time for his helpful interjection. At least 23 Government members hold seats needing a swing of less than 3 per cent to unseat them. They certainly will be targets for attention on the way in which they vote on the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill, which was introduced by the Democrats, once it is passed by the Senate. Their constituents will be advised of how they vote on the motion to suspend Standing Orders to bring this matter on for debate tomorrow or Tuesday.
—You're making me terrified.

—I know it would take a lot to terrify Senator Walters.
