TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I commend the course of action to honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Peter Baume) put:
That the debate be now adjourned.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Government Business has been taken out of the hands of the Government once again. This is a ludicrous waste of time. We now have a situation in which, tomorrow, we will be debating Senator Mason's private member's Bill, the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill, and will continue debate on Senate committee reports. It seems to me quite illogical to spend time on this matter now when we could debate it tomorrow. However, if this is the way that the Senate wants to proceed, I dare say it is in line with the Opposition's efforts to frustrate the passage of business through the Senate. This once again is evidence of the Opposition's efforts in this direction.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan and Senator Chipp have told us that the damming of the Franklin River will mean that there will be nothing left for the Australian Heritage Commission to look at. Maybe they do not understand the situation. Perhaps that is the reason for the venom in Senator Chipp's speech today. The area to be flooded is less than one per cent of the total area defined by the Cartland Committee as the south-west conservation area.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much? One per cent?

—Less than one per cent. It is just 1 1/2 per cent of the total area of the three nominated areas-that is, the South West, the Wild Rivers and the Lake St Clair National Park. Anybody listening today could be forgiven for believing that what Senator Chipp said was accurate, for thinking what on earth is the Government on about. We were going to put up for World Heritage Committee listing the area that we are now damming, nothing more. In point of fact what the Government is doing is putting up for World Heritage Committee listing nearly one-fifth of Tasmania of which less than 1 1/2 per cent is going to be dammed. This is an indication of the idiocy of the statements made little earlier by Senator Chipp.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chipp said that the Government's announcement is not a compromise; that it was taken only for political purposes. I say that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has never deviated from his original statement that this is a State matter. At the very beginning he said that the question of whether a dam would be built was a State decision. The Prime Minister said that he would put forward for inclusion on the World Heritage List the three south west parks nominated by the then Premier Doug Lowe. At no stage has the Prime Minister deviated from that. Right from the beginning it was said that this is a State matter. Senator Chipp now has the hide to say that a decision on this matter was made only three days after the Flinders by-election.

I guess that the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party do not understand the complete freedom enjoyed by each member on this side of the Senate. They do not have that freedom and they do not understand it. I was in East Germany at about the time the last Olympic Games began. I tried to explain to those few sympathetic East Germans I met that although our Government had asked our Olympic athletes not to go to the Games it had said they could make up their own minds and if they wanted to go they could use their Australian passports. The East Germans kept asking me why they were allowed to go if the Australian Government did not want them to take part in the Games. I again explained the Government's attitude but they still asked me why this was allowed to happen. They wanted to know why the Government allowed them to participate in the Games. They did not understand because they do not have the sort of freedom that exists in Australia. Likewise, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats do not understand because senators on their side of the Senate do not have the freedom under which a Liberal candidate can say: 'I will fight for a no dam decision. It does not matter what the Liberal Government decides, I will fight for a no dam decision'. Our candidates have that freedom. Our members of parliament have that freedom and, really, I do not blame members of the Opposition for not understanding it. They have never had that freedom and they are never likely to have it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't overdo it.

—I ask Senator Missen not to interject. Senator Chipp spoke about the Great Barrier Reef. He said that although we are able to say to the World Heritage Committee that we want this area contained we are going to allow the State that owns the land to build a dam as part of its own energy resources. He likened that situation to the Great Barrier Reef.
—Where is Senator Chipp who was so concerned?

—None of the Democrats is in the chamber. Senator Chipp has had his say and off he has flown. Whilst Senator Chipp likened this area to the Great Barrier Reef he did not liken it to the Kakadu National Park because that national park does not happen to suit his purpose. I remind the Senate that the Commonwealth put barriers around the mining area when the Kakadu National Park was put forward for listing on the World Heritage List. So in point of fact the Kakadu National Park was listed and accepted by the World Heritage Committee although mining was being carried out within that park.
—Not within it.

—To be accurate the mining is not within it; boundaries were put around the mining area. I have no qualms about boundaries being put around the Franklin Dam area. That would delete 1 1/2 per cent of the national park nominated for listing. Senator Chipp said that the whole area will be dammed, that 1,300 hectares of land are going to be flooded. However, he did not mention the percentage that was of the total area. It did not even enter his head to bring that into his argument because if he had his speech would have been completely ludicrous. These facts would have put the damming into perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: We have also been told by Senator Chipp today that 41 per cent of people in Flinders voted for no dams, that they wrote the words 'No Dam' across their ballot paper. The other day during Question Time I asked Senator Baume whether this claim was based on an official count figure. He said that there was no official count. I also asked from where the figure came. I asked whether the figure was a figment of the imagination of a scrutineer who had Tasmanian wilderness sympathies. Of course, the only answer is that this must be so. There is no official figure. I could claim that 10 per cent, one per cent or 0.5 per cent of people wrote 'No Dam' across the ballot paper and nobody in this place could correct me. There are no figures whatsoever in this respect. I could claim right here and now that less than 0.5 per cent of Flinders voters wrote 'No dam' across their ballot paper. But we do not know. No one knows whether that is correct because there are no official figures. I do not hazard a guess like that . Only people who want to mislead would hazard a guess and say that 41 per cent of people acted in this way. As I say, such an estimate is just a figment of the imagination of one of the scrutineers.

What did the Labor Party and the Democrats suggest we do? The Federal Government has said to the State: 'Right, it is a State decision to go ahead and build the dam in your area. We would like you to look after that area. We will assist you financially to look after it and to preserve as much as is physically possible'. Do the Labor Party and the Democrats suggest that we send in the troops, that the Government say: 'You will not build that dam'? The Tasmanian Premier has already had the relevant legislation passed in his State and has sent men in to build the dam. What does the Opposition want us to do? Are we to send in the troops to stop that work proceeding? Obviously, it must accept responsibility for sending in protesters to lie in front of the bulldozers. I tell Senator Button that I am very sincere when I say that that prospect terrifies me. I am sure that if honourable senators had seen on the program Nationwide bulldozer drivers at Queenstown being asked what was likely to happen they would be terrified also. I am extremely concerned that there will be not a peaceful demonstration but rather one that could end in violent confrontation. That is something about which surely everyone in the Senate should be concerned.

Rather than the representatives of the Labor Party standing up in this place and saying: 'Do not go in' they should remember that we live in a democracy; that a decision has been made by the elected government of Tasmania and the elected government of Australia that the dam should go ahead. Let us not try to use mob rule. Let us abide by the true democratic principles that Australians regard as precious. Instead, the Labor Party and the Democrats are sending in a number of supporters to demonstrate, a prospect that I find absolutely terrifying. I find it difficult to believe that the two Opposition parties would seek to create that kind of confrontation in an isolated, tough area, one that is not closely scrutinised. It could end in the sort of confrontation that I believe the Australian people would not want to see. I will hold the Labor Party and the Democrats primarily responsible for anything that occurs there. They have not been seen to stand up and plead that that kind of thing not be allowed to occur. On the contrary, the Federal Government and the State Liberal Government have done so; the Democrats and the Labor Party have not. In that regard they have been very remiss and, as a result, must certainly accept the blame for anything unfortunate that happens there.

I wish to return to the subject of the listing and how it took place because I think many honourable senators are not aware of the facts. The then Premier, Doug Lowe, submitted the area for listing while he was in the last stages of his premiership. The proposal was not passed by the State Parliament. That Parliament did not submit the South West for listing. It was submitted by one man.

TALK.START.PARA: —Plus the Federal Cabinet.

—I am talking about Doug Lowe submitting to the Federal Parliament the proposal to list these areas. I repeat, it was not passed by the State Parliament; it was submitted to the Commonwealth by one man from Tasmania.
—Rubbish.

—Do not say that it is rubbish. I have inquired and have found that that statement is completely accurate. The proposal was not passed by the State Parliament at any stage. I find it a matter of great concern that one man should advance such a proposal and claim that Tasmania wanted it. That was rubbish. At no stage was it shown that Tasmania wanted that. The Opposition is seeking mob rule versus democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chipp said that 29 jobs would be created as a result of the damming of the Gordon below Franklin. Then turning to Senator Teague, he said. 'If you do not believe me I will show you the evidence that was put before us'. Good heavens, there would not be in this place a senator who had not sat on Senate committees that had had all sorts of evidence put before them. If we are to accept as gospel every bit of evidence that is put before us--

TALK.START.PARA: —That was HEC evidence.

—The Hydro-Electric Commission submitted evidence that maintenance would involve 29 jobs. It did not say that the building of the dam would result in the creation of that number of jobs, which is what Senator Chipp said. The honourable senator omitted to list all the jobs that would result from the supplying of additional energy in Tasmania. At no stage did Senator Chipp suggest that it would result in even one job. It was extremely convenient for him to forget that the energy that would flow to industry would create jobs.
—Name one industry.

—Senator Grimes keeps interjecting: 'Name one industry'. I can assure him that when the dam proposal was first mooted Premier Doug Lowe was asked in the State Parliament how many industries he had to knock back because of the absence of an energy source. That was quite some time ago. He admitted that quite a number of people had sought to bring industries to Tasmania but had been knocked back because they could not be given hydro-power. They could have been given Bell Bay power.
—Come on, name one.
—The honourable senator should read Hansard. I cannot name one of the people who have sought power; Doug Lowe refused to name them.
—Oh!

—The honourable senator should read Hansard. Doug Lowe refused to name them, stating that the information was confidential. He said that he had knocked back certain industries because they required hydro-power. He had told them that they could have only Bell Bay power, which was far too expensive. He could not allow them the use of hydro-power because it was not available in sufficient quantities. How idiotic it was to claim that only 29 jobs would be created.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to speak further on this statement by the Government. The debate that will take place tomorrow on the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill and the report of the Senate Committee will be sufficiently time consuming. As Senator Peter Baume has said, the relevant matters should have been discussed as one. That is why the Senate suggested that the statement be listed for debate tomorrow. However, the matter was taken out of the Government's hands by the Opposition and the Democrats, who said: 'No, we want a full debate on this statement now; we will debate the other matters tomorrow'. That is a pity because it is a complete waste of the time of the Senate to debate them separately rather than jointly. I intend to continue my remarks on the South West in the course of the discussion on those related measures tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I refer to the terms of the statement I wish to make one or two comments that I believe to be important about Senator Walters's remarks. The honourable senator spent much time in attempting to prove to the Senate that it was most unlikely that 41 per cent of the electorate of Flinders had written 'No Dams' on their ballot papers, that it might well have been only 10 per cent or half a per cent. But that is quite irrelevant to the argument that she has put in this place on numerous occasions. Her argument, as I understand it, is that it does not matter how many people on the mainland write 'no dams' on the ballot paper. The figure could be 100 per cent; it is still not relevant. It is a matter entirely for the concern of Tasmanians. The honourable senator talked about wasting time in the Senate but I am not sure why she spent so much time on that argument because, according to her own argument, it is irrelevant.
—Why don't you run over all those unkind things you said about Tasmania last week, Senator?

—Seeing Senator MacGibbon provokes me and draws my attention to him-I would not normally have noticed him- I make just one point about some of the arguments which have been advanced in this place by people such as him. Like Senator Walters, they say it is a States issue and that the Senate is a States House. At some stage I would like to hear from Senator MacGibbon his view-I hope that, mercifully, it will be brief-as to what conclusion he draws from the fact that half the Tasmanian senators in this place supported the Australian Democrats' Bill. What does one conclude, then, about this place being a States House? Does that mean you pick your half?
—They are not very bright.

—Senator Lewis has provided the answer-50 per cent of them are not very bright. He should go out and tell his colleague Senator Rae about that and have the argument with him, not with me. The fact of the matter is whether, if one seriously advances arguments about this being a States House, one can conclude anything when half the senators in this States House, which, according to that argument, has nothing to do with parties--
—You never said it was a States House.
—No, I have not.
—Senator Button, do not waste time on my argument; waste it on your own.
—I can understand that perhaps Senator MacGibbon cannot follow it . It is a problem he has had since he came into the Senate.
—I accept that it is a Federal argument.

—It is an important debating point; it is what this statement is all about. The burden of Senator Walters's argument is that it is the responsibility of the opposition to have no views on this topic different from those of the Government. That is the burden of Senator Walters's argument because what she is saying is that if there is any violence when this dam is built, it will be our responsibility. Why is it our responsibility? It is because we advance a different view in the Senate from the view advanced by the Government. That is what Senator Walters is saying. If that is her view of a democracy, my spine shivers at the thought of all the arguments she has put about democratic processes in this country. Senator Walters went on to say that one of the great defects in the nomincation to the World Heritage Committee is that it was made intitially by one man-Doug Lowe. She said it was a disaster that that nomination should be made by one man, Doug Lowe. Then, two sentences later, she cited Doug Lowe as the impeccable authority for the proposition that the dam would create hundreds of jobs in Tasmania.
—No, I did not.

—Senator Walters did say that. She referred to new industries and said that Doug Lowe was the man who announced that new industries would be created as a result of the building of the dam. So he is the authority for that proposition and he is condemned--
—No, I did not say that.

—It is no good Senator Walters cackling. That is what she said. I just mention these matters because they illustrate much of the Government's approach to this statement, which really is one of the sadest statements in a sense that I have ever seen brought into this Parliament because of its essentially dyslectic quality. I believe that the statement was drafted by the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Anthony). It has all the hallmarks of a man who favours free trade when he is abroad and protection when he is at home. It has all those schizophrenic qualities. It has all the hallmarks of the Acting Prime Minister of this country, including its essential illiteracy. It is shameful that on such an important issue the Government should bring in a statement of such quality.
—What is the illiterate part?

—I will come to that. The first reason I advance as to its being a statement of the Acting Prime Minister is its essential quality-which is appalling. Secondly, the statement is contrary to Liberal Party policy so I think it unlikely that it was drafted by a Liberal Party Minister. Thirdly, it is contrary to the views of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr McVeigh-views which were expressed quite publicly yesterday. As I have said in another way, it has all the quality which is reminiscent of Stephen Leacock's character who jumped on a horse and galloped in all directions, trying to satisfy a variety of opinions in the community by not making any responsible decision about this very important issue. There is nothing new about that.
—That sounds just like the Labor Party.

—Senator Withers is alive again. After five years of bludging in this place he was suddenly stirred by the tax evasion debate. He has come to life again. He made no speeches for five years and he has come in here to defend tax evaders and to interject in the South West Tasmanian debate-the leader of the Western Australian Liberal Senate team. What a superb effort! Senator Withers is alive and well and dozing in Canberra.
—Little Big Horn.

—Anything you like, Senator, but it hurts, does it not, because it is true? Everybody on your side knows it is true. Let me go to the details of the statement, which is a very important statement in terms of consideration of conservation issues in Australia and a very important statement in consideration of economic issues in Australia. The first point I want to make is that this statement is reminiscent of everything this Government does. Political survival comes before everything else in terms of this Government's considerations. Look at what is said in the second paragraph of the statement. The Acting Prime Minister says:

SPEECH.PARA: If these nominations are accepted by the World Heritage Committee, these areas will join the Kakadu National Park, the Great Barrier Reef and the Willandra Lakes Region on the World Heritage List.

What does that mean? That is a horrifying statement in terms of people who are concerned about, for example, the Great Barrier Reef. It is absolutely horrifying. This statement says that we will put the South West region of Tasmania on the World Heritage List and at the same time we will make no national decision about whether this region is essentially destroyed or not. What does that say about the Great Barrier Reef being in the hands of this Government? What does it say about the Kakadu National Park?

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know the boundaries of the park?

—I do not want Senator Teague's view because it does not count when the hard decisions are made. What does it say about any of these things in terms of the Government's policies? It says that none of them can be relied on in regard to these issues. The statement then goes on at some length to deal with the history of the matter and what will happen at the meeting of the World Heritage Committee. On page 2 it gets to the nitty-gritty and the important considerations which, as I have said, are totally contrary to the expressed views of the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I join Senator Chipp on the issue of total lack of comprehension in this statement of the special reference to archaeological sites, the Huon pine habitat, the temperate rainforest and the other unique features of this area. These references are made in the same statement which says that a significant part of it will be destroyed. The statement goes on to say:
The Commonwealth Government has co-operated with the Tasmanian Government over a number of years in documenting the natural resources of the area as a basis for future planning and management.

How much has been spent on that, I wonder, by the Commonwealth Government pursuing the Liberal Party policy of 1975, the Liberal Party policy enunciated by Senator Peter Rae in the Senate last week? How much taxpayers' money has been spent on that exercise by the Commonwealth Government in pursuit of documenting the natural resources of the area? This statement identifies the key natural resource and then goes on to say that it will be destroyed. How much taxpayers' money has been spent on that in pursuit of Liberal Party policy? The statement goes on to say:
the Government stands by its commitment to provide financial and other assistance in the establishment and management of a national park.
Then the statement says:
the Government has to face facts.

The fact is-not 'facts' in the plural-that Premier Gray in Tasmania has stated firmly that the proposed dam is to proceed. That is the fact with which we must deal. We are not allowed to examine that fact because that would be putting a different view from that of the Government, and one which might encourage some young conservationists to go down there and demonstrate, and then it would be on the Opposition's head if they did that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should appeal to them not to do so, Senator.

—I wish the honourable senator would not keep on telling the Opposition its responsibilities. Honourable senators opposite are in government and they have to make the decisions about these matters, and they have to provide the leadership. On this matter, as on everything else, they are not very good at doing that. The Premier of Tasmania has, as I have said, said that it will proceed.
—And the Tasmanian Parliament.

—Yes, but that is the essential fact, is it not? As has been pointed out, that is accepting a Commonwealth obligation with one hand and denying it with the other. The statement goes on, in what must be the most classic example of double-think ever displayed in a statement by a Minister to say that the Commonwealth Government will discuss with the Tasmanian Government:

SPEECH.PARA: with a view to minimising the damage that the dam might cause.
Then the statement says:
The Government does not intend to intervene in the constrution of the dam.

Those two extraordinary sentences are lying together in one statement by an allegedly responsible Minister. Then, on page 3, there is the part of the statement with which Senator Chipp dealt. The Minister says:

I am aware that whilst Fraser Cave and other caves of archaeological significance will be flooded by the dam, let me assure the House that every endeavour will be made to preserve this important part of our heritage.

There was a bit of debate, by way of interjection, as to what on earth that meant. No one knows what that meant. I believe that no one in this Senate still has any idea of what that means. The reason is that it is gobbledegook. But if it is intended to mean anything, one would have thought that a Minister in the Government would have said what it was intended to mean. It just does not mean anything. We could have 64 speeches in this place interpreting what that silly sentence means. It is crucial to the whole issue, and it is written in absolute gobbledegook. In the second last paragraph there is this classic statement of political philosophy:
The House will understand that the position taken by the Government will be welcomed by parts of the community and opposed by others.
Those who oppose it are guilty of some offence, according to Senator Walters' views. It continues:
Nevertheless, the Government has to strike a balance between competing intentions.

This is not a statement about striking a balance between competing intentions. It is about striking a balance about votes. It is trying to strike a balance about competing votes. That is why it is couched in these mealy-mouthed terms, giving with one hand and taking away with the other. The statement goes on to say:
Confrontation between the Commonwealth and the States and between individuals in the community is not the road to prosperity.

That is the most serious economic statement that has been made by this Government in months-'confrontation between the States and the Commonwealth Government is not the road to prosperity'. This Government has not been able to tell us what is the road to prosperity, but at least it has told us something- that confrontation with Mr Gray is not the road to prosperity. The statement goes on to refer to confrontation being not in the interests of development or the conservation of our heritage. I, for one, do not know what that means, either. Then there is, of course, the exhortation about violence, which is tagged on most government statements about anything, and which does not have much more relevance here.

There are very sound conservation reasons which are terribly important to the national identity and heritage of this country which have been advanced in this debate and which are crucial to the content of this statement. Another argument which is very important in political terms is when in Australia we shall confront the situation of making national economic decisions. All the major problems of this country at present relate very much to its incapacity over many years to make national economic decisions. That is why we have a car industry scattered all over the country which is going down the chute day after day. We have all sorts of industries which suffer from the fact that we have never been able to make national economic decisions about them. I am not making a partisan political point; I am saying that it is an important point in terms of good government in this country. The fact of the matter is that the decision about South West Tasmania is a decision of national economic significance, because if $1,100m is to be spent on this dam-the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) knows that the projections of the Tasmanian Government about the demands for energy are wrong, as his Department knows; they are vastly inflated-

TALK.START.PARA: —As they gave evidence before the Committee.

—As they gave evidence before the Committee, I am reminded. If the Department of National Development and Energy knows that and the Minister knows that, it is an abdication of a national economic decision not to try to influence events against the building of this dam. The facts of the matter are, as other speakers have pointed out, that the Hydro-Electric Commission, on its own evidence, will employ 29 people after the dam is completed. Up to the time that it is completed, it will employ perhaps 1,000 people. In terms of the cost of this dam, $1,100m, we could pay each one of those 1,000 workers-not the 29 workers-a sum which would allow them to live on the French Riviera, in a manner to which they have never been accustomed, for the rest of their lives, and we would still have saved money for this country in national economic terms. If Tasmania borrows the money, it will not be able to service the debt in respect of this dam and this Commonwealth Parliament will be asked to do so. It is an abdication of national economic decision making to treat the whole issue with the simplicity and vote-catching survival strategy which-
—You just don't understand that we would not want to go to live on the French Riviera.
—Order, Senator Walters!
—You don't understand that we think that Tasmania is quite as good.
—Order, Senator Walters!

—One thing about which I am quite clear is that no one in his right mind would want to live on the French Riviera with Senator Walters. I was not talking about Senator Walters. I was talking about the people who might get jobs on the building of the dam.
—They would not want to go.

—I understand that, Senator. I am making a point, with a touch of hyperbole, which to people of average intelligence indicates a view about the employment situation and the economics of building the dam. It is very important . We listened to Question Time in this place today. Senator Sir John Carrick, with a good deal of political courage, said that it would be right to put up the price of petrol next year although that is contrary to every current attitude of the Government's economic policy. For reasons of looking to the future, he said, it would be right to do that. That is a matter for debate. But there is some courage in that decision related to looking to the national economic future.

SPEECH.PARA: But there is total cowardice in this decision. The Government is not prepared to look to the national economic future in relation to the $1,100m to be spent in Tasmania because Mr Gray says so. Mr Gray is like all of us. He will come and go. He will walk across the stage of politics and disappear from it much more quickly, I think, than many of us here. But it is an absurd abdicaiton of national economic responsibility in terms of national economic planning to go on like this on an issue such as this. For years we have done it in this country and got ourselves into so much trouble.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are talking economic nonsense.
—I thank Senator Harradine. If he would get off the fence on this issue we would know what he really is talking about.
—I am quite happy. I am well and truly off the fence. I will show you how you are talking economic nonsense.
—On the issue; I am not talking about debating points.
—I am talking about the issue. The alternatives are far more costly.
—Senator Harradine says it is far more costly than the alternatives.
—I said that the alternatives are far more costly.

—Senator Harradine says the alternatives are far more costly. Perhaps he will address his mind to whether the alternatives are needed. If he is thinking about the economic future of his State alone, being probably incapable of thinking about the national economic future, he should address his mind to whether the alternatives are needed and perhaps to the question, that Senator Walters could not answer, of what was in the secret confines of Doug Lowe's mind when he spoke of the industries that Tasmania would attract in the 1990s because of the building of this dam. Of course, what we in this Parliament also have to face up to is that manufacturing industry in this country is now steadily on a decline and has been for the past 15 years. The decline is accelerating, demand for energy is declining-more rapidly in Tasmania than anywhere else-and if somebody can come up with the answer on how we reverse that whole process in Australia, an answer which is not a gimmick like the wages freeze but an honest, carefully thought out answer--
—You would not accept it.

—Oh, yes. This Government would be in government forever if it came up with that answer because that is the crucial issue in Australian politics at the moment. The party that finds the answer to that, instead of this sort of gimmickry, deserves to be in government. It is absolutely crucial. This statement is appalling in the way in which it deals with a very important issue. It is appalling in quality and appalling in argument. But on two essential bases -the importance of protecting a very significant area of the Australian environment and the capacity of this Government to make national economic decisions which look to the future-it is a very sad statement indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not originally intended to enter into this debate today and in fact at the time when Senator Chipp finished speaking I thought that sufficient had been said about this sad statement before us not to require it to be trampled too much more in debate today, but rather that we should hear what the public had do say about it. I am sure of one thing; this debate will go on and on and on, and the public will be heard more. The statement today represents a sad temporary holding position. I do not believe for one moment that this will be the ultimate decision that the Government will make. I think that the public will make itself--
—We might have to change the Government though.

—No, I do not take that view. Today I feel very sorry for the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Tom McVeigh, because I believe he has fought a valiant fight. Obviously he has been overborne by some heavier forces.
—The Country Party.

—Well, he is a National Party Minister. He has fought well. I realise the humiliation he must have experienced to put down such an inconsistent statement which mentions national responsibilities and then tells how they are going to be torn up. I enter the debate very briefly. It has been very difficult to enter into debates on South West Tasmania. As a member of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania I have not yet had an opportunity to speak to or justify my views on the report.
—Neither have I.

—Neither has Senator Hill. Unfortunately, one of our colleagues chose to muscle in ahead of members of the Committee on the first occasion and, of course, more muscling in has been done today. We probably will not have a debate on the important issue of the Committee report and what should be done. These matters will be more fundamental than the political decisions being made at the moment, one of which was handed to Professor Slatyer this morning-just before he left. The way in which these things are done is really incredible. The people in Paris will have to decide what they will do about the issue of putting this area on the World Heritage List. Whatever happens, this issue is a big issue. I place much more reliance than I place on that statement on the fact that last weekend 41 per cent of the voters of Flinders chose to mark their ballot papers. That is something which Australian citizens are fearful of doing because they fear it might upset their ballot and might be disregarded. But they chose that course and very careful scrutineers counted the votes. Of course, it was unofficial-Senator Walters seems to think that fact is very important-but it was very reliable and nobody has sought to challenge its accuracy. Nobody has suggested that anyone wrote 'More dams' or 'Have more dams' on their ballot papers last Saturday. Nobody has suggested that even a single person did that. But 41 per cent of the electors down there at Flinders turned their minds to writing 'No dams' on their ballot papers and that is a very fundamental action. It will be observed by people in many other electorates across this country, particularly on the eastern seaboard. I have no doubt that as a result of the developments which will come from this most alarming and absurd decision there will have to be reconsideration of it. As anger rises in the community and as great trouble occurs in the community, which one regrets, one will realise that this cannot be taken as a sufficient answer by people who are responsible in Parliament. Indeed, I am ashamed of the decision that has been made.
—You were conned last Thursday.

—Last Thursday I worked and spoke strongly for a candidate who is committed to 'no dams' and who, like me, urged that the dam building should be stopped. Senator Martyr, sitting next to me, giggles now because he thinks we were conned. I do not think I was conned. Indeed, I believe that Peter Reith was elected on a proper issue. If the Government makes the mistake of thinking that the vote in Flinders was an endorsement of mere economic policies, it is wrong. It was certainly no endorsement of alternative ALP policies; that was very clear . But it was a very clear endorsement of a candidate who took an initiative and who gained votes by it. More importantly than that, 41 per cent of the electors determined to show their views. These matters will not go away. This afternoon in the Senate the debate has perhaps dwindled in significance and gone on too long. Perhaps there are more important things, even with regard to the Franklin issue, that we should be debating now. But we should listen to what the public has to say.

SPEECH.PARA: As one who has taken, I suppose, a high profile on this issue, I now find myself in a position in which a decision has been made that I hope will be temporary. It is one which I believe is most mistaken and most disastrous for the Government. Nonetheless, I for one will be fighting to change that. I am in no way lost in my determination to ensure that this great area of Tasmania is preserved, that the people who write to me and to members of parliament in their hundreds are not going to be left alone and neglected. We will fight this issue through until we win. I believe the public should come to the rescue of Parliament and make sure that this issue remains in the foremost parts of our minds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a few minutes of the Senate 's time to speak to the statement on South West Tasmania made this afternoon by the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume). It was a very disappointing statement. The Government took nearly two pages to say how committed it was to nominating the Western Tasmanian Wilderness National Parks for inscription in the World Heritage List. It built up people's hopes but then towards the bottom of the second page of the statment it let all those people down by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Nonetheless, the Government has to face facts.
The statement goes on to say:
The Government does not intend to intervene in the construction of the dam.

I will come back in a few moments to comment on a few of the sentences in the statement. Looking at it as a whole it is very obviously a cut and paste job, hastily put together. Sentences begin at the right hand side of the page. Bits have been whited out and other bits have been cut out and the page stuck together again. The sense of some paragraphs does not follow on. For instance, at the bottom of page 2 it states:
The Government does not intend to intervene in the construction of the dam.
The next paragraph states:
The Government in its discussion with the Tasmanian Government will make it clear that it will back its concern for these features with money, manpower and technical resources.

It is very difficult to see what these features are. Perhaps they were mentioned several paragraphs earlier. As I say, it is a very poorly put together statement and it obviously reflects the Government's very poor decision. Before I continue I seek from Senator Peter Baume an indication of whether the Government intends this statement to be the considered Government response to the report to the Senate last week of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania. The Minister does not give me any such indication. He obviously does not know whether it is supposed to be such a response. There is no reference to the recommendations and conclusions of that report in this statement. The statement does not deal at all with the question of power demand and supply and whether the dam is needed at all. The Government has ignored the report altogether. I am not suggesting that it necessarily should have brought down its total response to the report in one week, but at least it could have made some reference to it and indicated whether it was going to give further consideration to the conclusion that there is no need to start construction for at least three years because of the power demand and supply question.

If the statement is not a response to that Senate Select Committee's report I would like to know when the Government will respond. If it does respond, to what extent would the Government allow that response to be different from the position mentioned in the statement today? Perhaps Senator Missen is right; that this is just a temporary statement to cover the position until the Government has given consideration to the Senate Select Committee's report. But it would be difficult to know how the Government expects the South West Wilderness area-the nominated area-to be listed by the World Heritage Committee when it has made a clear announcement that it has no intention of protecting the area in accordance with its obligations under the very World Heritage Convention that it has signed and under which it has nominated the area. How does it expect that listing to happen? How does it expect the World Heritage Committee to respond to such a blatant notice by the Government that it will not comply with the terms of the Convention, let alone the spirit? As other speakers have said before me, it is hypocritical to expect to be able to have both. This statement is just a statement of words in respect of the nomination. I would like to put one specific question to the Minister concerning the last paragraph on page one which states:
For the information of honourable senators, it is the practice at meetings of the World Heritage Committee for the nominating country to respond only to questions put by the Committee.

This is in relation to the involvement of the Tasmanian representative at the meeting in Paris. It is not clear to me whether that sentence means that the Government wants to emphasise that it is only the nominating country-that is Australia-and not the unrecognised body-Tasmania-which will respond, or whether the Government really means that 'only' to be where it is. Perhaps the Minister might like to tell me about the deliberate nature and placement of that word. The statement went on to refer to:

. . . the Government's firm belief in the international importance of this area and its outstanding biological and cultural qualities which have been recognised by its inclusion on the Register of the National Estate.

The statement specifically makes reference to the archaeological sites. Let me point out that without those archaeological sites the cultural value, which is the other arm of the nomination and of the Convention, disappears altogether. Certainly there would be some natural value left in the area being nominated but not 98 1/2 per cent as Senator Walters would have us believe. She makes great play of only a small percentage of the area actually being flooded and that it is not a significant part of the area being nominated. But the important thing that has to be realised by everyone, including the Committee in Paris, is that it is amongst the most significant parts of the area being nominated that will be affected by the dam. Whether it is 1 1/2 per cent or some other percentage that is actually flooded is not important; it is the parts that will be lost because of that, including the cultural parts, those parts with archaeological value, and the most significant natural parts. Of course, in answer to Senator Walters, there are other things to look at in Tasmania and other parts will not have a lake over them. The whole concept of wilderness obviously is not understood by Senator Walters and apparently not by the Government either, despite its mouthing those words and suggesting that this area can be nominated for the World Heritage List and that the dam can proceed.

I regret to say that the wording of the statement is a joke. It would have been more honest of the Government to have said that in view of the Tasmanian Government's intransigence it withdraws the nomination for World Heritage listing. The Government is trying to have it both ways but it cannot. On page 2 there is the curious statement that the Government will:
. . . provide financial and other assistance in the establishment and management of a national park of world significance which includes a substantial wilderness component.

I am not one suggesting that the wilderness will be totally destroyed by the intrusion of the flooding, but it will be virtually destroyed. One cannot say: ' We have a wilderness here and 100 yards away we have human intervention'. The area is either wilderness or it is not. To say that there will be a substantial wilderness component when the area is destroyed-the Government is now supporting its destruction-is not to face facts, although the Government is claiming to do so. Even more amazing is the statement that the Government is discussing the scheme with the Tasmanian Government 'with a view to minimising the damage that the dam might cause.' That is a laughable statement. The Government would have done itself more credit by leaving out the stupid suggestion that it could minimise the damage that the dam might cause. I hope that the Minister in reply will also explain the following statement, which stands on its own and is inconsistent with what appears before it:
The Government in its discussion with the Tasmanian Government will make it clear that it will back its concern for these features with money, manpower and technical resources.

I trust that the Minister will give us more details about what that means. Another statement which will be impossible to comply with relates to Fraser Cave . The Government says that, whilst the cave will be flooded, every endeavour will be made to preserve this important part of our heritage. It is either flooded or it is preserved. It cannot be both. It is just not possible to preserve such an important part of the world's heritage by flooding it. I do not know whether the Government is suggesting that archaeologists in future will be trained in underwater diving, but it is a crazy notion. A further impossible suggestion which appears later is that the Government will strike a balance between competing intentions. I suggest that there is no balance at all. The Government is not striking a balance. It is purporting to strike a balance but in no way is it doing so. I understand that Fraser Cave was named after the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in the hope that he would not wish something named after him to disappear under water. Today the name ought to be changed since it has not had its desired effect.

Senator Walters made great play of the fact that the Australian Labor Party has not opposed the demonstration in the South West by those who are concerned about the matter. She tried to attribute blame for that activity to the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats and, presumably, to those members of the Liberal Party who support the nomination of the area and voted last week for the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill. I am worried, too. She does not have the sole ability to worry about people getting hurt. Demonstrating is not necessarily the wisest thing that people do when they feel strongly about a matter. But it is the right of people to demonstrate their concern and, of course, they should accept any consequences that arise. During demonstrations against the Vietnam war people were arrested because of their desire to be conscientious objectors. The law was wrong and they had the right to demonstrate against it and had to take the consequences. But let not Senator Walters say that anything that happens in Tasmania will be the fault of the Labor Party, the Australian Democrats or those Liberal Party members who were overruled today. Her talk of mob rule only encourages a reaction. I hope that the right of people to demonstrate will be supported. I do not think that the offer by the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) to send Australian Federal Police officers into the area to assist helps the situation. I suggest that it is a most inappropriate offer, quite apart from being contradictory. If it is inconsistent for the Federal Government to interevene, it is inconsistent for Federal Police to be involved in the area.

I conclude by referring to the earlier vote on whether this debate ought to proceed. It may not have been observed by people that apart from the pairs that were involved, several Government senators abstained from voting and obviously wanted the debate to proceed. I hope that now that that vote is well past they will return to the chamber and vote on this question. I can understand the disappointment of those honourable senators, including Senator Missen, who spoke before me, in the Government's position especially so soon after the Flinders by -election, which to some degree was won by the Government on false advertising. It is another indication that such Liberal Party advertising cannot be trusted. It is also unfortunate that the Government deferred its statement until today, after the by-election. It is difficult to believe that it was not deliberate that the statement was delayed until now. There is nothing in it that could not have been said last week. It is not as if a lot of attention were given to the contents of the report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania, which would have given the Government an excuse to delay its statement until this week.

I do not believe, although it is an interesting suggestion, that the Government 's decision today was made in order to stop a resignation from the Ministry. I do not believe that the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) is so important to the Government's fortunes, even in the eyes of the Government. But, of course, we heard the suggestion from Mr Hodgman that he would consider resigning unless the Government decided not to intervene. It is possible that a strong consideration on the part of the Government was that it could not afford to have the disruption of a Minister resigning and the consequential reshuffle that would occur, something which would further show its instability and division. I am pleased to have been able to make these comments on the ministerial statement at this stage. I repeat that it is a very sad day that this statement by the Minister was put down in such terms. I am pleased to support the position of the Australian Labor Party on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my intention to canvass a number of the points that have been made in this debate. Some of them have been irrelevant to the matter that is before us; that is, the statement that has been put down on behalf of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh) . I do not intend to address myself now-I am quite prepared to do so in an extended debate-to the economic nonsense that was talked by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) in respect of the costs involved. Nor do I intend at this moment to address myself to the vitriolic nonsense that was engaged in by Senator Chipp, particularly his unwarranted remarks about honourable senators. Suffice it to say that Senator Chipp has been caught out previously with his statements which, when matched with the truth, have not stood up. I refer, of course, to the comment that he made on 25 November wherein he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . 2,300 litres of oil has been lost in the Gordon River.
At that stage I said:
That is untrue.

Senator Chipp indicated that I ought to go and get lost, or words to that effect . I have a statement that was prepared by the Department of Environment in Tasmania which indicated that all of the 13 drums of oil were recovered intact from the river and that, in fact, the samples that were taken showed that in the areas where they were taken-Sea Reach, Barbers Pole, Champ Cliff, Butler Island and Sir John Falls-there was roughly six milligrams per litre of weathered diesel oil in the water. Of course, that represents about six parts per million. So much for what Senator Chipp had to say in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was like the rest of his argument; it was insignificant.

—Also it was not in accordance with the facts. Today I wish to address myself to the statement that is before us. I say very clearly: The statement is both constitutionally proper and timely. On behalf of the Government the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government has co-operated with the Tasmanian Government over a number of years in documenting the natural resources of the area as a basis for future planning and management. The Commonwealth looks to continuing this co -operative approach.

The statement adverted to the fact that the project has the backing of legislation which has been passed by both Houses of the Tasmanian Parliament. Fifty-one out of the 54 members of the Tasmanian Parliament voted for the project to be continued. No one can say that that was a party vote. The 51 out of the 54 included members of the Liberal Party of Australia, members of the Australian Labor Party and Independent members of the Legislative Council. These people have the responsibility and the capacity to evaluate the projects and come to a democratic decision. This they did. This statement recognises that there was a responsibility by the Tasmanian Parliament so to act and that the Commonwealth will not use any conceivable power that it may have already under the Constitution to intervene in a matter which is properly a matter for the State. In respect of the nomination of the area to the World Heritage Committee the statement goes on to say:

. . . the Government . . . has issued an invitation for the Tasmanian Government to be represented in the delegation subject to the conditions which normally apply to State representatives on Australian Government delegations.

That is an important recognition by the Government that in its responsibility as a state party to the convention it must have regard also to its character as a federal state. Although it does not go as far as the umbrella prospects of the Canadian situation it at least goes to the extent of including a representative of the State concerned on the delegation. The statement is very important. It is one upon which the Government should be congratulated. The Government indicates in the statement:
The Government in its discussion with the Tasmanian Government will make it clear that it will back its concern for these features with money, manpower and technical resources.

I turn to the second reason why I congratulate the Government on this statement. It is timely because a blockade has been organised in South West Tasmania for next Tuesday. The organisers of the blockade ought to understand that democracy has spoken.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion 'That the Senate take note of the statement' moved by the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) on behalf of Mr McVeigh, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment on the subject of South West Tasmania. I indicated prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner that the statement was both constitutionally proper and timely. I indicated that the statement had promised continued co-operation with the Tasmanian Government in the future planning and management of the area. I indicated that the statement was constitutionally proper in that it recognised implicitly the right and the responsibility of the Tasmanian Parliament to make decisions in respect of the area.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tasmanian Parliament has done so. After exhaustive examination and exhaustive deliberation both the House of Assembly and the Legislative Council came to a conclusion, as I said prior to the suspension of the sitting, by a vote of 51 out of 54 parliamentarians in that State. Only three parliamentarians voted against the proposal in respect of the development project which, incidentally, affects only 1.7 per cent of the whole of the area which is being nominated by the Australian Government to the World Heritage Committee.

Let me now turn to the reason I believe that the Minister's statement is timely . On Tuesday next a blockade is to be mounted in the South West against work that has been commenced pursuant to the democratic decision taken in the Tasmanian Parliament. That blockade is a calculated attempt to defy the law and to confront the police in the hope that when arrests are made publicity will follow. Just to make doubly sure that this publicity will follow, the blockade organisers have arranged for light aircraft and helicopters to ferry journalists from one confrontation scene to another. When all the photographs have been taken, those involved in the blockade will claim that they have been provoked. Only gullible people will swallow that.

The organisers of the blockade know very well that they have lost the argument now both in Tasmania, in the Tasmanian Parliament, and in Canberra. In their book this is only a minor irritation. They have not accepted the democratic decision taken pursuant to the constitutional rights and responsibilities of the State and taken pursuant to the responsibilities of the Federal Government. The Tasmanian law which the blockade organisers hope to get their supporters to confront involves a penalty of $100. It becomes relevant only when a person has been arrested as a result of that person's refusal a request to leave a designated area. The consequent arrests will achieve the objective that they desire and when that occurs they will cry foul. Let us contrast the $100 penalty , if we can, against the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill which has been introduced into the Senate by the Australian Democrats, ostensibly to 'save ' South West Tasmania. That Bill could have people landed in gaol for an indefinite period at a judge's discretion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like anybody who breaks the law.

—I am sorry; the blockade organisers who seek to break the Tasmanian law know what the penalty is. The penalty is a mere $100. They are after the publicity and they are wanting that to cry foul. The measure that the Australian Democrats have brought into this chamber is a draconian measure, with no penalty except the ultimate penalty of contempt of court which has, as the penalty, a period of imprisonment at the pleasure of a judge.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not one to deny people their opportunities for civil disobedience. But civil disobedience within a democracy is warranted only when all reasonable or legal avenues have been exhausted and the matter involved remains such a grave issue that a person's formed conscience dictates non-compliance when he or she is forced to act or not to act. Calculated defiance in the form of the publicity -seeking blockade is many steps removed from this concept of civil disobedience.

Politically motivated confrontation fractures the democratic processes. What those who promote it are really saying is: 'Forget about ballot boxes, elections , parliamentary representatives. We will take time off from being citizens of this democracy. We will opt out on this occasion and propose to take our own solutions'. That is why these people are mounting the blockade on Tuesday of next week. Such people are very far removed from the necessity of balancing conflicting demands and the responsibility of providing for adequate economic growth and employment opportunities. That responsibility devolves upon us all, but in particular it devolves and devolved upon the elected Parliament of the State of Tasmania. This statement clearly indicates that the decision of the Tasmanian Premier received the backing of legislation. That is a very important point which should not be forgotten in this debate; that 51 out of Tasmania's 54 politicians of all political persuasions voted in favour of that proposition. In the ideal democratic system, decisions should be made by a legitimate authority standing in the closest proximity possible to the people, to those people who will be affected by those decisions.

What I have to say to the people of Tasmania and particularly to the people of the West Coast of Tasmania, about whom fears have been expressed, I consider they already know. Let the blockade be seen for what it is-a deliberate defiance of the democratic process. There is no need to assist organisers in seeking publicity. If I were them I would just make sure that those taking part are charged full price for meals, accommodation and travel. In that way, in the short terms at least, the blockade organisers may contribute something to the economy of Tasmania. When they have disappeared from the scene, Tasmanians and their elected representatives can get on with the real task of running Tasmania. I believe the statement made by the Minister today deserves commendation. It states, and I agree:

Confrontation between the Commonwealth and the States and between individuals in the community is not the road to prosperity, development or the conservation of our heritage. The Government believes, on balance, that its decision is the right one and seeks from the community support in its continuing discussions with the Tasmanian Government. Finally, Mr McVeigh joins with the Premier of Tasmania in exhorting those who oppose the construction of the dam not to physically interfere with construction works. Mr McVeigh makes the comment that he abhors violence as I am sure do all in this Senate. Nothing can be gained from violent confrontation.

I could not possibly conceive of a more apt or more timely statement at this time. Not only is it apt and timely having regard to the possibilities of next Tuesday, but also it is constitutionally proper recognising the existence of the Tasmanian Parliament, recognising the responsibility-as it does implicitly-of that Parliament in respect of the matter and recognising the true meaning of democracy within our Federal system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the statement put down by the Government. I also support the Tasmanian senators in their fight to preserve Tasmania from excessive Federal interference. Indeed, the Government has recognised, quite clearly, what its responsibilities and its rights are. That is the reason for this statement today. Senator Button and Senator Ryan, and, to some extent, Senator Coates, have all been taken aback by the clear Government statement which recognised all of the realities that are inherent in the struggle between those in Tasmania who wish State rights and for the Tasmanian Government to control its own affairs and those from outside who wish to impose their will on the Government and people of Tasmania. If Senator Button had really believed his argument about power costs in Tasmania, if he was prepared to follow the logic of this argument to its conclusion, he would go all out for a small nuclear power station using Australian uranium right in the centre of Tasmania. But it is strange; Senator Button is not prepared to consider this logic or to carry it to its conclusion because the political consequences within his own party may be just a bit severe at the moment. It is easy for him to talk about national economic responsibility because we would have to say, if the result in Flinders is any indication and probably other results in time to come are any indication, that he will never have any personal responsibility for ever exercising any national economic responsibility.
—Don't kid yourself.

—I am not kidding myself, Senator. I have coined a new disease to illustrate the problem that Opposition senators have at the moment-it is called 'Flindersitis'. The Labor Party will take a long while to get over it. It is a curious disease because it actually helps us and makes us feel rather better about things that the Opposition has been trying to tell us are wrong. However, I must not be diverted. I can see that the Deputy President is starting to eye me with anxiety so I will come back to the matter before the Chair. Senator Mason's colleague Senator Chipp regaled the Senate with more howls of rage and massive alliteration. He was in deep shock, dismay, devastation and disappointment at the decision. To us it is a sort of a D-day for the Democrats.

—Yes, he did say that. I recollect that he also said 'diabolical' . That is massive alliteration which proves absolutely nothing. The Commonwealth will not interfere with Tasmania' s essential decision.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chipp also said that a huge area in Tasmania was to be covered with water. I gathered the impression that Tasmania was about to sink under the flood of water that was going to be released by the Tasmanian Government aided by the Commonwealth Government. I can tolerate alliteration but exaggeration has really no place here at all. We are delighted, therefore, in the triumph of State rights.

I think it is fair to say that Australia will be in good repute in the world because in making this decision we have not been stampeded by a bunch of irresponsible greenies into destroying State rights and State sovereignty. Just imagine, if this greenie nonsense was accepted by this Government nobody in the world would listen or speak to any State Premier; the States would be absolutely destroyed in their own right if this sort of thing were accepted by this Parliament and the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —They must protect a principle.

—There is no doubt that the Government has upheld the principle of State rights magnificently in this statement. I thank Senator Kilgariff for his assistance because it is quite plain that in previous debates he has appreciated the importance of State rights.

SPEECH.PARA: My friend Senator Missen, who sits alongside me, drew attention to the fact that I had laughed. I do not often giggle in this place. I am tempted to laugh more than I am to giggle about many things, most of which occur on the other side of the aisle. But Senator Missen told us that he was adopting a fairly high profile. I do not think it would be uncharitable to say that if I had laughed at that I was entitled to laugh because the high profile left me plenty to laugh at .

I listen to Tasmanian senators first on Tasmanian issues. I listened with interest to what Senator Coates had to say. I listened to him more attentively than I did to other honourable senators because he lives in Tasmania. I might disagree with his conclusions but I think that he has much more right to speak on these matters than I or anyone else who does not come from Tasmania. I think it is clear that I am interested in State rights. I have a very strong attachment to those rights, I do not want them minimised and I feel compelled to say something when these rights are threatened. I appeal to Tasmanians not to be upset by those outside Tasmania who have concocted what I describe as a greenie stew-a stew that is liberally sprinkled, has Labor vegetables and is heated over a Chipp fire.

I think what has happened, as a result of the Government's statement, is that this whole ghastly mess, which was boiled on the Chipp fire, is now overflowing the pot. I hope it puts the fire out, because it is a stupid and irresponsible fire. If that happens it will put out of the Parliament something that we will be glad to see put out. Senator Chipp submitted a hit list, if you like, of government members in various States who would be targets for the greenies in those States. All I can say to anyone who has been threatened by Senator Chipp is: 'Do not worry about it'. I have been threatened plenty of times and somehow or other it has not had a permanent effect. Who is to say-my time might come-but my advice to anybody who wants to stand up to these people is: 'Stand up to them and you will probably be a hero in your own electorate and have a far better chance of being returned than if you give in to this sort of pressure, engineered from outside the electorate'.

I am indebted once again to Senator Walters for speaking out so soundly and strongly for Tasmania. She made the important point that when Tasmania was controlled by a Labor Government the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made a decision not to interfere in Tasmanian affairs. Thus, the Government is being perfectly consistent in its attitude. It will not interfere now that Tasmania is controlled by a good government either. In my opinion, Premier Gray ought to be the toast of every State. He made a tough decision in the face of well organised but nonetheless illogical and in some ways dishonest opponents. Senator Harradine has alluded to the sort of dishonesty practised by this irresponsible mob. Premier Gray has spoken, as has the Commonwealth, with common sense and rationality for the real people of Tasmania, who know that the dam is essential to their future economic well-being. I support the Government's statement as representing basic principle and political common sense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had no intention of speaking in this debate. I had hoped to speak in a cognate debate on this matter and on the Bill which is being brought forward by Senator Mason and the Australian Democrats. I wish first to contradict the statement by Senator Walters this afternoon that this matter was being debated now rather than with the legislation to which I have referred because the Opposition, and in particular the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats, wanted to take over the business of this place.
