Indeed, it would have been sensible to debate the issues together. Instead, we are debating the statement put down today in the other place by Mr McVeigh, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, and in this place by Senator Peter Baume, the Minister for Education.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an important statement from both a Tasmanian, and a national, viewpoint . As such, I join with others in describing it as a very disappointing statement . As Senator Coates says, anyone who looks at this three-page document realises that it is a cut and paste job, that sentences have been whited out in haste, that the whole document was prepared in haste. It could not even be typed up properly for presentation to this House of Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your evidence for that?

—I invite the honourable senator to look at the document. Senator Martyr made what he thought was a very amusing speech, but I noticed that nobody laughed at his little jokes about fires stoked by Chipp and everything else.
—He didn't say that, did he?

—He cracked some terrible jokes, Senator Button. He made his little speech about States rights and people being consistent-this from Senator Martyr who has been in every party in this country except the National Party. As somebody said, the line has to be drawn somewhere.
—And the Communist Party. I haven't tried that yet, either.

—We do not know whether he is in the Communist Party; he has been in so many parties. He has been in the Australian Labor Party, the Democratic Labor Party and the Liberal Party, and I daresay the way he is going he will be in a few other parties before he is finished. So I do not really take any notice of what Senator Martyr said because this is not a matter for jest; it is a matter of very serious concern for Tasmanians, as all Tasmanians know. It is a matter which has divided Tasmanians as few issues have in the past. Yet all we get is a brief three page document which says that the Government believes that these national parks are very important places-something that is not agreed with by Senator Walters, by the way-and therefore they are being nominated to go on the World Heritage List. At the same time, the Government is saying that we will flood this most crucial section of that wilderness area with the hydro-electric scheme because it believes it is a matter of States rights.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue has provoked emotional debate on both sides of this chamber for three or four years. I suggest to honourable senators that most of the emotion in the debate in this place has come from that very colourful speech by Senator Walters last Thursday night and that very colourful speech by Senator Harradine last night which were barely balanced by Senator Chipp's contribution today. I wish initially to take up a couple of the points raised by Senator Walters. Senator Walters said that the decision to nominate these areas for the World Heritage List was Doug Lowe's decision-nobody else's, just Doug Lowe's. The facts of the matter are that the proclamation of the Franklin Rivers-Lower Gordon Wild Rivers National Park was an Executive Council decision in Tasmania and the decision to put forward the Wild Rivers and the Lake St Clair national parks to the Commonwealth Government for nomination for the World Heritage List was initially made by the Tasmanian Cabinet. It was confirmed by the Tasmanian parliamentary party.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party.

—I am sorry; the Tasmanian parliamentary Labor Party, which was then in government. The decision was not Doug Lowe's alone; it was a decision of the legally elected Tasmanian Government. The decision has been carried out by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and one assumes the Cabinet and Executive Council of this parliament. It is important to remember that and it is important to remember that Senator Walters's claim-Senator Harradine also made this claim by interjection one night-that one person made this decision is nonsensical. Senator Walters went on at considerable length about what she saw as the danger of violence, about what she described as mob rule in the blockade which is allegedly going ahead next week in the area of the dam construction site. Mr Gray, the Premier of Tasmania, has frequently made reference to mob rule and has talked about having to spend $15,000 a week to prevent this blockade, about sending in helicopters, about gaoling people and continually about violence in the area.
—And he wants the Federal Police in.

—The Acting Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, has now offered to send Federal Police into the area, although he says it is not a Commonwealth responsibility. All the provocative talk about violence and nonsense of this type in this area has come from that quarter. It has not come from those who oppose the construction of this dam. It has not come certainly from the Australian Labor Party or, as far as I understand, from the Australian Democrats in this place.
—What is a blockade if it is not provocation?

—Let us talk about a blockade, as Senator Harradine has brought it up. As it happens, I would prefer that we had a protest there that was not of the blockade type and did not involve breaking the law. But it makes me laugh to hear Senator Harradine and, for that matter, Senator Martyr get in here and talk about democratic rights and the breaking of democracy by people who do that. Has Senator Harradine ever got up here and complained about people who blockade clinics in Victoria which are conducted legally under the laws of the Victorian Government? Did Senator Harradine complain when a group of ladies-I agreed with their right to do so-blockaded the offices in Hobart of a member of this Parliament? They did so, as was their right, to demonstrate their disagreement with that parliamentarian's views. The people in Victoria who blockade Dr Wainer 's clinic, wherever it is, and abuse people who go in and out, are blockading an establishment which is set up legally under the laws of Victoria, and we hear no complaints from Senator Harradine. His complaint is very selective. His arguments about blockades are very selective.
—That is not so.
—Senator Harradine will support the blockades which suit his arguments--
—So do you.

—And he will oppose blockades that do not do so. I inform Senator Martyr that I would prefer the demonstration at the dam site not to be of the blockade type, not to break any laws. I just get sick of the sort of hypocrisy that we hear from Senator Martyr and other people in this place about this sort of nonsense.
—That is totally unfair. You know that the Victorian situation is quite different.

—The Victorian situation is analagous in this way: What is happening there is legal, whether Senator Harradine likes it or not, but because he does not like the laws he accepts the blockade. Let us not quibble about it. That is the situation, and that is the attitude that Senator Harradine takes. Let us not hear all this piety and pompous nonsense that Senator Harradine goes on with in this place. I take up the point taken up by Senator Button, because this is a serious problem about national responsibility, national economic responsibility, and national responsibility for conservation and heritage. It is terribly important to Tasmania. I point out, as have others, that the Tasmanian senators in this place happen to be equally divided on this question. It is not, as Senator Martyr says, that all of the Tasmanian senators are on one side and every other honourable senator is on the other side. The Tasmanian senators happen to be equally divided. It is a very important issue. It is an important issue for Tasmania and an important issue for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I take up the point made by Senator Walters earlier. It is a terribly important issue. What we are indulging in here is the construction, at a very large cost, of a dam in Tasmania to produce, I think, 183 megawatts of power. It will be a very small power station at a very high cost. Senator Walters and others have assured as here that we need this power to attract industries to the State and that those industries will employ people. I have asked Senator Walters, by interjection tonight, I have asked Mr Gray, the Premier of Tasmania, and I have asked many other people in Tasmania over the last five years: What are those industries and from where will they come? The answer is as deafening a silence as there is here now. Senator Walters claimed that Mr Lowe had said that he had had to deny industries access to Tasmania because there was no power. In fact the problem was that some industries already present in Tasmania wanted to increase their power consumption and at that time there was not enough because of the delay in the construction of the Pieman scheme. At that time there was no suggestion that a horde of industries was coming to Tasmania because they wanted our power. If there had been, we should not be building a power station of 183 megawatts; we should be building a reasonably sized power station of 400 or 500 megawatts-not fiddling around with a small station like this.

If what we need to progress in Tasmania is massive industrialisation, I would point out that I have never heard anyone on the other side say what that massive industrialisation would be. I have never heard anyone name one industry that would want to come to Tasmania. There are no such industries and yet the Government is asking us on faith to go ahead with this project. There are alternative hydro-electricity projects in Tasmania which will employ the work force of the Hydro-Electric Commission which I am concerned about and which every Tasmanian senator is concerned about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jobs are the issue.

—Jobs are the issue, as Senator Tate says tonight, and as he said the other night. But we are concerned about jobs that present a permanent future for my children and everbody else's children in Tasmania.
—You say that you are but your actions do not support it.

—Senator Martyr, who says that we all should listen to the Tasmanian senators on this issue and who comes from as far away from Tasmania as one can in this country, has more to say than anyone else on the grounds of States' rights. He says that we must let the States do what they like. As a Tasmanian senator, it is on this matter that I am concerned, and more concerned than anyone else. The problem which faces this country is that if we go ahead with six States and a couple of Territories competing for overseas markets and for industries the way we are over this, we will inevitably end up selling what we have at the lowest possible price and not at the highest possible price. In doing so we will end up doing the wrong thing by the citizens of each of those States. In any such war-be it a tax war or an industrial war-with competition between the States in this country and without the national interest being put first, Tasmania will lose out. Tasmania will lose out because of its small population. It will lose out because of the barrier that Bass Strait presents with respect to transport costs and everything else. Tasmania inevitably will lose out in such a battle.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought federation was about protecting the far-flung corners of our country. I thought it was about ensuring that places such as Tasmania with great disadvantages-disadvantages which until recently made Western Australia a claimant State-were protected and letting them overcome their disadvantages. But if we proceed with this States' rights nonsense that we have heard in this place in the last couple of weeks, the losers inevitably will be the smaller States such as Tasmania which have their disadvantages.

It is very easy in a small State like ours to take the populist view. It is very easy to get up like Senator Walters and others and say: 'My concern is for the people of Tasmania. That is what they have said. That is what the majority of them seem to be saying at the moment and I will go along with that, rightly or wrongly'. But a responsible representative of Tasmania in this Parliament should sit back, look at the facts, look at the long term prospects and forget the short term prospect of whether they will be re-elected. He should forget the threats that have been made to me through Senator Walters in recent days and look at what is best not only for Tasmania but also for Australia, because Tasmania's success and prosperity depend upon this country's prosperity. If we are to proceed the way we are in reproducing the shambles that the Ord River Scheme in Western Australia represents, if we are to cast the burden of this sort of scheme on to our children when at the moment we have no prospect of reasonable industries to pay for the power that will be produced by this scheme, we are not performing our duties as parliamentarians representing Tasmania and we are not performing our duties as representatives of the Australian nation in the Senate, in the House of Representatives or anywhere else.

Senator Harradine said that this statement is timely. It certainly is. It appears four days after a by-election in which the Liberal Party promoted its candidate as a 'No dams' candidate with central office funds. As someone said, there is no reason why this statement could not have come out last week or the week before. But it is a very timely statement organised around the Flinders by- election. It is also a timely statement, as Senator Harradine said, because it comes out just before the protests which will be conducted in Tasmania. Like the other statements which have been made by Mr Gray and others, it is a statement which feeds the sort of fire which Senator Harradine wants to see occur there. It also occurs just before the hypocritical nomination of these national parks for the World Heritage List. It is very timely. It is the most hypocritical timing of any statement which has ever come down in this place.

I repeat that this is a terribly emotional issue as well as a terribly difficult one for Tasmanians. What we have to decide in Tasmania and in the rest of Australia is whether the construction of this dam at the extraordinary cost which will eventually fall on the Tasmanian community for years and years to come and the 180 megawatts of power that it will produce are justified, Senator Walters told us that industries will flood in to use this 180 megawatts, a tiny amount of power--

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that at all.

—If we are not building it for that reason, for what reason are we building it? Why are we not building a dam on the King River to produce 60 megawatts? That would supply the power which is needed for Tasmania in the foreseeable future and would employ those hydro-electric employees whom I am concerned about-whether the honourable senator believes it or not-as much as anyone else. If people are waiting to use these vast amounts of power, why are we not building, say, a much bigger thermal power station in the Fingal Valley, for less? Why are we not even considering it? We are not considering it because some very stubborn people over the last few years have managed to convince themselves and others in Tasmania that somehow the proposed dam will solve all our problems. Those problems include unemployment that will soon reach 14 per cent, and the honourable senator knows it. Our problems are labour shedding all over the State, not because of a lack of power but because of the other disadvantages that we have. We face these problems because our kids cannot get jobs and have to leave the State. Is Senator Walters seriously suggesting, as is being suggested in Tasmania, that the solution to that problem is to build this dam at a huge cost for a small amount of power?

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania and the evidence of the Hydro-Electric Commission show that the projections for power needs in the future are very uncertain. At the highest projections they involve the industries that Senator Walters cannot tell us about, that Mr Gray cannot tell us about, that no one can tell us about. All the Senate Committee said was that we could wait three years and sort out the economic, ecological, conservationist and archaeological problems which face us in this area. But no; just after an election when the Liberal candidate said that he would save the Franklin and just before we nominate this area to a world body we get a statement which, amongst other things, says:

I am aware that whilst Fraser Cave and other caves of archaeological significance will be flooded by the dam, let me assure the House that every endeavour will be made to preserve this important part of our heritage.

No one on the other side has been able to explain that paragraph because it is nonsense, as are so many other paragraphs in the statement. We have guarantees that the Federal Government will consult with the State Government to make sure that only minimal damage is done to the area. What in heaven's name does that mean? We are talking about a massive expenditure. We are talking about the nomination of a very important area to the World Heritage List. We are talking about an economic problem which faces Tasmania and which potentially could land my children and your children, Senator Walters, with an interest burden for years and years to come. If they cannot pay it, the Federal Government will have to pay. All we get is three pages of cut and paste, as Senator Coates said. All we get is three pages of paragraphs which are confused and which, as Senator Button said, in many places are barely literate and give no justification for this decision at all, apart from the fact that the Federal Government believes that it is a matter of States rights. How the hell is it States rights if the Federal Government is nominating the area for inclusion on the World Heritage List? How is it only a State matter if the Federal Government is sending the Australian Federal Police to the area? How is it only a State matter if the Federal Government admits in this statement that in the past it was concerned about the area, was willing to fund the investigation of the area and is willing in the future to join with the Tasmanian Government to make sure that the area is not badly or seriously damaged?

I suggest, despite all that has gone on in this place in the last two weeks and all that has gone on in Tasmania and in this country in the last few years, we have not investigated this matter properly. I suggest that the import of the Senate Select Committee's report is that we do not really know what the power projections are. We do not really know what sorts of needs Tasmania will have in the future. We do not know what sorts of industries this dam will allegedly attract to Tasmania. But what is worse is what we are saying to the Hydro- Electric Commission workers in Tasmania, 700 of whom sent cuttings from a paper to me via Senator Walters, which I think is a very significant indication of who directed that little operation. We are saying to them: 'If you build this dam your jobs will be safe for life'. That is nonsense because we have no guarantee that the power that is produced from this dam will result in jobs for Tasmanians in the future. In fact, the indications of recent years are that it will not. We have no indication, based on long term planning, of what the Hydro-Electric Commission's plans are after the construction of this dam. Will we continue to build dams on the grounds that we will have to keep someone employed just building dams?

This is a serious question not only for Tasmanians, who are in dire economic straits at the moment, but also for the people who will follow us in Tasmania and who will have to bear the burden of this cost. All we got was a three-page statement which tells us nothing. The statement told us that before the Professor Slatyer left Australia this morning he was told that when he arrives in Paris he will have to tell the World Heritage Commission that despite the fact that we want the South West Tasmania area included in the World Heritage List we will build the dam anyway. This occurred on the day he left. We are not doing the right thing by Tasmanians, by Australia and certainly by the delegation which we have sent to Paris. I hope that in the future we can have a sensible debate on this issue. But we cannot do so when all we have to debate is a document such as this and while we refuse to debate the report brought down by a select committee of this Senate. I believe we will probably ignore the report this session and next session, as Senator Missen said, because the facts contained in it and the results of the inquiry are uncomfortable for the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable senator claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—The honourable senator may proceed under Standing Order 410. He cannot debate the subject.

—Senator Grimes, who has just resumed his seat, stated that I was hypocritical in that I had urged the organisers of the blockade to be held on Tuesday of next week to call off the blockade when, according to Senator Grimes, I am a supporter of the blockading of abortion clinics in Victoria.
—I didn't say that. I said you never protested against them.

—Or that I never protested against them. Although I regard the right to life of a human being as most precious I do not, nor have I ever, approved of the Victorian tactic of the physical confrontation involved in a blockading of an abortion clinic in that State. Also, I understand that this tactic is not approved of by the official Federation of Right to Life Associations in Australia. If Senator Grimes had any decency he would recognise that and apologise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. It seems that Senator Chipp recognised that I can say in five minutes what he says in five hours. First of all, I refer to two fundamental points.
—What is the position--
—Do I hear a gurgle from the gutter of the one-man slum on my right?
—Order, Senator Crichton-Browne!
—Yes, you do.

—Senator Walsh is attempting to call out again. Senator Grimes made some observations about the responsibility of the State governments. I wish that he would state categorically, as a matter of fact and as a matter of course, for the record what he sees as the constitutional rights of the State governments and of the Commonwealth. I ask him: What are their rights and responsibilities? When does he see it necessary to impinge upon the rights of the State governments and when does he consider that they might have some meagre competence to deal in some facile way with trivia that he sees as being comparable with what they are able to do? When does he imagine that the Federal Government has some superior knowledge, capacity, competence and wisdom which imposes itself well above that of a State government? I often think to my--
—Have you ever had a look at Ray O'Connor?
—Again, I hear the gurgle from the gutter. It is interesting--
—Order! The honourable senator will withdraw that remark.

—Without qualifications, Mr Deputy President, I withdraw that remark, unlike the man on the other side who is now breaking into hysteria because for the first time he has seen me withdraw something I said against him.
—Order! The honourable senator will address himself to the subject before the Chair.

—Senator Button raised the question of why a number of honourable senators from Tasmania voted the way they did. I do not know to whom he was referring. In the unlikely event that he was referring to any Liberals I should think that they would have made their judgments on the basis of pragmatic , intelligent, in-depth, personal conscience decisions which they would have arrived at as a result of considering everything placed before them. There is a distinction between that and what honourable senators on the other side do; they simply put their hands up like one-armed puppets. If a member of the Australian Labor Party does not support the ALP, of course that member is expelled. It is axiomatic; it is automatic. That is the real distinction. The sad fact of life in respect of this matter is that, while I do not for a moment presume to make judgments as to why, how, when, where or whether ALP senators from Tasmania made their determinations in the Caucus, one thing I do know is that they are committed and compelled to support the point of view to which 51 per cent of the voters of the Caucus has agreed.
—That is democratic.

—It is terribly democratic, Senator Tate said. It is not without significance to note that the Caucus is not made up simply of members of the Senate; it is made up of members of the Senate and the House of Representatives. The facts of the matter are that the ALP does not hold one single House of Representatives seat for Tasmania.
—Go back to school.

—Senator Siddons says that I should go back to school. I would be delighted to indulge in a debate with him any time he wants about making two and two come to five in terms of protection. The facts of the matter are that in ALP caucusing no ALP member of the House of Representatives has a voice because the ALP does not have a member in the House of Representatives. The majority of the Caucus votes in respect of this matter-ALP members are compelled to adopt Caucus decisions and risk expulsion if they cross the floor- were cast by people on the mainland.
—New South Wales.
—Senator Harradine said 'New South Wales'. New South Wales and Victoria alone have more seats than all the other States combined. If one happens to be, by the grace of God, blessed--
—Careful, Senator. There is nothing wrong with New South Wales.

—There is nothing wrong with New South Wales if you are a Liberal. If one happens to come from Western Australia, or a smaller State such as Tasmania, in the caucusing and the machinations of the ALP one is immediately cast aside as an inconsequential, modest little number who really does not matter. To answer Senator Button's question, the reason that we have made this decision is that the mainland States, through votes in the House of Representatives have cast themselves in a direction which could be in contradiction of the convictions of the hearts, minds, souls, consciences and the ultimate direction of the people who represent Tasmania in this Parliament. That is exactly the reason we are where we are right now. It is interesting that --
—A good note to end on.

—I think it is a brilliant start, but I appreciate Senator Chipp's comment. It is interesting that the mainland States seek to make judgments about the welfare, and the economic future of the people of Tasmania. It is interesting that more than anyone else in this final debate, in the final conclusions and determinations and decisions, it will be the people of Tasmania- -
—Oh!

—I thought I heard somebody from Western Australia pass a crude comment. Was it Senator Walsh? Let him own up if it was. If it was not, I suggest that he close his mouth next time he grunts. It is the people of the mainland who are directing the course of the future economic, social and environmental considerations of the people in Tasmania. The economy of Tasmania is in no brilliant state at present, thanks to a number of Australian Labor Party governments over a number of years. As I understand it, from the recent statistics that I have been able to observe, unemployment in Tasmania is running at something like 11.8 per cent. No doubt that will fall away with the implementation of the Liberal Government's policies into the community. In the meantime that is a fact of life and it has to be accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: One ought to look for a moment at how this electricity, this energy, this new drive, this new capacity for development will be used. Seventy per cent of this new electricity will be supplied to domestic, commercial and light industry; 30 per cent will be supplied to major industries. It is interesting that at present something like 70 per cent of employers in Australia are in small business. That is where Tasmania, if anybody, can surely take some advantage of this proposal and look-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the argument of the pro-dam lobby. Its argument is big business, big industrial users.

—With respect, I do not know how Senator Tate draws the distinction between the pro-dam and anti-dam lobbies. There are those of us who simply just look at this proposal on the basis of what will be the best thing for Tasmania and ultimately what will be the best thing for Australia. As I sit here and listen to those people from Victoria, the altruistic, clear-minded, clear-headed people who want no dams in Tasmania, I wonder where they would stand or how they would feel if suddenly all the coal were closed off for reasons which might be compatible with their short term philosophic views about what is good and what is bad for the environment of Australia. I wonder what would happen in South Australia if suddenly the Cooper Basin happened to fall within a certain environmental structure and no longer could they have the natural gas or what looks like being a very exciting oil prospect. If everything else I have said so far has been abstract I know one thing for sure: If in Western Australia anyone tried to stop our iron ore, our bauxite, our alumina, our uranium, our natural gas or our oil, there would be grave indignation. There would be protestations which could not be exceeded because they are the sorts of things which make us the powerful powerhouse of the economy of Australia. They are the sorts of things which cause us to be responsible for 20 per cent of Australia's exports, notwithstanding the fact that we have only 8.7 per cent of the total population of Australia. It is interesting how other people, sitting home very comfortably in their own environment, can make judgments about one State. It is almost as if the have-nots are competing with the haves. It is almost as if those in certain positions in certain areas of influence who do not have to risk their jobs, who do not have to worry about their future and their families' futures, can sit in whatever electorate it is on the mainland of Australia and suddenly decide that somebody else's job, somebody else's future, somebody else's children's future is not terribly important as long as they can row down that river that nobody ever goes to. I must exclude Senator Chipp from that statement. I think he broke an arm cruising down the river, tranquilly discovering how pleasant it is.
—I can think of better ways of breaking an arm.
—When you are big enough you will be too old, my friend.
—A knuckle job.
—The honourable senator says a knuckle job. Would he like it behind the toilet or behind Parliament House?
—Order!

—The Tasmanian Government presumably has looked at all the options. Presumably it considered coal, a Bass Strait link, nuclear energy, solar energy, wind power and every other option. A good State government would want to be liked, respected and voted for. Presumably it gave all these matters consideration before it arrived at the ultimate determination. Having drawn the final conclusions together, the Tasmanian Government decided what it needed to do for the people of Tasmania. I think any State government that did not put its people first would be derelict in its duty and should not be supported. It is not without significance to note that in the Tasmanian Parliament, as I understand it, only three of the 54 members of the two Houses voted against the present proposals of the Tasmanian Government.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it also, two successive governments of totally different persuasions-a Liberal Party government and a Labor Party government-have taken the same view. Both governments, in my view, showed impeccable judgment, courage , integrity and responsibility for their constituents. Nobody has argued against that except a monolithic group of giants on the opposite side of this chamber who seem to have the belief that all wisdom resides in this building, as I said before, and that everybody on that side knows more than anyone else in any State of Australia. Suddenly, everybody on the opposite side has decided that it is terribly important that decisions be made under the roof of this Parliament. It is my view that the judgment that has been made is one of compassion, understanding, wisdom, knowledge, perception and sensitivity for the voters. If the people who made that judgment are wrong they will be removed at the next election. Inasmuch as both parties have been courageous enough to make a determination, they have drawn the same conclusion-that this dam is in the best interests of Tasmanians. I move on briefly to the Federal Government's determination in respect of the statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you give us a rough idea of how much longer you will be? You said you would be brief.
—You spoke for half an hour. I interrupted you not once.
—Senator Crichton-Browne, will you address the Chair, please.

—Mr Deputy President, I will give you the courtesy that has not been given by Senator Chipp all afternoon. The Federal Government has recognised the rights of the States to determine their own future. More importantly, it has recognised the constitutional responsibilities that rest with State governments--
—Not for long.

—Did I hear a member of the ALP say: 'Not for long'? Let it be recorded. The mineral rights and the resources of each State are, as a result of the Constitution-by statute and by right-intrinsically in the hands of the State governments. Under the proposals that have been put forward by the ALP and Australian Democrats those rights would be removed very quickly. I can only assume that the former Labor Government in Tasmania and the present Liberal Government there very carefully considered what would be in the best interests of that State before they made their ultimate determinations. It is difficult enough for the people of Tasmania being isolated in terms of distance, environment and transportation. Whenever it suits members of certain unions to go on strike Tasmanians cannot export and they no longer have access to imports. It simply takes a short strike to paralyse the capacity of that community to continue to function. One of the few advantages that Tasmania and a small number of other countries, such as New Zealand, have is the capacity to produce hydro- electric power. Tasmania has a capacity to produce electricity. One of the fundamental capacities required these days by manufacturing industry, whether it be at the first phase or the last phase, is the ability to produce low unit cost power. With hydro-electric power Tasmania will be able to attract major, minor and middle industries.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for those on this side of the ocean to make determinations that do not affect them. But I put it to those people that if they were in the situation in which Tasmanians find themselves where families are without jobs, without hope, without ambition and without immediate prospects the thought of some new projects or prospects would be very appealing. Notwithstanding the fact that it has been put to me by the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labour Party that there are votes in this for them at the next Federal election, I would have thought that Tasmanians would be more concerned about their future in terms of jobs and the social consequences which would flow from the construction of the dam.

I support the proposal. I find it regrettable and sad, to say the least, that there are those who, for their own altruistic, divorced reasons which are quite unrelated to the reality, the necessity, the need and the purpose of the dam, decide that it is better in the long run that they should have the pleasure of motoring up and down the Franklin River once in a million years rather than see people have jobs, prospects, hopes, aspirations and a chance of succeeding in life. As I recall, 11.8 per cent of the people of Tasmania are, at present without employment. I just wonder how they feel when Opposition senators stand up and say: 'We do not need dams. We are doing very nicely over here in the blue ribbon seats on the East Coast of Australia'. I wonder how people who cannot find a job feel about the prospect of cheap power and cheap electricity that will give them the chance of jobs, security and hope for their future and the future of their families.

As I have said from the outset, I support the concept of the statement. As I said I think a week ago, besides all the other considerations, the Federal Government's judgment in terms of this being a matter to be resolved by a State government as distinct from the Federal government is an impeccable judgment of States' rights. It goes back to the intrinsic principle which was expounded so often during the constitutional debates from 1893 right through to Federation when the division of powers was clearly and articulately drawn up between the States and the Commonwealth. At that time a decision was made as to who should have what powers. To use some surreptitious, insidious, external affairs power which has suddenly been found by accident in relation to some other matter as a reason to intervene in the way that is proposed by Senator Evans and others I think is an absolute prostitution of the Constitution. The use of such a power was never intended and should never be implemented. I admire the Federal Government for its courage, capacity and integrity for saying--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us again it is a States' House.
—Yes, of course this is a States' House.
—What nonsense!
—Well, I think it is. The honourable senator cannot afford to think it is. the reason he cannot is that if he crosses the floor because of his conscience he will get expelled. That is his problem.
—It is based on party lines and you go along with it.
—I do not.
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, you must address the Chair.
—With respect, I am doing my best.
—I am aware that the honourable senator is under pressure.

—I am not under pressure but rather bombardment by the over-noisy people on my immediate right. In my view, the Federal Government has shown courage in defining the clear distinction between Commonwealth rights and States' rights and, in the final analysis, has decided that this is a matter for a State government and not a Federal government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listeners to the parliamentary broadcast tonight may be unaware that, effectively, the Opposition-the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats-has taken the running of the business program of the Senate out of the hands of the Government, that it has brought on this debate despite the great deal of attention that has been given to this matter on previous occasions. I hope that as the Christmas recess draws near the Opposition will allow appropriate time for other matters that form part of the legislative program to be considered. They include many important matters and I hope that we begin to get all of our priorities right in regard to this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been doubt as to the propriety of the making of the initial application for consideration. Essentially, as far as we can make out, it was prompted very much by the decision of one man. There was no parliamentary debate concerning it. I believe that it has been difficult to find a cabinet minute which authorised the making of the application.

I believe that if earlier there had been good will and consideration of this matter by the Commonwealth we may not have been considering it tonight. However, the Tasmanian Government had to make a decision. It could not put the matter off indefinitely. Given the available resources, after examining comparative costs and benefits, it decided that a dam should be built. That was the Tasmanian Government's decision. One of the problems of Tasmania is that for too long decisions have been put off, and have not been made. Premier Gray is to be applauded for being prepared to take hard decisions and hard knocks. Australia would be far better off if other State governments were prepared to take hard decisions in a difficult environment.

There are in the community, and in the Parliament too, many people who would like to see a lot of the big power users in Tasmania-Comalco, Temco, and EZ- wiped out of Tasmania. But I ask honourable senators to think of the employment implications of such actions. The tragedy is that when many of these organisations-for instance, Comalco-came to Tasmania no inducement was offered that they set up rolling mills, which are big employers of labour. One of the difficulties over the years for instance associated with the tremendous hike in power prices, has been that many industries, upon wishing to change to electric boilers have been offered power at Bell Bay thermal power station rates and have had to decide against the change. Up to two years additional blocks of power were being offered, again on the basis of Bell Bay thermal power rates. These were not attractive for or conducive to expansion. As a result, some of the expansion that could have taken place in Tasmania was diverted to the mainland.

One of the tragedies that we face is that the difficulties arise not from present decisions but from those of even 12 months or two years ago. Many of the job opportunities that could have been present are not present for that reason and I believe that Premier Gray is trying to improve the business climate so that industry will again see an opportunity to set up undertakings or expand in Tasmania.

I believe that one of the tragedies of this debate is that some people have suggested-I mentioned this before-the siting of a thermal power station at Bell Bay. To put a thermal power station in the vicinity of Bell Bay would be a real tragedy because the Tamar has problems with fog. One has only to go to New South Wales or Queensland to see the disgusting sights of factories belching out polluting smoke. It would be a real tragedy if that were to take place in the pretty Tamar Valley in Tasmania. Tasmania certainly has the expertise in hydro- electric power generation. The civil engineers at the Hydro-Electric Commission are ranked, as far as hydro knowledge is concerned, second to none in the world. They have the expertise and it should be developed. There will be a continuing need for power and after this people will be asking: What next? Other rivers could be considered for future development. The point is that the power demand exists now.

I think that, under the circumstances, at this late stage the Commonwealth has made a very sensible compromise. Jobs are important. They are scarce in Tasmania and our Government in Tasmania has had to take a courageous decision. That decision was overwhelmingly backed by the parliamentarians of both the lower House and the upper House. It is a tragedy that there has been such a high level of interference from outside. People who are unaware of the terrain and the nature of the problems in Tasmania are trying to influence the situation, to the detriment of the people of Tasmania. I would like to see those people who are of a conservation bent do their utmost to try to make sure that we can blend the natural environment with the hydro-electric developmental plans. It is only a very small section of the Franklin River and, apart from a few caves, the majestic beauty of the river will be preserved. One of the tragedies of this whole debate has been the lack of honesty in the presentation of facts and I hope that over time the Tasmanian community will realise some of the falsity that has been spread on the mainland. It is a Tasmanian decision and Tasmanians will have to live with it. I support the Tasmanian Government in the hard decision it has had to make in very difficult times.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That Mr President be authorised to grant, at his discretion, access by Dr Sheila Shaver, of Macquarie University, to all or part of the evidence or documents taken in camera by, or submitted on a confidential or restricted basis to, the Joint Committee on Social Security of 1941-46, and to permit Dr Shaver to make copies of any such evidence or documents to which she is granted access.

In moving the motion, I briefly explain what it is about. It relates to a request for access by an academic researcher from Macquarie University of considerable reputation in the field of social policy who is writing on the history of social security legislation in Australia. She wants access to evidence that was taken in camera by a Joint Committee on Social Security in this Parliament in the period 1941-46. On the face of it, it is remarkably uncontroversial, since it was at least 36 years ago. The present Senate and House of Representatives Standing Orders, however, are such that no access to such material taken on a confidential basis at the time, however long ago, can be granted except by resolution of the Senate. In order to explain the procedures that relate to this matter, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an exchange of correspondence between myself and the President of the Senate, together with an extract from Hansard of 22 May 1980, which will lay down for the record what the rules are currently understood to be so far as access to such material is concerned.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA-THE SENATE
Office of Senator Gareth Evans
Commonwealth Parliament Offices 400 Flinders Street Melbourne, Victoria 3000 Telephone (03) 622 521
17 November 1982 GE:CM
Senator The Hon. H. W. Young,
President of the Senate,
Parliament House,
Canberra. A.C.T. 2600
Dear Mr President,

I have received correspondence from Dr Sheila Shaver in relation to her request for access to certain materials held by the Australian Archives arising from the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Social Security 1941-1946. I understand this matter has been under consideration by the Presiding Officers.

I would appreciate your advice as to any decision taken by the Presiding Officers in this matter. My own view is that all material of this kind should be in the public domain after the usual archival period of 30 years, subject, of course, to the usual exceptions.
In particular I would appreciate a response to the following questions:

1. Why did the resolution of the Senate of 22 May 1980, relating to the release of evidence and records of certain Senate and Joint Committees, specify no period of years after which evidence taken in camera by such a committee or submitted to it on a confidential or restricted basis might, with your permission, be examined by a person in accordance with the resolution?
2. In practice, is a specific time period applied to such evidence and if so what is that period?
3. If the period applied is greater than the usual archival period of 30 years, what is the reason for the difference?

4. Will you now permit the release of documents relating to evidence in camera and confidential reports to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Social Security 1941-1946, being documents all of which are now more than 30 years old?
Yours sincerely,
GARETH EVANS
Senator for Victoria
Shadow Attorney-General
President of The Senate
Parliament House Canberra
30 November 1982
Dear Senator Evans,

Thank you for your letter of 17 November 1982 in which you raise a number of questions concerning a request by Dr Sheila Shaver for access to in camera material held by the Australian Archives arising from the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Social Security 1941-46.

As a background to the questions you raise, I advise that the Australian Archives accepts material from the Senate and the House of Representatives on a ''for storage only'' basis and does not hold that material in a normal archival situation as it does for Executive Departments.

This arrangement exists because Senate Standing Order 308 and House of Representatives Standing Order 340 provide that evidence taken by any Select Committee of the Senate or the House of Representatives and documents presented to such Committee which have not been reported to the relevant House shall not, unless authorised by the relevant House or, in the case of the Senate, by the Committee, be disclosed or published by any member of such Committee or by any other person.

In response to your inquiry as to any decision taken by the Presiding Officers, I advise that an approach was made by Dr Shaver in November 1981 for access to material held by Archives from the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Social Security, 1941-46, and permission was granted. Dr Shaver recently made a further request to the Clerk of the House of Representatives for access to the in camera and confidential material held by the Australian Archives in respect of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Social Security and was advised that pursuant to the resolutions agreed to by the Senate and the House of Representatives on 22 May 1980, this in camera and confidential material was not available for purposes of research.
You asked four specific questions, the answers to which are as follows:
1. Question:

Why did the resolution of the Senate of 22 May 1980, relating to the release of evidence and records of certain Senate and Joint Committees, specify no period or years after which evidence taken in camera by such a committee or submitted to it on a confidential or restricted basis might, with your permission, be examined by a person in accordance with the resolution?
Answer:

The resolution agreed to by the Senate and the House of Representatives on 22 May 1980 has modified the operation of the two abovementioned Standing Orders to the extent that the President and/or the Speaker may authorise the release of evidence and records of Parliamentary Commitees which have been held for at least ten years under certain conditions. However, both Houses under the resolution specifically excluded evidence taken in camera or submitted on a confidential or restricted basis from this provision. As I understand it the resolution was considered by the Leaders and the Whips of both Houses and reflects the normal protection afforded to individual witnesses who appear before Parliamentary Committees.
2. Question:
In practice, is a specific time period applied to such evidence and if so what is that period?
Answer:
Unless the relevant House or Houses decide otherwise no in camera evidence may be released by the Presiding Officers, regardless of the passage of time.
3. Question:
If the period applied is greater than the usual archival period of thirty years , what is the reason for the difference?
Answer:
See answers to 1 and 2.
4. Question:

Will you now permit the release of documents relating to evidence in camera and confidential reports to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Social Security 1941-46 being documents all of which are now more than thirty years old?
Answer:

I am unable to permit the release of documents relating to evidence in camera and confidential reports to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Social Security 1941-46 unless the Senate and the House of Representatives agree to a resolution authorising the release of these documents.
Yours sincerely, HAROLD YOUNG President of the Senate
Senator Gareth Evans,
The Senate,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T 2600

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator EVANS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The particular material here is described by Dr Shaver as relating to the Chifley Government's attempt to establish a salaried health care system, including abortive negotiations at the time with the British Medical Association. Dr Shaver says that the material appears to have been restricted through simply the mechanical application of the provisions of the House and Senate resolutions on this subject and not to reflect any particular sensitivities. She also says that she gathers from extrinsic evidence that it appears that only a very small proportion of this information contains material about particular individuals. The largest part of it appears to be documentation of a kind which would be released for research use after 30 years without demur under the usual archival practice.

INTERJECT.PARA: I simply make the further point that questions as to the release of such material are clearly matters for Parliament rather than the Executive Government of the day because the Parliament is the custodian of material given in evidence to its committees. But I have agreed in discussions with the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), who has conduct of this crucially important matter for the Government, that it would not be inappropriate, in all the circumstances of the case, for us to have some vetting procedure just to ensure that there is no wildly defamatory material or something of that kind which might cause embarrassment, even after all this time, were it to gain release. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Government, I indicate my agreement with the course of action set out in Senator Evans's amended motion.
