DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to this Bill.
Debate resumed from 7 December, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: -When the Senate adjourned last night I was speaking to the National Crimes Commission Bill. I had looked at the purpose of the Bill as stated in the second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). I had indicated that I was not surprised, since the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, that the emphasis has now been upon organised crime. I had looked at the nature of organised crime , the types of criminals involved and the techniques and methods which they adopt. I had listed the large number of royal commissions which have indicated that not only is organised crime not being suppressed by conventional methods of law enforcement but also it appeared to be increasing. I had accepted the importance of finding an answer to organised crime and the assertions of Costigan that the unchecked operation of large scale criminal activity of the type described in his report can lead only to a breakdown in law and order and the eventual destruction of the society in which we live.

SPEECH.PARA: I then looked at the deficiencies of the current system in an effort to determine whether such deficiencies can be overcome by the provision of greater resources or whether twentieth century organised crime requires a new approach, a new methodology. I identified the deficiencies of jurisdictional limitations- that is, the restrictions in both geographical matters and in separate criminal codes. I identified the deficiency of a lack of powers. In the light of such deficiencies I then commenced to look at the advantages of the proposed National Crimes Commission, starting with the additional power born out of the experience of royal commissions-that of compelling evidence on oath at the time of investigation. That required a digression into whether the power was consistent with the protection of basic civil liberties. I stated that on the Bill which was presented to the Senate, as amended in the other place, I was reasonably satisfied on that aspect although there were several other matters which would be raised at the Committee stage. I had looked at the advantage of putting together interdisciplinary teams of experts to analyse information.

The third advantage to which I wish to refer is the potential for involving the eventual prosecuting counsel in the development of the case. This is, of course, possible within the existing system but demarcation as a result of practice and tradition has limited its use. In Australia we do not have the opportunity available in the United States of involving counsel at an earlier stage by virtue of its system of the use of grand juries.

The fourth advantage that I wish to point out to the Senate is that the Commission has the potential to look at organised crime from a national viewpoint. That, I believe, is particularly critical because criminals do not respect State boundaries. There is the additional advantage promoted on behalf of the National Crimes Commission that it would utilise a computer-based data management system, something which is essential to the efficient analysis of information. I must confess that I do not place great weight on that advantage because there is no reason why it cannot be as efficiently used and operated by the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. Therefore, I accept that the conventional law enforcement agencies are not adequately suppressing organised crime in Australia, that a new approach is necessary and that a National Crimes Commission has the potential to assist significantly in that regard.

The question then arises: How should it be structured and to whom should it be responsible? As most criminal law within Australia remains the province of the States it appears obvious to me that the full co-operation of the States is a pre-requisite to the success of a National Crimes Commission. Earlier this year we read of the Cabinet proposal. One of the media reports at that time said that the Cabinet proposal was to establish a 'Joint standing Commonwealth-State Crimes Commission with powers to police both Federal and State laws'. That appeared to me to make sense. What we have here, however, is a National Crimes Commission that is limited to breaches of Commonwealth law and corruption by Commonwealth officials. There are provisions for the States to come into the fold but they are meaningless unless the States are prepared to do so. It appears from various Press releases of the State police ministers that they are not prepared to do so.

Therefore, it appears to me that the body that we are setting up does not overcome the geographical or jurisdictional boundaries that are a major difficulty and disadvantage of the current system and should have been a major advantage of the new Commission. Where the breakdown occurred, I do not know. I read that the States said that the Commonwealth announced this new structure whilst negotiations were still taking place. But the breakdown does no credit to either the Commonwealth or the States because the most desirable structure is not being implemented. The States do not have a good record in co-operation and co-ordination in the areas of organised crime. In information gathering they have improved the position so that from 1979 the majority have set up criminal intelligence units. One commentator, C. Williams of the criminology department of the University of Melbourne, said:
There is only limited interaction between the State CIUs.

However, to give credit where it is due, in the last two years things appear to have changed. The Police Ministers Council has achieved the development of a number of national co-operative initiatives. In the criminal intelligence area it has set up the body that I mentioned a moment ago, the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. The Commonwealth Government Directory, when referring to the functions of that Bureau, states:

Facilitate the collection, collation, analysis and dissemination of criminal intelligence. Provide such intelligence to the Police Forces of the Commonwealth , the States and the Northern Territory to enable them to combat organised crime in Australia, particularly illicit drug trafficking.

That body commenced operation only this year. From one Press report I read, it seems that it is expected to focus on organised crime, which is familiar because it is really the subject of this debate, drug trafficking, illegal gambling and international organised crime. It is true that it was set up to provide intelligence to the State police forces and to the Australian Federal Police and the Northern Territory police force but it could provide such similar intelligence information to a joint Commonwealth-State crimes commission. I understand also from some of the Press reports that at the time of the termination of the Commonwealth-State negotiations that proposal was in fact being promoted by at least one of the States. The police Ministers point also to other initiatives such as the National Police Research Unit, the National Institute of Forensic Science, the upgrading and relocation of the Australian Police College, which is, of course, relevant because of Costigan's criticisms of police capabilities. They are achievements which are pointed to as having occurred in only the last two years.

Whereas I support the setting up of a national crimes commission, I am disappointed that it is not being set up as a Commonwealth-State body within the spirit of co-operative federalism which is necessary for it to be effective. So even at this late stage I would urge the Government to hold over this Bill and make a last ditch effort to negotiate a co-operative scheme with the States. If it is the view of the Commonwealth that it cannot negotiate anything better than is presently before the Senate, I would support the Bill because, for the reasons that I have indicated, I support the principle of a national crimes commission.

I would then urge the States to join in the Commonwealth Commission. I think that it is probably better to refer to it as a Commonwealth commission rather than a national commission, but I fear, on the basis of what I have read, that the States will not be willing to join. But even if they can be persuaded to join, which would make a new body far more satisfactory from my observations, a number of questions remain. For instance, what is to be the role of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence in relation to the Commission?

We have an obligation to avoid duplication and misdirection of resources. If we look at the proposed functions and charter of the new Crimes Commission and the functions of the ABCI, as I have just indicated to the Senate, already there is duplication. Why can the ABCI not act as the central bureau for criminal intelligence in a similar way to the body in Canada? Why can it not act as a repository for all criminal intelligence reports across the country, including those of the National Crimes Commission? We could then develop a national criminal information bank.

What is to be the role of the Australian Institute of Criminology? It is a joint venture of the Commonwealth and States in the systematic and co-ordinated organisation of criminology research. The National Crimes Commission is to have a function of making recommendations to government. But surely directions for government legislation and policy should be coming from the research of the AIC, yet it is in fact being downgraded. Its effective establishment is now only just over one-third of that approved in 1975. In my opinion, the proposed National Crimes Commission should concentrate itself as an investigative body of organised crime with a view to successful prosecutions. This would provide a deterrent and would be a worthwhile task for it, without it attempting to assume the responsibilities within the expertise of others.

There is no doubt that organised crime is facilitated by outdated criminal laws . Crime is political because we in fact define what is crime. Mr Justice Kirby, Chairman of the Australian Law Reform Commission, has stressed the need to relook at such sensitive and difficult issues as marihuana, prostitution, consenting homosexual conduct, gambling, liquor intake and indecent literature. I refer briefly to an article by Richard Hall which appeared in the Australian Financial Review in May 1982. He said:
As for SP betting, the next major corruption problem in New South Wales-
He was referring to after-drinking hours-
and probably throughout Australia, by now it is surely clear that a lot of punters would always want the choice of odds.
In an age where computers take rockets to Mars it should be possible for the State totalisator agency boards to devise a parallel system that can give punters odds when they phone up.

He is, of course, indicating that it is in many ways easy to remove, simply by legislation, a lot of the minor criminal activities upon which serious organised crime fosters. We also must not use the National Crimes Commission as an excuse not to keep upgrading or updating State and Federal police forces. Where limited resources are involved, as is always the case, this temptation must be avoided. We must work towards a national criminal code. When negotiations with the Commonwealth broke down, a spokesman for the Queensland Government said that Queensland would not support any body which could initiate prosecutions under Queensland law in Queensland courts. I find that type of statement quite frightening.

In conclusion, major organised crime must be identified and pursued on a national basis. There must be a body to determine priorities and to co-ordinate intelligence investigational activities. This must be the role of the new National Crimes Commission. It must not be that of a super sleuth force. Let us leave that to the existing law enforcement agencies and ensure that with proper resources they are lifted to that level. Let us find a way of making it a co- operative Commonwealth-State venture so that it has full opportunity to work effectively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main function of the National Crimes Commission Bill which we are discussing tonight, finally, is to establish a National Crimes Commission whose main function is to investigate organised crime and official corruption with a view to prosecution action where appropriate. It has a secondary function in that the Commission will be authorised to conduct investigations of a more general nature. To assist in both of those attributes the Bill gives the Commission important powers necessary to its function. The explanatory memorandum adds this rider to that:

SPEECH.PARA: However, these powers are made subject to appropriate safeguards to protect the rights of individuals.

Some concern has been expressed in reports from and by the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills that, in fact, the legislation does not go far enough to safeguard and to protect the rights of individuals in certain circumstances. I understand that most of the Australian Labor Party amendments set out to correct that as does the one amendment that the Australian Democrats have to the National Crimes Commission Bill. I will say more about that later.

It has been mentioned by previous speakers that there has been considerable concern in the community over the years that the traditional law enforcement agencies that we have in this country are, for one reason or another, not appropriate, not adequate, not sufficiently staffed or not sufficiently empowered to cope with the burgeoning criminal activities that are emerging in this country, particularly with regard to the sophistication and the organisation of these activites. I do not intend to list-they have been listed by others-the royal commissions and the reports from those commissions that have indicated this trend and have indicated that we need further, better or different investigatory bodies with wider powers than are presently available to the existing law enforcement agencies in this country.

In addition to those royal commission reports numerous newspaper articles have mentioned this fact. A couple of the most recent ones have appeared as late as July of this year and later. I would like to refer to an article in the Australian of 16 July which refers to a four-man deputation which advised the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that a proposed permanent National Crimes Commission should have access to tax records and so on. Included in the article was the comment from Mr Ballantine-Jones that the proposed Crimes Commission had to be established on a national basis and had to be permanent to have any impact . He is quoted as saying:
'At the moment we feel unco-ordinated procedures between State and Federal agencies are working to the benefit of criminals, and are not giving the community the type of protection it needs'.

I would suggest that that comment, amongst a whole host of others, refutes the sorts of States rights arguments that have been put forward by people such as Senator Crichton-Browne who argues that this Bill infringes the constitutional rights of the States. I would suggest that that argument would be a perfectly valid one if the criminals only knew that was what they were supposed to be doing, that they remained within State boundaries and allowed the State police force to apprehend them there. The police would need to use their law enforcement powers within the States on criminals who remained within the States . As it is, we had a situation that arose recently in which a policeman had difficulty in crossing a border simply to chase an ordinary criminal. Complaints were raised at that stage that there may have been an infringement of the constitutional powers of the police of one State moving into another State. I suggest that the problem is much more difficult when we are trying to cope with the extremely organised crime that is involved in drug running and various other forms of racketeering.

The Age of 24 June reports a call by a senior Victorian policeman for the establishment of a Crimes Commission to monitor organised crime. The policeman concerned was the Deputy Chief Commissioner of Police, Mr Rod Hall, who told a royal commission that a Crimes Commission should initiate or recommend action against organised crime. The article stated:
Mr Hall said that in 1978 the Victorian Criminal Intelligence Bureau had nominated more than 40 people suspected of being involved in organised crime in Victoria, who should be investigated.
But he said the force's resources allowed it to concentrate only on one or two of these people at a time.
The article continued:
Mr Hall said the Victorian Police's operational and other commitments did not enable investigators to devote much time to organised crime.

Earlier in the debate Senator Missen touched on the role played by the normal police agencies in this country and indicated, whether intentionally or not, a rather disparaging attitude to the police forces of this country. I cannot speak for the police forces of other States, but I know that most South Australians are proud of theirs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable senator. It is pleasing to hear an endorsement of that from the other side of the chamber. The comments made by Senator Missen, which I understand related to the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs, seemed to give the police forces in this country a sort of dumb cop tag which I do not believe they deserve. He suggested that part of the problem was that they were not intelligent enough, that university graduates were not being engaged at the senior levels and so on. He spoke as if a university degree somehow confers greater wisdom and ability on a law enforcement officer. He argued that the criminals were smarter than the police although I am not aware of too many criminals who have university degrees. I could not quite follow his argument. I suspect that in fact it is less to do with the academic qualifications of members of the police forces in this country , which are not as adequate as perhaps some of us would like, than it is to do with their manpower and the powers that in fact they have.

SPEECH.PARA: I am certainly not advocating that the police be given more wide, sweeping powers than they have or the kinds of powers envisaged for the National Crimes Commission. However, I am saying that it is not fair to imply or to assert that the police of this country are inadequate because they have not sufficient university graduates among their number. Nor am I sure that corruption will end in police forces, where it does exist, simply because some policemen have degrees.
The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), in his second reading speech , indicated support for these calls for a National Crimes Commission. The Minister said, amongst other things:

. . . a fresh look must be had at existing arrangements and institutions for the investigation and prosecution of criminal offences of a serious kind, particularly offences in the nature of organised crime.
The Minister went on to say:

. . . existing Australian law enforcement efforts need to be supplemented by the establishment of a new standing body with the necessary expertise and powers to make an effective attack on organised crime . . . the National Crimes Commission which will be given the functions and powers necessary to deal with forms of crime with which existing law enforcement bodies now have difficulty in coping.

The Minister went on to repeat that the intention was to supplement, not supplant, existing law enforcement agencies. On those grounds alone, the Australian Democrats are very much supportive of what the Government intends to do. This is not to say that we find the Bill perfect. Even the Government did not come up, first time around, with a perfect Bill. That is indicated by the fact that in the House of Representatives a number of Government amendments had to be introduced and the Government accepted a number of amendments from both a member of its own back bench and from the Australian Labor Party. They certainly improve the Bill in line with the comments of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee with regard to probable infringements of civil liberties and so on. Nevertheless , the amendments have not brought the Bill to the peak that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, as indicated by its latest report, would like to be reached.

I remind the Senate that on 2 September 1982 the Australian quoted Senator Chipp as saying that the setting up of the Commission was one of the most commendable things done by Mr Fraser. I would like to endorse that here and now. It is for this reason that, provided a number of amendments proposed by the Labor Party and by the Democrats are passed by the Senate, the Democrats have no intention of supporting a call by anybody that this Bill be referred to a committee. We state that for a number of reasons, the most important of which is that clause 41 seems to proclude the necessity to send the Bill to a committee. In effect, it is a sunset clause which brings the Bill into operation for five years. Should any loopholes, abuses or infringements of civil liberties become apparent in that time it will certainly be possible for the Government to take amending action to mitigate them. If, at the end of five years, no such action has been taken it will be up to the Parliament to prevent the National Crimes Commission from continuing beyond that initial five year period.

The main complaints that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee had about the Bill related to such things as the ambiguity about the types of offences the Commission can investigate; the lack of specificity concerning what might be seized under a search warrant; the authority to seize passports for up to three months; the fact that there appeared to be insufficient protection for individual reputations in the Commission's public hearings procedure; the absence of limits on cross-examination; the power to summon persons to give evidence without adequate notice of the nature of the inquiry; the failure to incorporate a person's right to refuse to testify against his or her spouse; inadequate definition of what constitutes a reasonable excuse for failure to produce requested documents; the indeterminability of possible gaol sentences for contempt; inconsistent penalty provisions for false or misleading evidence; inappropriate, severe penalties for contempt of the Commission, including the inadequately defined offences of insulting or interrupting the Commission; and the absence of the requirment of secrecy for Commission staff.

As I said earlier, a number of the amendments introduced in the lower House satisfied some of those doubts raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and a number of other doubts are also attacked, we say, by the amendments proposed by the Australian Labor Party. The absence of a requirement of secrecy for Commission staff is the substance of the Australian Democrat amendment to clause 36, which will be moved in the Committee stage. It is interesting to note that the Labor Party moved an amendment in the lower House, one which it does not intend proceeding with in the Senate, relating to the rights of a person to refuse to testify against his or her spouse. Although I know that Senator Evans' s reasons for not continuing with this amendment is different from my objection to it, I commend him for his action since it seems to me that this is an anachronism. I am more than pleased to see it not included in the National Crimes Commission Bill and hope that eventually it sees its way out of all the other legislation in this country in which it presently has a place. There is absolutely no reason why a spouse should not testify. As I said before, it is an anachronism. It is a vestige of when wives were nothing more than chattels. They had no rights of their own and it was a protection for husbands rather than anything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Careful, you will set off Senator Martyr.
—Heaven forbid that I should send off Senator Martyr.
—Where to? I wouldn't mind being sent to heaven.

—There may not be much chance of that. However, as I was saying before I was interrupted by an assortment of asides, I applaud the ALP's decision not to continue with this amendment, as I applaud the Government's decision not to include such a provision in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: There is indubitably a need for a National Crimes Commission. There is a need for some organisation with fairly sweeping powers to investigate national crime at a national level. It is interesting that of all the speakers on this Bill only one was not a member of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I wonder whether that is because other senators are more concerned with States rights than individual rights or because they felt they did not have time to consider it. The Bill has been mooted, the problem of national crime has been mooted and the need for a National Crimes Commission has been mooted for long enough for other honourable senators to have had the opportunity to prepare some sort of attitude to the legislation, so perhaps the make-up of the speakers on this Bill indicates those who cherish more than others the concept of civil liberties.

The Australian Democrats do support this legislation. We do intend to support a majority of the Australian Labor Party's amendments. We do commend the government for taking action to correct what is becoming an offensive intrusion of organised criminal activity in this country and we hope, in turn, to get the support of both the Government and the Australian Labor Party for our amendment to the National Crimes Commission Bill, which seeks to include secrecy provisions with relation to staff, members and counsel. I hope also to get support for our amendment to the Royal Commissions Amendment Bill which provides for compensation for witnesses appearing before a commission. I do not intend to say any more about that at the moment but will take the opportunity to speak on it during the Committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I still have a couple of reservations about the Bill but I will mention only the State rights situation. I have listened to the debate and I have read the appropriate papers. I wish that the essential matters had been ironed out with the States. No matter how we move away from it, it seems to me that we have unilaterally interfered with what up to date has been almost the sole and intimate province of the governments in the States. My worry is that my unqualified consent to this Bill might imply that I believe that the Western Australian Police Force is inept, and worse, and that the Western Australan Minister of Police is the same. I emphatically believe that the Western Australian Minister of Police is honest, capable and energetic.
—And highly intelligent.

—And highly intelligent. I think that he sees that his police force is the same. I wish that the essential matters had been ironed out with the States. I know that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has made every effort to accommodate reasonable amendments and that there is general agreement about the necessity for the Bill. I appreciate this effort, but I cannot overcome the essential difficulty that I have about the State rights, which in some ways take into consideration individuals' rights as well, so I shall be voting no on the voices on this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply -I thank all honourable senators who have spoken on the second reading in what has been a constructive debate. One feature of the debate has been widespread agreement among those speaking as to the need to take some new action to cope with organised crime in Australia. I do not wish to canvass the material set out very fully in other senators' speeches and set out in the second reading speech that was brought down setting out the Government's position at the beginning of this debate. But the acknowledgment of the reality of organised crime in Australia, the concern which has been evidenced about the inability of the existing instruments we have in the community to deal with it, and the common acceptance of the need for some fresh approach, were features of the debate. There are, of course, differences of opinion on some of the detail, and a couple of the contributors, in particular Senator Martyr and Senator Crichton-Browne expressed a concern about the interaction between the Commonwealth and the States with respect to the proposed National Crimes Commission. But I think that even in their speeches there is an acknowledgment of the reality of the problem with which the Government is attempting to come to grips.

SPEECH.PARA: In this response I do not intend to spend time on the points of detail that have been raised in the debate. They will be recanvassed in the Committee debate , and the Government's position, which has already been stated on most of the amendments in the House of Representatives, can be restated then. But out of respect for the very considered views which have been put down by honourable senators, I wish to make some comment in response. Senator Evans's contribution, consistent with the contributions of Senator Missen, Senator Tate and Senator Hill, brought out the general support that exists for the National Crimes Commission Bill. As I say, there was a good deal of comment on the detail of the Bill with which Senator Evans was prepared to take issue, but I note at this stage the support for the second reading which was foreshadowed in his speech, and the fact that by deliberative processes-which are really similar to the deliberative processes which have led the Government to its conclusion-he led us through to the point of saying that this was the option which needed to be pursued. That reinforces the validity of the Government's stance in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that, Senator?

—That was Senator Evans and, indeed, Senator Tate gave a similar analysis which very much reflects the sort of material which is contained in the paper which was put before the States by the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, and to which I think a number of senators have had access. I do not wish to weary the Senate but the reality of the existence of organised crime, the fact that there are limited options that we can pursue to come to grips with the problem that we have not come to grips with successfully in the past and the fact that the logical processes lead us to have a specialist body with a high degree of technical expertise and a high degree of intellectual skill to undertake the very difficult task of the gathering together of material and its subsequent analysis, is a matter on which it seems there is largely common ground in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose the major issue which has been raised relates relly to the question of the desire which I think was expressed by all contributors that there should be a high degree of Commonwealth-State co-operation in this area. A number of senators stressed the concerns of the States in the administration of criminal law, of the courts and State responsibility for police activities. I wish therefore to respond in more detail on that aspect of the debate than on the other matters of detail which were raised because those matters are less squarely raised by the debate which we may have at the Committee stage of the Bill.

From the outset the Commonwealth has kept the States fully informed of its concerns about the growth of organised crime in Australia and of the difficulties encountered by regular police forces in dealing with the problem. The matter has not been raised with the States only very recently. It was first raised at a meeting of Police Ministers in May 1982. Indeed, at the Premiers Conference of June 1982 at which I was present the Prime Minsiter (Mr Malcolm Fraser) raised with the Premiers the possible need to establish a new body in the form of a crimes commission. The Premiers agreed that the proposal should be referred to in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and the Australian Police Ministers Council, to report back by 1 October 1982. At that stage there was some indication of the desire of the Commonwealth to deal with this matter in a prompt way. After all, with the sort of evidence which has come before the Government, both from the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and from other reports which have been referred to in the debate, that is an understandable concern of the Government.

After the Premiers Conference there was a series of meetings of Attorneys- General and Police Ministers. At meetings of Attorneys-General and Police Ministers in August 1982 the Commonwealth circulated a paper making a specific proposal for the establishment of a crimes commission along the lines of the present Bill so that the Commonwealth proposition was squarely put before the States in August of this year. The meetings that were held then culminated in a joint meeting of Attorneys-General and Police Ministers on 24 September 1982. That meeting has been the subject of comment during the debate. As well as the Commonwealth proposal a number of State proposals were discussed and, while indicating that the Commonwealth position was based on the Commonwealth proposal previously circulated, Commonwealth Ministers indicated at that meeting that States' proposals merited further consideration and would be considered by the Commonwealth Cabinet on 28 September 1982. It needs to be made clear that at that same meeting Commonwealth Ministers made it clear that there was no commitment by the Commonwealth to hold action until the next proposed ministerial meeting on 5 November 1982. I am assured by Ministers present-I was not present-that this was an express matter, that there could be no guarantee that a decision would not be taken on 5 November.

Subsequent to the meeting in September, there was Cabinet consideration of the matter and careful consideration was given to the States' proposal. The Government decided that, because of the need to take effective steps to combat organised crime, it would and indeed must adhere to the Commonwealth proposal. The States and the Northern Territory were then informed by telex on 13 October 1982 of that decision and that legislation for this purpose would be introduced in the present parliamentary sittings. The Commonwealth was willing to continue discussions with the States with a view to accommodating, if possible, particular suggestions that the States might wish to make. Subsequently, at the instigation of some of the States, the meeting of 5 November was cancelled on the grounds that since the Bill was to be introduced, no useful purpose would be served by having a meeting. That is not a matter with which the Commonwealth agreed, but that was the reason for the cancellation. That was a view put by the States, not by the Commonwealth which was prepared to proceed with the meeting.

There was also the consideration that South Australia had an election the following day and Ministers from that State could not in any event attend. After that meeting, consultations still continued at officer level with at least some of the States. As a result of concerns expressed by those States, amendments were moved by the Government in the other chamber to the following effect: First , an amendment was made to ensure that where a State had conferred powers or functions on the Commission, agreement of that State would be obtained before any directions or guidelines were given to the Commission with respect to the performance of those functions. Secondly, an amendment was made to the clause dealing with the transmission of evidence to make it clear that any investigations the Commission referred to in that clause must be limited to the function of the Commission elsewhere specified in the Bill. Thirdly, a requirement was imposed on the Commission to inform the appropriate State Minister of its operations in respect of functions conferred by the law of that State.

Apart from those changes the Bill made very careful provision for participation by the States and the Northern Territory in several possible ways. Under the first procedure the States could confer powers and functions on the Commission. Under the second, functions or powers could be conferred by a State on a member of the Commission to be performed in conjunction with his powers and functions under the proposed Act. These provisions, and the amendments moved by the Government in the other chamber, demonstrate that the Commonwealth has a continuing desire that the States participate in this national effort and that we are prepared to take appropriate steps to that end. Indeed, we are ready to continue discussions with the States as to possible forms of their participation .

We would share the view which has been expressed by honourable senators in this debate and we certainly would have preferred that satisfactory arrangements had been settled with the States before the introduction of the legislation, but the exigencies of the parliamentary timetable and our belief that there is a pressing need for action to stem the growth of organised crime in the Commonwealth's own area of concern precluded deferral of the introduction of the legislation. The position is that the way remains open for the States to join in this important effort and, indeed, the Commonwealth hopes that there will be substantial co-operation between us.

I will just go back over some of that ground to point out some of the matters which I think were overlooked in the speeches which addressed themselves to this point. The fact is that there were two different forums of consultation-both Attorneys-General and Police Ministers. I think Senator Critchton-Browne referred to a working party. That was a reference to a working party which operated in the police forum. As I have said, the joint meeting of Attorneys- General and Police Ministers on 24 September had not only proposals from the States in front of it but also the Commonwealth's own proposal. It is important that there was an indication at that meeting that that still was the Commonwealth's view although there was to be Government consideration of the view then being promoted by the States. In fact, we decided that the alternative State proposal was not feasible, largely on the ground that it involved fragmentation of effort. As I said, the States were advised of that on 13 October by telex. The Bills were distributed to the States at a further meeting on 21 October. At that stage State officers declined to proceed further with the meeting, but it was open to the States to make suggestions at that time. It would not be correct to say that the Commonwealth was drawing on information learned from a joint working party in the process of drafting that legislation. Senator Durack had indicated the lines of the Commonwealth legislation at the initial Commonwealth-State Ministers meeting on 23 July. The States have been invited to submit or to indicate their specific concerns. As I have already said , changes have been made to the Bill in light of some of the concerns which have been expressed by the States.

The suggestion that the solution to the problem lies in the upgrading of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence was carefully considered by the Government. Of course, the fact that the Commonwealth is still agreeable to upgrading that unit is set out in the second reading speech. But the proposal as it was being developed would involve giving drastically different functions to the Bureau, which is now an intelligence gathering body. As has been generally agreed in speeches, as was recommended by Mr Costigan and as is the view of the Government, the key to the crimes commission proposal is the special powers which would be given to the Commission to require oral answers and the production of documents. It would be difficult to justify vesting such powers in a body such as the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. In the same way the sort of people who are appropriate to lead and direct a body with the powers and role contemplated for the Crimes Commission would be different in capacity, background and experience from the persons who might be appropriate to head the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. It is also incorrect to claim that the States saw-

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Commission use the Bureau? The second reading speech does not relate the two.

—The Bureau of Criminal Intelligence may well be a very useful source of information for the Crimes Commission. There is probably a need for some further discussion between the Commonwealth and the States about the interaction between the Bureau and the Crimes Commission. But if the Bureau is in possession of relevant material, obviously that is something which desirably would be made available to a crimes commission which was inquiring into any area about which the Bureau had relevant information.
—Isn't the ABCI subject to a States agreement in conjunction with the Commonwealth, to which the Crimes Commission has no knowledge?

—I think that is correct. That is why I indicated that it is a matter that will require further discussion between the Commonwealth and the States. But it would be a very odd situation if the Bureau had useful information and it was not made available to a body which was investigating organised crime on behalf of the Commonwealth in areas of Commonwealth responsibility and competence. Before the questions were raised, to which I responded, I was dealing with the claim, that the States saw an upgraded Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence as the only solution. In fact, the solution preferred by the States on 24 September was a series of ad hoc royal commissions with some attempt at co-ordination by an office of special commissions, with an upgraded Bureau of Criminal Intelligence being a subsidiary part of that general proposal. The objection to this scheme in the Commonwealth' s view was that it was a fragmentation of effort.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish again to canvass the sort of concerns which have been expressed by the Government, many honourable senators and Mr Costigan about the fact that the traditional royal commission is not the perfect model for the pursuit of organised crime leading through to prosecution. But the alternative proposal that there should be a series of royal commissions is one which I believe flies in the face of arguments which have been very broadly advanced in the debate on this Bill. I do not wish to prolong the Senate further. It would be useful if we at least advanced the Committee debate some way along the track this evening. I thank the honourable senators, as I said before, who have contributed to what I think has been a thoughtful and constructive debate. I commend the Bill to the Senate. I express the view on behalf of the Government that it is high time that organised crime was dealt with more effectively in Australia than it has been in the past. The Government puts forward this proposal for a crimes commission in the confident expectation that it will lead to a more effective attack on something which is of great concern to much of the community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave under, I think, Standing Order 135 to make a brief statement in respect of the vote which has just been cast.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that a great deal would be achieved tonight by seeking a division of the Senate, as would be necessary other than under the procedure which I am about to adopt. I should be very grateful if it could be recorded that I dissent from the motion that the National Crimes Commission Bill 1982 be read a second time. I understand that Senator Martyr will be seeking the same indulgence for the same reason, as a courtesy to the Senate and to give it an opportunity to expedite the debate. I should be grateful if I could record that vote. Perhaps at a later time I can explain the reasons to Senator Gareth Evans, who seems to be hanging on every word I am uttering.
—Your vote will be so recorded.
—by leave-I associate myself with the remarks of Senator Crichton-Browne. I would like my vote recorded against this Bill also .
—Your vote will be so recorded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 6-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 4, clause 7, sub-clause (2), leave out the sub-clause, insert the following sub-clause:
'(2) In this section, 'offence' means an offence-

(a) relating to organised criminal activities, that is to say, activities that appear to involve a number of offences connected with one another, several offenders and substantial planning and organisation;
(b) involving the use of sophisticated methods, planning or techniques; or
(c) relating to bribery or corruption involving officers of the Commonwealth or officers of a Territory.'.

This is probably the most important of all the Opposition's proposed amendments to this Bill. It goes to the jurisdiction of the National Crimes Commission and the matters in respect of which it is to have powers of investigation. The basic aim of the amendment, which I will explain in a little more detail in a moment, is to narrow the scope of the investigative jurisdiction of the Commission to something rather less than the enormous width that is encompassed by the present provision. The scope of the investigative jurisidiction of the Commission can best be appreciated by reading part of clause 7 (1) (a) as it presently stands. The clause states:
. . . the functions of the Commission are-
(a) to investigate of its own motion or at the request of the Attorney-General-
(i) any circumstance suggesting that an offence may have been . . . committed against a law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory;
(ii) any allegation that an offence has been, or is being, committed against a law of the Commonwealth or of a territory;

(iii) any circumstance suggesting that a person has or may have, or any allegation that a person has, influenced or attempted to influence an officer of the Commonwealth . . . to do any . . . thing contrary to law or to his duty . . .
(iv) any activity that is, or appears to be, impeding the implementation or enforcement of a law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory;

It will be appreciated that the Commission can, of its own motion if need be, without any reference from the Attorney-General, embark upon an investigation of any matter that occurs to it in relation to the possible breach of any law at all of the Commonwealth of Australia. It is this width or potential width of the jurisdiction of the Commission that has set so many nerve ends jangling among those who have been worried about the potential implications for this Commission should Australia move into a period of McCarthyist witch hunting of the kind, which, regrettably, has not been all that unfamiliar in our past and certainly not at all unfamiliar in the past of such countries as the United States of America which have been very keen on crimes commissions and similar bodies of this kind. To the extent that this body will retain something of an inquisitorial set of powers and to the extent that its jurisdiction will enable it to range as broadly as the present clause does, this is indeed a potentially dangerous institution. It must be appreciated that although there is in sub- clause (2) of clause 7 some attempt to restrict the scope of the investigative powers that the Commission may exercise, this is not mandatory in its effect and has no legal effect other than an exhortation to the Commission to confine itself to the particular matters here set out. To clarify what I am saying let me read sub-clause (2). It states:

(2) The Commission shall, in the course of investigating circumstances, allegations and activities referred to in paragraph (1) (a), seek, so far as practicable, to direct its activities in relation to-
(a) organized criminal activities, that is to say, offences that appear to be connected with one another and involve several offenders and substantial planning and organization;
(b) offences involving the use of sophisticated methods, planning or techniques ;
(c) bribery or corruption involving officers of the Commonwealth or officers of a Territory; and
This is expressed much more widely-
(d) other offences of kinds that persons or bodies engaged in law enforcement are experiencing special difficulty in investigating.

Even if one takes this purported qualification of the otherwise very broad ambit of clause 7 liberally, it will still be appreciated by honourable senators that the width of the jurisdiction that is available to the Commission is enormous. Moreover, I repeat the point that I made that sub-clause (2) as it presently stands does not have any actual legal effect; it is merely exhortatory.

What the Opposition seeks to achieve by its amendment is to narrow very substantially the scope of clause 7 by using, but in different contexts, some of those concepts that appear in the present draft of sub-clause (2). For those who have the Bill in front of them, what we have done in essence is to pick up sub- paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of sub-clause (2) as they presently stand-that is, the reference to organised crime, offences involving the use of sophisticated methods, planning or techniques, and bribery or corruption of the Commonwealth or Territory officers. We have built that back into the basic statement of the jurisdiction of the Commission in clause 7 (1) (a) by saying that these are the sorts of offences and only the sorts of offences that can be investigated by the Commission. I think that is a very important amendment.

The need to keep the ambit of the Commission narrowly directed towards organised crime properly so called or definitions of offences that are limited in the way I have indicated becomes particularly acute if one starts to look about the statute books with perhaps a rather jaundiced or sceptical eye and thinking about the context in which, if this amendment does not go through, the Crimes Commission could spread its wings. For example, if one looks at the existing Commonwealth Crimes Act one finds the notoriously broad ranging set of essentially political offences which are contained in the early sections of that Act and which deal with crimes such as treachery, sabotage, seditious enterprise and so on which are capable of enormously wide political application should a government or a crimes commission investigating possible breaches of these provisions be minded to embark upon them. Let us take section 24D of the existing Crimes Act which makes an offence the writing, printing, uttering or publication of any seditious words. Seditious words are defined as words which bring the Sovereign into hatred or contempt and which can be described as exciting disaffection against the government of the Commonwealth or against either House of the Parliament or against the connection of the Queen's Dominions under the Crown. So much for what could be described as fairly routine expressions of republican sentiment. They are technically caught by the extraordinarily wide language and rather ancient language of section 24D. Someone who is engaged in promoting feelings of ill-will or hostility between different classes of subjects so as to endanger the peace, order and so on can also come within the scope of section 24D. The mere allegation that someone may be about to engage in this type of activity could, if clause 7 of this proposed Act stays unamended, be brought within the scope of a Crimes Commission investigation.

Similarly, if one has regard to the provisions in the Crimes Act governing official secrecy one will see that section 70 deals with the prohibition of the disclosure of information by Commonwealth officers. Section 76 deals with the wilful obstruction of or resistance to Commonwealth officers in the discharge of their duties. That is very wide. More particularly, relating to official secrets , section 79 makes it an offence to communicate Commonwealth material to any unauthorised person. This again is the sort of thing that could come within the scope of a MacCarthyist operation should circumstances change and the Crimes Commission be minded to embark upon this. Section 30B, the absolutely extraordinary provision of the Crimes Act, relates to the membership of unlawful associations-unlawful associations being described elsewhere in the Act as bodies which advocate or encourage the overthrow of the Constitution by force or violence, the overthrow of the established government or the destruction or injury of property of the Commonwealth or property used in trade and commerce. An organisation affiliated with any organisation which advocates or encourages any of these doctrines or practices is caught by the scope of this provision, and so on and so forth.

Then there are provisions which have been the subject of debate in this chamber . They relate, for example, to uranium. Under the Atomic Energy Act it is an offence to communicate certain restricted information, to acquire or to remove information and to unlawfully communicate information with an intent to prejudice defence and so on. I simply make the point-I could go on making it ad nauseam were I to spend more time scouring the Commonwealth statute book-that there are an enormous array of crimes on the statute book, some of them ancient, some of them of more modern creation, which have the potential to be used as vehicles for political persecution by a crimes commission that happened to choose to embark upon a McCarthyist inquisitorial enterprise of this kind. I am not suggesting that that is within anyone's immediate contemplation at the moment but when we are legislating in this area we have to approach the matter with a jaundiced, sceptical eye and with a view to what words can mean rather than perhaps in the first instance what they are likely to be applied to mean.

It is for all these reasons that we argue that the scope of section 7 must be drastically restricted. It is argued by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in response to this kind of concern, which was expressed by the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills, that to set even the rather wide-ranging definitions as to the jurisdiction of the Commission, to build these back into section 7 in the way that I am proposing, would be to create an opportunity for endless litigation by people the subject of investigation by the Commission who could then be in a position to argue that the particular investigation was beyond the Commission's statutory charter.

That is a point that has to be given some weight, but I make two answers in respect of it. The first answer is that I think that perhaps overstates the extent to which attacks could be launched on the jurisdiction of the Commission. Provided the Commission is acting in reasonable good faith, it would be very difficult to establish that the kinds of things with which, say, the Costigan Royal Commission, with its orientation, was concerned would not be covered by this language. That is to say, it was concerned with offences or possible offences relating to organised criminal activities involving the use of sophisticated methods or relating to bribery or corruption of Commonwealth officers. Those concepts are very large and would not give very much scope for any ordinary kind of crimes commission investigation of the kind that is no doubt being contemplated by the Commonwealth as being sabotaged by adventurous litigation of that kind.

The other answer I make is that even if there would remain some residual scope for destructive or obstructive litigation of the kind the Commonwealth is proposing, that is a price we ought to be prepared to pay for the guarantee that this legislation will not be able to be used in the way that so many people have feared that it might be used; that is as a vehicle for the political oppression of dissentients in this community. I believe the amendment the Opposition is proposing in this respect is a moderate one. It is an extremely important one. It goes to the heart of what this legislation is all about and to the heart of concerns that people have expressed about it. But it does not do so in a way that is destructive of the basic concepts and intentions lying behind the legislation. The Opposition's amendment in this respect is genuinely intended and I hope the chamber will respond accordingly to what is meant to be a constructive suggestion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Evans is greatly exaggerating the importance of this amendment and the significance of what he sees as deficiencies in clause 7. He said that some of the crimes which come under the Crimes Act are outdated. Certainly a review could be done. It is a different matter altogether to suggest that they might be used for McCarthyist purposes. I have no doubt that some of the offences that have existed for years in lanes that have not been used are not going to be suddenly plucked out of the air by the National Crimes Commission in trying to mount some sort of McCarthyist investigation. Therefore, whilst I believe there is a need to review the Crimes Act-that certainly is an important point-at the same time it does not seem to me likely that the Act will be misused in the course of a National Crimes Commission action.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 7 provides that the Commission, in the course of investigating, will seek as far as practicable to direct its activities to four major areas. The amendment seeks to define an offence as organised criminal activity or the use of sophisticated methods. That is a summary of the two paragraphs of the amendment. Very curiously, when this point was debated in the House of Representatives the amendment moved by Mr Lionel Bowen listed three types of offences. Somehow the offence relating to bribery or corruption involving officers of the Commonwealth-

TALK.START.PARA: —It has gone back to three.

—The copy that Senator Evans supplied me with did not contain the third one. The Opposition's amendment now includes the three types of offences. The fourth offence to which Senator Evans apparently objects very strongly is set out in paragraph (d) of sub-clause (2), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: other offences of kinds that persons or bodies engaged in law enforcement are experiencing special difficulty in investigating.

It seems to me that this is an area in which there should be concentration on the part of the National Crimes Commission. If other bodies are finding great difficulty in investigating offences then the National Crimes Commission should be expected to give special attention to them. I cannot really see what the objection to that is. I know that the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills raised some general objections to the vagueness of what might be examined. On reflection and seeing the replies and what is contained in this clause, I do not really feel that the functions as set out are unreasonable. Of course, the Commission will be subject to close scrutiny by the Parliament and by others.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would you test it? How would you challenge a wrongful exercise of power by the Commission? Where is the procedure? Where is the machinery to do it?
—The machinery, of course, is in this Parliament.
—Nonsense. You have a chance in five years time.
—The machinery is in this Parliament, apart from any actions of the High Court or the Federal Court--
—In five years time the legislation comes up for review.

—That is a different matter. I am not talking about the sunset clause, which is a further way. I believe that the Opposition is exaggerating the difficulties involved. The matters which are set out in this clause limit the Commission. It ought to concentrate on these matters. I think that there is no basis for supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 7 (2) (d) states:

SPEECH.PARA: other offences of kinds that persons or bodies engaged in law enforcement are experiencing special difficulty in investigating.

I recognise that subsequent provisions-such as clause 8- specifically allow for co-operation, coercion and participation by the States. It seems to me that the elimination of paragraph (d) detracts from the thrust and the principle of the States' proposal that the Commission should be of a task force nature rather than a standing inquisitorial royal commission. For that reason I oppose its deletion. Frankly, the deletion of paragraph (d) would strengthen the objections that I have to the legislation as it stands. Left in, it would at least give some certainty of further expansive co-operative arrangements between the States and the Commonwealth.

(3) Statistics are not available of the number of persons engaged in the north Queensland tin industry at 30 June 1982 although the number was probably less than the quoted figure of 1600. The number of persons so engaged has certainly fallen since that date but it is not possible to indicate the extent of the reduction.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Hotels and Motels: Accessibility to Disabled Travellers

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 18 November 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Department of Industry and Commerce commission a national survey of hotels and motels to determine their accessibility to disabled travellers in 1981: If so, were the results of the survey made available to the Department in January 1982.
(2) Was it the Department's intention to publish this material as an accommodation guide by May 1982.
(3) Has the guide been published, if not, when will it be published, and what provision has been made for regular updating.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1981 the Department of Industry and Commerce commissioned the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled (ACROD), in association with the Australian Automobile Association (AAA), to survey Australian accommodation establishments with appropriate facilities for disabled travellers. The results of the survey were made available to the Department in January 1982.

(2) It was the Department's intention to publish an accommodation guide for the disabled in early 1982. However, there have been unavoidable delays in its publication. These delays included the need to correct some minor errors in the data, seeking advertising which might have provided additional information for disabled travellers, and in printing.

(3) The guide is now expected to be published during December 1982. No provision has been made for regularly updating the guide. Options for its possible updating could be considered by interested organisations when the demand for and re-action to the guide is known.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Nuclear Test Program: Effects on Servicemen

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 23 November 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have fifty-seven (57) servicemen and others involved in the nuclear test program at Monte Bello Island and Maralinga and in the subsequent clean-up and transport of equipment died from cancer.
(2) What action is being taken to ascertain the instances of cancer among servicemen and civilians who were involved in the series of nuclear tests conducted at Monte Bello Island and Maralinga.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As many as 16,000 Australian servicemen and civilians may have been associated with the atomic tests. National mortality statistics show that from such a number considerably more than 57 can be expected to have died from cancer . A final estimate of the number of cancer deaths expected cannot be given until the group involved in the tests has been defined, and dates of birth determined.

(2) My Department is co-ordinating an intensive investigation into the involvement of Australians in the United Kingdom atomic weapons test program conducted in Australia during the 1950s and early 1960s. The investigation includes a study of all Australian personnel who may have been connected with the program and who have been traced.

The study aims to identify any connection between the atomic tests and the subsequent state of health of those who were associated with them and, in particular, to compare among the difficult work units involved, the prevalence of conditions, including cancer, which may be caused by exposure to radiation. A study of causes of death will also be carried out.

The Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council has undertaken an investigation into the nature and distribution of fallout from the atomic tests to identify what possible harmful effects, if any, there may have been on the health of the Australian population. The results of this investigation will be tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2033) Senator Colston asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a comment in Inside Canberra which states:
'The Department of Industry and Commerce will settle the dispute between the Sydney brewer Tooth and Co. and the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights' Union'.

The dispute referred to centres on Tooth and Co. Ltd letting a contract to a United States manufacturer for $10m to $15m worth of stainless steel beer barrels. Will the Department of Industry and Commerce settle the dispute? If so , how will it do so?
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
I am aware of the article referred to by the honourable senator and of other recent media reports that a contract to supply beer barrels to Sydney firm Tooth and Co. has gone to an American firm.

The article suggests that the Department would refuse to grant by-law admission on the barrels thereby subjecting them to a duty of 15 per cent. The article goes on to suggest that faced with this duty it is unlikely that the order would go outside Australia.
I am informed that no application for by-law has been made on the barrels, and I understand that the company has no intention of doing so.
The Department of Industry and Commerce has had discussions with Tooth and Co. and the local manufacturing industry on this matter.

Apparently initial quotes from Australian suppliers were significantly above the duty paid prices quoted by a number of overseas manufacturers including one manufacturer in the United States of America. I understand a revised quote from local industry was not received until after Tooth and Co. had taken its commercial decision to place the order with the United States manufacturer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2399) Senator Lewis asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is about the rebate for excise on diesel fuel used for agricultural purposes, is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. The rebate has been in force for a period of two months or more. I ask the Minister: When will the necessary forms to claim the rebate be available?
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Diesel fuel rebate claim forms could not be printed or circulated prior to the passage of the relevant legislation which occurred on 26 October 1982.

Claim forms were provided to oil companies on 1 November 1982 for distribution to their agents and fuel suppliers. Forms were also available at the same time at all offices of the Australian Customs Service.
The first completed claims were received by the Customs Service on 3 November 1982 and processing commenced on 8 November. The first payments were made during the week commencing 15 November 1982.
